TALK.START.PARA: —-I am giving these notices today because this is the last sitting day upon which it is possible to do so. The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is concerned that drafting deficiencies exist in these two instruments. The nature of these defects is such that an intended right of AAT review of a discretion granted to a public official may be nullified. It is a breach of parliamentary propriety for an instrument to fail to effect its stated purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case the instrument not only is defective in this regard but also leaves individuals without a right of review of an administrative discretion, which may be a breach of personal rights. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns of the Committee.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows--
Australian Horticultural Corporation (Dried Fruits Export Control) Regulations Statutory Rules 1991 No.199
Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection (Avocado) Regulations
Statutory Rules 1991 No. 207

These Regulations are principal Regulations made to effect recent changes to legislative schemes provided for by the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Act 1991 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991. Both are important instruments, the first providing the Australian Dried Fruits Board with power to recommend on the granting of licences, to set quota allocations for exports and export markets, to set quality standards and minimum prices, and to approve overseas agents. The second prescribes avocados as both a leviable and chargeable horticultural product, sets rates of levy and export charge, prescribe the industry body with which the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation must consult, provide for the manner of payment of levies and charges, and require the keeping of records.

The Committee was concerned that apparent drafting errors in both sets of Regulations may be so serious as to affect the validity of review provisions. The view of the Committee is that the drafting and presentation of delegated legislation should be of a standard not less than that of an Act of Parliament. Anything less is a breach of parliamentary propriety. This is particularly so when the defects may nullify the right to an independent, external review of the merits of administrative decisions, taken by public officials, which may adversely affect the livelihood of persons engaged in production for export. The Committee has an express mandate from the Senate to ensure appropriate review of administrative decisions. In addition, lack of such review is a breach of personal rights, in respect of which the Committee also has a mandate to act.
The Committee has written to the Minister seeking advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The coalition supports the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 and continues its bipartisan support for this whole Aboriginal education policy which, as I said, has received support in the past and is receiving support now. This Bill amends the original Act of 1989. It is purely an administrative Bill and, in itself, does not provide supplementary assistance or have any financial implications. The original Act underpins the Aboriginal education policy which not only had cross-party support but has been endorsed by State and Territory governments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill does two things: it integrates the higher education component of the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 with the Aboriginal participation initiative within the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. This will mean institutions will support participation by Aboriginal students within their total education program rather than have their support come from two different sources. There is an ambiguity in the original Bill as to whether an indexation formula should be read as year on year or quarter on quarter. The intention and convention have been that year on year is used and this Bill clarifies the original intention.

I would like to make a few points about this whole policy because prior to the introduction of an Aboriginal education policy, there was good evidence that 10 to 15 per cent of Aboriginal students in the compulsory schooling years were not participating in primary and basic secondary schooling. This was despite the national expectation that all school-age children would receive such schooling. Also, participation rates for Aboriginal people in post compulsory schooling were only about one-third of the number for all other Australians.

These concerns led to the development of an Aboriginal education policy which came out of the Hughes report of 1988. This report found that, despite improvements over the past two decades, Aboriginal people remain the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. The need to develop this coordinated and comprehensive policy for Aboriginal people was recognised as a priority by all sides of politics. It was based on these findings that this policy was developed, involving agreement between the Commonwealth and all State and Territory governments and, of course, all political parties.

The problem was to define the appropriate roles of the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments in the policy, with the Commonwealth adopting a strategic planning and monitoring role while the operation and implementation role is largely a function of the States. This seems to be a model that could perhaps effectively be extended in other areas of Aboriginal programs where that kind of coherence and cooperation does not exist.

There are two main programs under the Aboriginal education policy: firstly, the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program; and, secondly, Abstudy direct assistance. The Aboriginal education strategic initiative program funds operational plans, the Aboriginal student support and parents awareness program and Aboriginal language initiatives. It includes supplementary funding for Aboriginal education strategies of higher education institutions, which has now been transferred. Abstudy direct assistance incorporates non-income support elements of Abstudy. It has two programs consisting of the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme and the vocational educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme.

The year 1990 was the first year of the triennium of operation of what is overall a $229m program, roughly ranging from $70m in 1990 to $80m in 1992, and that is, of course, is in 1990 dollar terms. A review will take place in the first year of the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme. This year, 1991, is the first year of the vocational educational guidance for Aboriginals scheme. At this stage it is not possible fully to assess the effectiveness of this scheme.

However, there are some areas of weakness. Firstly, the information coming back to the Federal Government, which is largely dependent upon the States and Territories for that information, indicates that the scheme appears to have been fairly slow in operation. Certainly, the Commonwealth's early monitoring of the scheme has not been adequate. But that, of course, may be overcome as the scheme gets over its early problems.

Secondly, the Aboriginal tutorial assistance scheme, while a very good scheme in concept, works on the basis of establishing a large number of Aboriginal homework centres. This in itself may not appear to be a bad thing, given the home conditions under which many Aboriginal students try to work. It is very important that Aboriginal people have a place to do their homework, but one wonders why there is any need to establish a separate centre for homework rather than look at further extending already existing schools where the facilities are actually there. Why could these homework centres not be in fact the schools? Why create new centres? There must remain the suspicion that this decision to have separate centres may have more to do with the policy of the teacher unions than with the efficient delivery services to Aboriginal people.

While this program does not relate directly to Abstudy, Abstudy is nevertheless fundamental to Aboriginal education. There are some concerns on the Opposition side that there is a very lax definition of Aboriginality for Abstudy payments. This matter has been raised by the Auditor-General. It should be clear-cut and easy to establish who is an Aboriginal for the purpose of Abstudy and other Aboriginal programs. It should be easy to establish the exact number of people who describe themselves as Aboriginal--in other words, people who identify themselves with an Aboriginal community--because they put themselves down on the 1986 census as such. With the known mortality rates and so on, it is reasonable for us to have a clear view of what the numbers should be.

If we look at the number of people who have claimed to be Aboriginal--to have Aboriginality--and then look at the take-up of Abstudy, we find that in relating the two figures 72 per cent of all Aboriginal people between 12 and 18 years of age are getting some form of Abstudy and that of those between 12 and 44 years of age more than one-third of every predicted Aboriginal person in Australia is receiving Abstudy. Clearly, the reality would be that not more than a third of all Aboriginal people between 12 and 44 years of age are getting some sort of higher education. Clearly, that is a matter that needs to be looked at to make certain that the benefit is going to the people for whom it is intended--that is, the Aboriginal people of Australia.

There is another slight problem that should be raised-- that is, the teachers within the system not having the capacity to communicate with Aboriginal people who do not speak English. There are some schools in central Australia where the basic language, for example, could be Aranda. It appears that probably 10 per cent of Aboriginal people in Australia do not use English in the home. For many people, English would not be a second language; in fact, it would be a totally foreign language which is not understood. That is why it is vital that teachers in these areas should have a capacity to communicate in the language used in those regions.

That is not to suggest that English should not be introduced into those schools--obviously it should. A failure to do so would limit the capacity of Aboriginal people, if they wished, to participate fully in the Australian society. It explains why it is so difficult for students, who may have no working knowledge of English, coming into schools, and obviously a program entirely in English does not meet their needs. That is a point in passing. The fact is, of course, that good educational opportunities are fundamental to Aboriginal people having the opportunity to be full participants in Australian society. This Bill continues that course and, as a result, has the total support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill is a piece of legislation which is basically administrative. The character of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy will remain unchanged. The passage of the Bill does provide, however, an opportunity to review the situation which Aboriginal and Islander people currently face.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal Act which this amendment relates to signalled the beginning of the Labor Government's decision, supported by the Australian Democrats, to endorse a national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy. Two years down the track for this policy, which aims for cooperation between all State, Federal and Territory governments, we have seen some improvements and also room for further progress. Part of the problem with developing effective educational opportunities for indigenous peoples in Australia is that the education system in this country, particularly with respect to higher education, is in bad shape, thanks to the management--or mismanagement--of Mr Dawkins.

With tertiary institutions so starved of funding, there is even less likelihood that proper attention will be paid to the issue of Aboriginal education. Recently Dr Mary Ann Bin-Salik, who has been involved in the tertiary field since 1975 and who is one of only four Aboriginal women to have attended Harvard University, wrote a book called Aboriginal Tertiary Education in Australia: How Well Is it Serving the Needs of Aborigines?. She was quoted earlier this year as saying:

Tertiary education isn't filling the needs of Aborigines very well because of funding. Most higher institutions aren't really committed to Aboriginal education--I think some are but we have a long way to go. Some institutions are receiving money for Aboriginal programs, but I don't think they are using it usefully; they don't have well-defined policies.

Recently we have also seen the Northern Territory Government cutting education funding, adversely affecting the provision of education services to Aboriginals in many parts of the Territory. In Queensland, in another example of the Goss Government's heavy-handed approach to problems affecting Aboriginal and Islander people, we saw teachers being withdrawn from the school at the Aurukun community.

As with many other issues, how seriously we address this matter will impact on the effectiveness and ultimate success of the reconciliation process which the Parliament has just implemented. Education has to be a central part of this process, both through educating non-Aboriginal Australians about the history of this country and by ensuring that appropriate and adequate educational opportunities are available to Aboriginal and Islander people. Setting up appropriate strategies is a good step but, as with the national Aboriginal health strategy, it can be little more than a hollow con unless it is backed up with sufficient and stable funding.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the sections of the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which dealt with the education issue. I have referred to this report in various speeches because I believe it is essential that we do not ignore the wealth of information and ideas which the report provides. It provides a detailed perspective which is independent of political parties and bureaucracies, so it is free of any empty rhetoric which otherwise it might have. On the education issue, it provides a good guide to how much progress has been made and, in contrast to many other issues in the report, education receives a generally favourable appraisal in the sense that things appear to be moving in a generally positive direction.

The report identified the double bind which schooling presents to Aboriginal and Islander people. In essence, the problem which occurs is that the schooling process is almost by definition assimilationist, but it provides many skills and resources which are essential to provide the indigenous people with greater control over their own lives and future.

I believe that this can be overcome as long as the maximum degree of participation in the educative process is provided to Aboriginal and Islander people. This principle is embodied in the first long term goal of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, and it is an essential principle not only in education but also in all aspects of Aboriginal and Islander issues. I quote the following passage from the report:

The important thing is the Aboriginal people are allowed to choose a direction for themselves. The only chance for improving education as a social resource for Aboriginal people will come as a result of Aboriginal people deciding for themselves what it is they require of education and then having the means of determining how that end is to be achieved.

As ATSIC develops, the role that it plays as representative of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community in supervising and having input on the suitability of education services to indigenous people must also be developed. There is evidence of the odd teething problem with ATSIC, but it is essential that it has a proper role in the education issue--and I believe that role is being developed.

One other interesting aspect of the Royal Commission's report was the focus it placed on preschooling. This is one area of education that is often ignored, yet its importance, being in the formative years of a person's life, is obvious. The Commission specifically recommended that governments and education consultative groups pay great attention to the fact that the scope of the national Aboriginal and Islander education policy extends to preschooling programs and that it should be recognised that, to a considerable extent, the success of the whole education policy will turn on the success of the preschooling initiatives. I take this opportunity to remind the Government of this recommendation and call on it to ensure that it is being followed up.

The report also indicated that we have some way to go in developing curricula that are appropriate for Aboriginal and Islander children's learning needs. Curricula also need to be improved so that they reflect to all Australians the fact that white Australia has a black history--and it was not just a history of problems. The report outlined the fact that many Aboriginal communities and groups have identified the need for education curricula to include a course of study to inform students on social issues, such as the legal system, civil liberties and drug and alcohol abuse.

Leaving aside the question of adequate funding, we still have evidence of increasing retention rates for Aboriginal students, of the valuable role played by Aboriginal education workers in the teaching process and of the development of further independent Aboriginal schools. For me, one of the most recent and pleasing developments in this regard is the opening this year of the Pemulwuy High School in inner Sydney. Developments such as this maximise opportunities for self-reliance and Aboriginal participation, and should be encouraged and supported.

This Bill relates in an administrative way to the ongoing operation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy. This policy focuses on issues of curriculum but, as it focuses on funding and coordination, it must be considered as part of overseeing the educative process.

Another area where curriculum still needs improvement is that which is taught to trainee teachers. Teacher training courses need to provide trainees with greater knowledge and understanding of the educational needs and views of Aboriginal and Islander people. There is absolutely nothing more unhelpful and wasteful of resources than sending teachers who know little of Aboriginal attitudes, customs and needs to teach at a predominantly Aboriginal school. Consistent with my previous remarks, indigenous people must be more involved in training courses. It is not a negative picture that I am painting; there is much to be positive about in the development of education practices which meet the needs of Aboriginal and Islander people.

The education policy was specifically addressed by the Royal Commission's report. I would like to finish by reiterating the Royal Commission's report on this policy. The Commission recognises the value of the policy, but is conscious of the dangers which are present if it is not adhered to in the right spirit. This is why the actions of governments and the outcomes of the policy need to be continually analysed and reviewed to see whether progress is occurring at sufficient speed. As long as the goals of the policy are strongly adhered to, the direction of progress will continue to be generally positive.

The Commission pays particular attention to the first long term goal, which I mentioned previously, as being of special significance in providing Aboriginal people with an appropriate level of control. The Commission's recommendation is as follows:
At every stage of the application of the National Aboriginal Education Policy the utmost respect be paid to the first long-term goal expressed in the policy, that is:

To establish effective arrangements for the participation of Aboriginal parents and community members in decisions regarding the planning, delivery and evaluation of preschool, primary and secondary education services for their children;

It be recognised that the aims of the Policy are not only to achieve equity in education for Aboriginal and Islander people but also to achieve a strengthening of the identity, decision making and self-determination of the indigenous people. . .

I think it is important to note that the Commission believes it is unlikely that either of these aims can be achieved without the achieving of the other. What we must do is ensure that we do all we can to make sure that those aims are achieved.

This Bill is a small part in the process of achieving those aims. As we move forward in a spirit of cooperation and reconciliation, I hope that over the rest of this decade the Parliament and future governments of whatever complexion stay true to these aims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise today to address the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991, particularly because of the comments that I read by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, in the other chamber on 11 September in which he primarily attacked the Northern Territory Government's expenditure and efforts on Aboriginal education. I think many people would be well aware that Mr Snowdon has his roots in radical teacher union politics and Aboriginal land politics and not, unfortunately, in the efficient, proper and appropriate delivery of educational services. By comparison, I believe that the present Minister for Education in the Northern Territory, Shane Stone, and the former Minister for Education, Tom Harris, have both for a long time been focusing the interests in the Northern Territory very specifically on the needs of a decent and proper Aboriginal education policy that ensures that Aboriginal students are being properly developed and focused in many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: For too long the Federal Government has used the Northern Territory as a trial place for social and economic experiments where it would not often use such experimental schemes elsewhere in Australia. Too often these schemes are targeted at Aboriginal people where the Labor Party, the media and the wider Australian public never experienced first-hand the consequences of these actions. I, therefore, want to address the issue where social justice for territorians, particularly Aborigines, is being neglected by the present Federal Labor Government. The hollow rhetoric of the ALP is too often hypocritical. To me, the measure of educational success should be the number of people in real jobs, not being in handout situations.

As long ago as 1973, in a report of the interim committee of the Australian Schools Commission, the issue of equality of educational opportunity in Australian education was taken up. The report reinforced the view that achievement and attainment levels were firmly linked to the socioeconomic circumstances of the student's home environment. It became apparent that, if there were to be any improvement in the educational achievements of students in the poorest sections of the Australian community, there would need to be positive discrimination in favour of these students.

The Commonwealth Government introduced the disadvantaged schools program in 1974 to address these needs. This program was one of several to support children and communities in their areas of educational need. It was specifically introduced to assist schools to change their approach to teaching and to assist students attending schools in the poorest parts of the Australian community. In order to achieve this, a target group was formed to identify accurately these schools so that the program resources were delivered to the most needy schools. The Commonwealth Schools Commission had to make fundamental decisions on what social criteria were to be employed.

It is now ancient history, but those decisions were seriously flawed. Since its commencement, the disadvantaged schools program has failed to help those in the greatest need. Schools were adopted as the unit of funding rather than as individuals. They were ranked in order of eligibility. It is this ranking which has so obviously incensed the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, and prompted him to make some comments in the other chamber on 11 September this year. However, the honourable member for the Northern Territory has assumed, in his normal fashion, that it was the fault of the Northern Territory Government. However, he has either been misled by his Labor mates or his own ignorance, or he is deliberately concocting a saga in this area.

The disadvantaged schools formula made use of 38 census variables, including socio-economic status, the extent of schooling, unemployment, Aboriginality, ethnicity and housing. The methodology also conducted resources on a sliding scale that provided a higher proportion of resources in ratio to the depth of poverty of the school. In 1979, the Commonwealth Schools Commission knew that all was not well with the formula. It was decided to revise the indicator of disadvantage and to improve the methodology using techniques that reflected more accurately the social composition of schools.

In 1983 the Labor Government initially agreed with the assessment made by Dr Ross of Deakin University on his findings in this area in his study entitled `Social Area Indicators of Educational Need'. By November 1983 all States and Territories were invited to join, with the Commonwealth, a national working party on the index of disadvantage to which Dr Ross was an adviser. The working party developed the following dimensions that were found to be significant in identifying disadvantaged schools: occupation, education, income, family, accommodation, tenancy, crowding, language and Aboriginality.

A review conference of the disadvantaged schools program was held in Sydney in June 1984 at which the Commonwealth, all States and Territories, parent groups, the National Aboriginal Education Committee and the then Department of Aboriginal Affairs were present. Several major recommendations were made at the conference. These included, firstly, that non-English speaking Aborigines and Asians be included in the new index, as would all other non-English speaking groups; secondly, that all the variables agreed to by the working party should be retained in the index; and, thirdly, that any weighting mechanism adopted and upon which funding distribution would be based should be a fair one and should be linked directly to disadvantage.

Case studies undertaken in Victoria and Queensland--also copied separately in the Northern Territory--demonstrated the effectiveness of the Ross methodology. One has to remember that, through all of this, the disadvantaged schools program continued dispensing funds to schools considered disadvantaged under its existing flawed criteria.

By early 1985 a further meeting of the working party agreed that the existing resources allocation methodology was inequitable and had no basis in research. It was agreed that the Ross methodology, as undertaken in the pilot study, should be adopted for a national index of disadvantage. The decision in 1985 to adopt an objective methodology started a long, protracted struggle that continues today to the detriment of all Territorians but in particular to the detriment of my Aboriginal constituents in the Northern Territory.

The struggle arose because, to adopt the pilot study approach on a national basis, a significant reallocation of funding was necessary. The pilot study methodology readily identified the very poor communities and their particular socioeconomic structures. It proved what had been suspected for years: many of the disadvantaged schools were being discriminated against by the program established to help them. It also happened that schools in the Northern Territory--particularly schools in remote Aboriginal communities--were among those doing without.

What ensued was an impasse--a protracted debate between the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth on the implementation of a fair and equitable indicator. The Commonwealth was faced with two options. Firstly, adopt a stable index which weighted all dimensions equally and reallocate funding away from the disadvantaged Labor voting electorates in the cities or, secondly, adopt an indicator that maintained the status quo. This would avoid a reallocation of resources to those who need them desperately, but it would mean cheating through the adoption of a less stable indicator. A model approximating the first option was endorsed by the then National Aboriginal Education Advisory Committee to the Commonwealth because it clearly identified the extreme poverty of Aborigines in remote areas. The Australian Council of Government Schools also endorsed the proposal, as did the national Isolated Children's Parents Association.

However, those based in western Sydney, Melbourne or any other southern city who are accustomed to disadvantaged school funding were not to be deserted so readily by the Labor Party. A contrived reference group on the definition of disadvantage was established to debate the proposals of Dr Ross in his notable absence. It received a draft report which dismissed most of the factors that indicated a need to reallocate resources and took no account of Aboriginal needs. After complaints from the Northern Territory Government, its author, Dr Manning, reviewed his findings. He identified that Aborigines did have special needs and recommended that they should receive double the funding of other eligible students and that any school with more than 25 per cent Aboriginal enrolment should be automatically declared a disadvantaged school.

In 1988, a publication entitled Indicators of Socio-Economic Disadvantage for Australian Schools included a demonstration by Dr Ross of the impact of various weightings on the dimensions which are used to construct an indicator of poverty. Dr Ross provided a table demonstrating the disadvantage ratio for two indicators--Q, the preferred Commonwealth indicator, and G, for each State and Territory. Indicator Q gives a heavy weighting to a dimension occupation that, for the most part, excludes the Northern Territory Aboriginal population. Indicator G gives equal weighting to all dimensions, including occupation, and picks up the remote Aboriginal schools.
Dr Ross's comments concerning the table presented for indicator G were:
The most striking feature (of the disadvantage ratio) was the magnitude of disadvantage ratios for both sectors in the Northern Territory.

The ratios indicated that, if indicator G was used, the Northern Territory had 3.7 times the national rate of socioeconomic disadvantaged of the rest of Australia. This was largely caused by the extreme poverty associated with remote Aboriginal schools. After seven years of criticism of the existing model from consultants, the Schools Commission, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the National Aboriginal Education Committee, the Australian Council of Government Schools, the Isolated Children's Parents Association and the Northern Territory Government, the Federal Department of Employment, Education and Training finally acted to produce a change through the introduction of what it calls the 1991 indicator.

Who stands to benefit from the changes within the Department of Employment, Education and Training? Unfortunately, for my Northern Territory Aboriginal constituents who have contributed in the past so significantly to the election of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, it will not be them. They have been conned and Mr Snowdon will have to wear the consequences at the next election.

Not only has the Department of Employment, Education and Training reduced the percentage of the national allocation to Northern Territory Aboriginal students, but also it has discarded the mechanism for identifying the depth of poverty of the poorest schools in Australia. A disadvantaged schools program with no mechanism to identify the extent of poverty in disadvantaged schools is quite absurd. It certainly demonstrates the arrogance of the Labor Government and the inequities which flow from its efforts to put its mates at the head of the queue. No consultation took place with the State and Territory governments during the development of this indicator or the abolition of the depth of poverty mechanism.

Northern Territory officers of the Department of Education who have questioned the changes have elicited answers that leave the Minister for Education in the Northern Territory, Mr Stone, along with myself, wondering whether the Department of Employment, Education and Training officers involved even knew that this important part of the structure existed.

Questions from all the various bodies supporting the proposals of Dr Ross are still unanswered by the Department, which has offered no rationale for the weightings it has imposed. One of the outcomes of the introduction of the Federal Labor Government's 1991 indicator is that it identifies several Aboriginal schools as the least disadvantaged schools in the Northern Territory.

Papunya Primary School is probably one of the best known of these schools nationally. In data from the 1986 census, Papunya has a population of 340 persons. Of these, 184 are within the work force age limits. Of the 184, 53 are employed and two are actively seeking employment. The census indicates that Papunya has a 3.6 per cent unemployment rate. However, there are 129 persons at Papunya categorised as `not in the labour force'. Therefore, as the two unemployed persons are added to the 129, there are 131 persons not identified in the heavily weighted occupation dimension of the 1991 indicator. Of 184 persons in the potential work force, 131, or 71 per cent of eligible persons in the community, are unemployed.

How a school with a permanent unemployment rate of 71 per cent can be identified as one of the least disadvantaged schools in the Northern Territory is of concern to me and should be of concern to the member for the Northern Territory. An indicator that fails to take into account known under-enumeration on this scale is useless in identifying relative poverty across Australia. Not only does that 1991 indicator have this obvious methodological flaw but, by weighting the occupation dimension by a factor of five, it also exacerbates the problem five times. These schools are penalised in a multiple fashion. One wonders how many other schools in Australia are discriminated against by this indicator.

Those responsible for the disadvantaged schools program are not walled up in the office in Canberra. They have visited Papunya and many schools like it. They know the problems and the inequity produced if one chooses to misinterpret the employment statistics in relation to seriously disadvantaged schools. So the Commonwealth bodies, the Department of Employment, Education and Training's own advisory groups, consultants, parent organisations and State-Territory representatives were not the only ones ignored. These Department of Employment, Education and Training officers have ignored the evidence before their own eyes. The only conclusion that can be reached is that a deliberate decision was made to proceed with an indicator that was known to neglect Aborigines and the long term unemployed.

There is a further issue that relates to many Aboriginal communities and causes them to be further discriminated against even if classified as employed, and I refer to the community development employment scheme. Under CDEP, Aborigines in certain communities must work on community tasks--they work for the dole, a benefit other Australians receive as a right. In return, Aborigines who receive this benefit through CDEP are classified as employed. At census time these Aborigines are classified as employed although they may never have had, or have any prospect of having, a real job in their lives. As a direct result of CDEP, their community's eligibility for the disadvantaged schools program suffers.

In the last couple of months the Commonwealth has argued that the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program was introduced last year to give additional funding to Aborigines for education, but even the Department of Employment, Education and Training has not suggested that they should be considered less disadvantaged as a result. Aborigines should qualify for disadvantaged schools program funding on the basis of poverty, not on the basis that they are Aborigines.

The Northern Territory Government has obviously tried for years to get the Schools Commission and now the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address these issues. It has proposed that all future resource indicators or formulae be developed by a subcommittee of the Australian Education Council so that all States and Territories can participate in their development.

In the past few weeks, officers from the Department of Employment, Education and Training have visited the Australian Bureau of Statistics in Darwin to discuss these issues. The Bureau of Statistics has confirmed that the Northern Territory Government view was based firmly on an accurate interpretation of data of the Bureau of Statistics. However, there still appears to be an unwillingness to allow these poorer and remotely located Aboriginal schools to be counted on the same basis as other schools in Australia.

It is time that we addressed this chronic problem of education in Australia. The Labor Government seems to have been caught up in rhetoric rather than results. The bureaucracy seems to be bogged down in detail rather than looking for proper outcomes by which they should be measured.

The coalition supports this legislation. However, it is necessary and timely to highlight the issues and major areas that must be addressed if we are to see good educational opportunities as fundamental for Aboriginal people, and as giving them the opportunity to be full participants in Australian society.

This was put very well by Charles Perkins in Alice Springs in August when talking about education, and his words make for potent and disturbing reading. Charles Perkins was the first Aboriginal Australian to graduate from university. That it was 1965 before any Aboriginal Australian did so is a shame. It is also timely that we look at his comments in the context of today, and I will quote what Charles Perkins said this year:

This has not received the focus it justifiably demands. It has been our greatest `blind spot' over the years in not realising the vital element of good education. We have usually left this to others or we have let our academic Aborigines tinker at the fringes with the Federal Government. . . The reality is, we are in the majority, unskilled and uneducated and as such, at the mercy of governments, bureaucrats, pathetic politics and the rise and fall of the economy.
Those comments are very timely for us to take note of as to where we are going and the type of underpinning we are giving education for Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill. It is important that there be an opportunity for this debate even though the legislation is purely administrative. It is nevertheless an important occasion, as each of the previous speakers indicated, on which to discuss policy issues and future directions with regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly welcome the bipartisan nature of this debate. Perhaps Senator Tambling and I would disagree on some aspects of the very historic overview he gave of difficulties he has had in relation to the recognition of particular skills in the Northern Territory. Where I would agree with him is that in future we must avoid an over-bureaucratisation of Aboriginal and Islander education. We must get back to far greater reliance on decentralised decision making and the recognition of Aboriginal and Islander communities--and their experts within their own communities who can educate their children--rather than act as well meaning, distant, white bureaucrats and politicians who think we know what is best for Aboriginal and Islander people.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Perhaps we should have more Aboriginal schools in Aboriginal communities, Senator.

—-Senator Tambling and I might find some agreement on that point, but we can debate that later. I come to this debate with particular experience in Aboriginal education. As long ago as 1967, I was very much aware of the problems of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education in north Queensland. As a teacher, I decided to do something about it. I was responsible for the establishment of the first preschool for Aboriginal and Islander children in that State. We called it `Kindergarten Headstart', modelled on the disadvantaged school concept in the United States at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: In retrospect, while this kindergarten was a good initiative, it was created very much from the point of view of a paternalistic or, in this case, maternalistic approach to helping Aboriginal and Islander people in education. While it was established and run by well-meaning white Australians, we did succeed in passing over the running of that kindergarten to the local community within about four years. From that point on, it certainly was a very important initiative.

A few years later there was an attempt to establish what was called the Black Community School, which is very much the forerunner of many of the independent schools that Senator Tambling has referred to. When it was suggested in some of the local papers, the reaction of the educational bureaucracy in the 1970s to the term `black community school'--and I do not know whether Senator Macdonald remembers some of the headlines--was, `What is so special about independent schools for Aboriginal communities when, after all, we have had our independent schools for almost the past 200 years?'. At that time it was regarded as quite a different issue and a threat and a challenge to the education system. I do not want to dwell so much on history; rather I want to talk about the importance of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy.

The Eurocentric view that we have of education for Aboriginal and Islander people in this country must be addressed in coming years. Clearly, there are Eurocentric skills, if you like, that we all must obtain. I particularly commend the comments that have been made in relation to Aboriginal preschools. We must ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children have access to aspects of that Eurocentric education system so they can acquire the skills that are needed in the modern society. But we must see that children come into the system at their own pace, within their own culture. This situation was appalling in the 1960s and into the 1970s. Of course, in some parts of Australia it is still going on. In their first few weeks at school when Aboriginal and Islander children are learning to read, they confront middle-class, white characteristics and values that mean absolutely nothing to them. They cannot relate to those issues, and that would be the case if many of our children were to go to school in a totally different society: they would find it difficult to learn in a totally different value system. That is an issue which is fundamental to the beginnings of education.

Senator Tambling touched on the issue of cooperation of the States and the fact that we have a national approach to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education. That national approach is tremendous, but we must ensure that the States do not--`breach' is perhaps too strong a word--forgo some of their obligations. I cannot let this debate pass without a comment in relation to statements made by Premier Goss at Aurukun some months ago. It was suggested that, because children were not attending school and because parents were not valuing education in the way that is anticipated and expected in the Eurocentric culture, teachers should be withdrawn and parents and children should be virtually punished for not valuing education.

I understand totally the Premier's frustration and the frustration of teachers, educational bureaucrats, ATSIC, and Ministers where, on some Aboriginal communities, children are truanting; they are not in a position to take advantage of the education that is being offered. But I do not believe that withdrawing from the situation is the answer. I think the answer lies very much in the kind of teachers we appoint and how long we leave them in the one area. I know, as someone who used to be involved in teacher training, that a number of my former students wanted to remain in Aboriginal communities and were transferred. Certainly, that is going back a couple of years.

We need to encourage those teachers who want to work in Aboriginal communities with Aboriginal people to develop their own skills and structures in conformity with a broad curriculum base but recognising the Aboriginal culture. These are the teachers who should be encouraged to remain rather than have them transferred when they have only just come into the community and gained some acceptance and credibility.

Aboriginal parents, Aboriginal teacher aids and Aborigines themselves training to work in education is an area that must be extended. Many Aboriginal parents are still reluctant to work within white middle-class schools. They are suspicious because of their own experience at school, because they feel that some of the teachers do not understand and because they have particular expectations of their children. We must break down those barriers between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander parents and teachers. Many teachers are only too eager to do this. I do not mean this to be a criticism of teachers, but I do think this is an area where much more work has to go into community education and community relations.

It is difficult to talk about Aboriginal education without reference to the over-bureaucratisation of our education. These days, everything has to be measured, quantified and calculated in terms of how much it will cost--financially, of course. I think educationalists within the departments responsible--DEET and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs--have to start thinking about what the alternative is and what the social costs are. There is a financial cost, there is a bottom line, and Treasury and Finance will always remind us of those actual costs. But what is the alternative if Aboriginal and Islander people do not gain just recognition for their skills and talents in this society and if they do not gain the educational skills that they will need to meet the future? The social cost and the ultimate financial cost will be far greater in the long run.

I was interested in what Senator Michael Baume had to say about homework centres. I am sure that Senator Colston and I and, no doubt, others in this chamber have worked in homework centres over the years. Senator Baume asked, `Why are the schools not used? We already have a community resource'. As someone who has always campaigned for schools to be opened up and used for a whole range of community functions, I can sympathise with that view. However, often we are dealing with children who are opposing the education structure in which they are obliged to work. I do not think that schools necessarily provide--some schools do--the supportive environment that is needed for the homework support scheme.

I certainly believe that wherever possible we should move towards utilising schools for homework centres, but not at the risk of the homework scheme. We do not want a situation such as has occurred in Aurukun where children are not going to school and are not going to the homework centre because the homework centre is based in the school. After all, the majority of children will do their homework in a home-like atmosphere. If that is difficult in some Aboriginal families, we should be far-sighted enough to ensure a comparable environment is provided for Aboriginal children at this time.

In regard to some of the issues that have been raised about higher education, I would not want to let this opportunity pass. It is true, as Senator Kernot said, that some tertiary institutions are not particularly interested in Aboriginal education. They do not necessarily go out of their way to take advantage of many of the outstanding Government initiatives that have been taken to encourage tertiary institutions to provide special programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I even know of one institution--perhaps there are more--which took the resources that were provided by the Federal Government for Aboriginal and Islander special programs and absorbed that money into other areas of the university. I will not embarrass that particular institution by naming it in this place because the issue has been corrected and that institution is now taking many more positive measures. I think it does illustrate that the Federal Government, through the departments of both Minister Tickner and Minister Dawkins, has to be eternally vigilant in ensuring that the resources that are allocated for specific Aboriginal programs in universities are, in fact, expended in the way in which they are intended.

There is just one such example that has been launched recently at James Cook University. Members of the Aboriginal and Islander community can now obtain special entry into nursing studies at James Cook. The head of the department has announced that the course started in July this year. It is long overdue. We have had special courses for teachers in several tertiary institutions for over 10 years, but there have been very few initiatives in regard to nursing which is a vital area for Aboriginal and Islander people to train in their own health care.

I might just indicate that, although the applicants preferably should have a high school education--grade 11 or grade 12--interviews are also being held to facilitate special entry. We do need to ensure that there is that degree of flexibility in the entry requirements. Ultimately, the test will be whether the individual can work within the course that is provided. I do not think we should put arbitrary entry limits in the face of applicants who may well be able to succeed once they get past that initial barrier.

In debating this piece of legislation, the important fact that has to be raised is that, essentially, we have a bipartisan approach to Aboriginal and Islander issues in the Federal Parliament now and that is a very strong basis on which to build national reconciliation. National reconciliation will occur only if we have education on both sides.

Today we have been talking about education in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. That is very important. But we also have to talk about what amount of education occurs in the broad community, about what understanding has yet to be achieved in the general Australian community about the reality of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's history--it is a black history, as we know--about what has occurred and about what limits there are to Aboriginal and Islander people. We have to educate the white community to those problems.

One such initiative has been taken in Queensland which should provide a model for all States. Queensland is in the process of finalising the establishment of what is called a mobile cross-cultural awareness training unit which has been funded jointly by the Federal Government, through the Office of Multicultural Affairs, under the Commonwealth-State-Territory initiative of the Federal Government's community relations strategy, and the State Government of Queensland.

The rationale for this cross-cultural awareness training unit is that it should foster and support positive community relations and interactions between groups and individuals to group all Australians together in a multicultural society. Its goal is to enhance community relations. Those community relations depend very heavily on education. The unit will consist of a four-wheel drive vehicle and a specially constructed multipurpose van. It will be resourced with multimedia resources to assist its two project officers in travelling around the communities, particularly the outback communities, in trying to build bridges between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. We are very aware of the degree of racism that is present in our community, and that is something that must be broken down through education.

Finally, today we have heard about the importance of education that was stated in a number of the recommendations of the reports into Aboriginal deaths in custody. It is essential that our correctional centres, our prisons--whatever they happen to be called in the different States these days--must undergo major transformations in regard to education, not just the education of the prisoners themselves, but the education of the people who work with them. Without that two-way process of education, I fear that we will continue to have the tragedy of Aboriginal deaths in custody.

It is an ideal opportunity, we could say, when Aboriginal people are in prison for a short time, we hope, to give them certain education that has not been obtained in the wider community. It is important that that opportunity is taken so that those people go back into the community with skills, with the opportunity, to participate along with all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have chosen to speak very briefly on this Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1991 just to relate some broad impressions that I obtained recently in a four-day or five-day trip which I undertook in Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands in the company of Dr Michael Wooldridge, the Liberal Party spokesman on Aboriginal affairs. My comments will, for that reason, be reasonably broad. Before doing that, I just want to muse on a couple of matters mentioned by Senator Reynolds.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that I consider Senator Reynolds to have a genuine interest in the field of Aboriginal affairs. It is one in which she has a lot of experience, a genuine compassion and a wish to help Aboriginal people. But I also wonder, in my relative inexperience in this chamber, about some of the bureaucratic programs, systems and schemes that evolve and are put into place particularly in relation to Aboriginal communities. I note that Senator Reynolds was lamenting or concerned about the over-bureaucratic control of education in Aboriginal affairs. I agree with her. But after eight or nine years in Government, I wonder what this Government has done about it. I would have hoped that people like Senator Reynolds, who have an understanding of this, may have been able to change the system.

Coming from where I do--a non-expert category when it comes to Aboriginal education--it does seem to me in a broad way that the programs that are devised in Canberra by Canberra bureaucrats and public servants keep going. The money that is spent on these programs--Senator Reynolds and other senators have mentioned a few--just seems to add on to the cost of administering education and benefits for Aboriginal communities. I often wonder whether the money that is spent on these new programs and bureaucracy would be better spent on the things that really would assist Aboriginal groups.

I believe that we should not be looking towards particularly separate development for different racial groups. These theories went out of favour decades ago right around the world. We should be attempting to get programs that build a oneness of Australia whilst recognising that various groups, particularly Aboriginal and Islander people, come from different backgrounds and different histories and have particular problems. We should be aiming for a oneness of Australia rather than as I see things going in certain areas.

This particular Bill transfers the higher education funding component of the Aboriginal education strategic initiative programs to the Higher Education Funding Act, which means that the higher education institutions will provide supplementary assistance to Aboriginal students out of the global budget. As I understand it, these are simply some administrative arrangements to get the funds more defined and more clearly flowing from one to the other. The fact that this Bill is necessary gives some credence to my point. There seem to be so many different programs, different Acts and different initiatives all costing enormous sums of money which I think would be better spent more directly on the real problems of Aboriginal and Islander people.

This legislation arises following the commencement in January 1990 of the national Aboriginal and Islander education program. That program embraced a number of programs, including the Aboriginal and Islander education strategic initiatives program, the Aboriginal student support and parent awareness program, the Aboriginal and Islander tutorial assistance scheme and the vocational and educational guidance for Aboriginals and Islanders scheme. Generally speaking, the coalition supports the legislation which underpins the national Aboriginal and Islander education policy. The Bill has no particular contentious provisions in itself that require debate here.

Prior to the introduction of the Aboriginal education policy, something which has enjoyed bipartisan support in this Parliament, strong evidence suggested that 10 to 15 per cent of Aboriginals of student age were not participating in primary and secondary schooling despite the national expectation that all school-age children would receive such schooling. Also, participation rates for Aboriginal people in post compulsory schooling are only about one-third of the number for all other Australians.

These and other concerns led to the development of the Aboriginal education policy which followed the Hughes report of 1988. The report found that, despite improvements over the past couple of decades, Aboriginal and Islander people remain the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. Based on these findings, the Aboriginal education policy was developed.

During my recent visit to Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands, we spoke with Aboriginal community groups about a number of the problems that they were experiencing with education. Some of the previous speakers mentioned in passing the problems at Aurukun, where the absentee rate is very high. There have been figures suggesting that five out of six students are not attending those schools. The solutions to this problem of education have to be found from within the communities themselves.

I believe that the long term future of Aboriginal and Islander people depends upon their young people having a good education that will equip them to live in the world which, whether they want to or not, they are going to have to live in. Regrettably, we cannot hold time back. Aboriginal and Islander people are Australians. They are part of the world as it rapidly changes every week. They must be equipped to be able to deal with that. Of course, that happens through education.

During my visit to Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait islands, we saw a varying range of educational establishments and the way they are run. Some do have problems and Aurukun has been mentioned. I might mention the situation on Darnley Island, which is one of the easternmost of the Torres Strait islands. One would not find a more beautiful island anywhere. I was very impressed with the school on that island. The school was in recess at the time we visited it, but it was still very obvious from the school that pride was taken in it.

We were told by the teacher in charge that there was not a problem with absenteeism on Darnley Island; in fact, the children were so anxious to get to school that they were turning up very early in the morning. The teacher actually had to circularise parents to make them aware that the students would not be supervised before 7.30 a.m. That seemed to be a tremendous lesson to learn. Obviously, something is being done right in that school which encourages the students to go there and which makes them want to be there.

The school itself and the classrooms showed that the students really have a positive approach and a very broad education. I might say that I learnt something myself during a self-guided tour of a little compound out the back where the students were obviously learning about hydroponics. It is a subject which I know very little about. We walked through their compound and saw the different results. They were actually growing tomatoes by hydroponics. A little story was told about each little plot and there seemed to be a competition going on between the various students. This all seemed very positive.

Hydroponics is something that may well assist these islands where, at times, the soil that is naturally on the islands might not be the right soil to grow crops and food. Hydroponics may well be an appropriate study for the future of those islands. This was of interest to me, and I am sure the students enjoyed doing that. The school itself is in a beautiful setting overlooking the very deep blue waters of the Torres Strait and the reefs that surround the island. It was all a tremendous feeling because something is obviously being done right. After visiting that school, one would have great enthusiasm and great confidence for the future of education in the Torres Strait islands.

Various community leaders spoke to us about the problem that, after year 7, there are no continuing educational facilities on these islands or in communities on Cape York Peninsula. The students have to leave their home base and the family they have grown up with, and move some distance away to Thursday Island, Cairns or bigger places such as that. In some cases they must go quite long distances to continue their education. That is a problem.

Coupled with that problem is the fact that the students who go away to continue their education tend to be the brighter ones. Once they go away they never come back to their community. They make lives and careers in other parts of Australia. At times the better students are lost to those communities forever. That is not a problem peculiar to Aboriginal and Islander communities; it is peculiar to remote Australia. In the community that I live in, and in other communities throughout remote Australia, that is a problem--the better students tend to go away and never return. The expertise or the better learning never returns to remote Australia. That is something we should look at. Of course, the way to get them to return is to have employment opportunities for them. That would give them a reason to return.

We should not be looking at only Aboriginal and Islander education but remote Australia education, and I prefer to think of it as remote Australia education. We should be looking at providing incentives to kids to study more so that they can get decent jobs within their own community. It is very difficult to ask remote Australian children to spend a lot of time at and have a real enthusiasm to go to school and expand their knowledge when they know that at the end of their schooling they will leave and have nothing to go to.

What interest is there for them to continue with their education studies if they know that at the end of the day they will go onto the dole or that the Government or some agency will support them and give them everything they need? They may not be terribly exciting lives for them, but they will be fed and clothed. They think, `Why bother? What is the incentive? What is the interest in continuing with education? What attraction is there to perform, to achieve excellence, to be the best and to get ahead if it is all for no cause?'. I say this quite obviously not as an educator nor as one with any formal training or particular expertise in the educational field.

We have to look at the real bottom line: what education is all about and what future there is for kids in remote Australia. We should really be looking at employment opportunities, the things that will give people something to do in remote Australia. The Government needs to look at that a bit more. It becomes an economic problem, a resource development problem. They are the sorts of things that I think this Government has failed dismally on. It is no good spending millions of dollars on education if the bottom line is not there at the end. In a very broad way we have to look at the incentives for kids to go to school and to stay in their communities once they have graduated.

The coalition certainly supports this Bill. I ask that some thought be given to the schools and the educational opportunities that are really working and have proved themselves. These schools and establishments might be used as examples or goals for other schools and educational establishments to aim towards and put some rationality and commonsense into some of the programs that we introduce for education in remote Australian areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill is an extremely simple administrative Bill which has neither a Budget impact nor a policy impact. Contributors to this debate have quite reasonably used it as a platform to discuss the important area of Aboriginal education. There is no need for me to detain the Senate, because there has been welcome and consistent support both in the House of Representatives and, indeed, in the Senate for this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that the program for which these pieces of legislation act as legislative support--that is, the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, commonly referred to as the AEP--is a truly national policy and is one of the very few where there is total support from both State and Territory governments and the Federal Government for the 21 goals which underpin this important program.

I make reference to a point raised by Senator Reynolds and, no doubt, by other speakers; that is, that education in this area is very much a two-way street in that we act as the potential beneficiaries--the non-Aboriginal people of Australia--in learning more about that culture. I was pleased to hear Senator Macdonald's contribution about the visit that he recently made to a number of Aboriginal communities. I am certainly aware that Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal society have often been denigrated in the past by non-Aboriginal people in Australia--not so much these days, I am pleased to say. The Aboriginal culture has a richness and a diversity and it is of enormous value to this country and to Australians generally, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal.

The relationships that Aboriginal people have with each other--their family relationships, the strength of those relationships and the relationships between the family and the land upon which they live, certainly in traditional Aboriginal society--are expressed to an extent which has largely been lost and are to a great degree unknown in the wider Australian community.

I mention this because a number of years ago--in fact, so many years ago that it is almost ancient history--the national curriculum unit, a unit of the Commonwealth Department of Education, prepared a superlative kit, based on a number of Aboriginal families on Elcho Island in the Northern Territory, now known as Galiwinku, which consisted of educational material, videos and language cassettes. The kit simply gave a brief appreciation of the richness and diversity of Aboriginal culture. The kit was specifically designed to be put into schools all over Australia so that non-Aboriginal students could appreciate the great value and diversity of Aboriginal culture. I do not know whether that material has been added to. I have not seen any consolidated material of the quality of that which was produced. Perhaps it is still the main tool in schools for this appreciation.

The goal of providing non-Aboriginal Australians with an understanding under this program, for which these Bills act as a legislative support, is acknowledged and recognised in the 21 goals that are provided for under the AEP. Goal 21 states that the scheme is to provide all Australian students with an understanding of and respect for Aboriginal traditional and contemporary cultures.

It is an extremely difficult task for an Aboriginal person to cope successfully with both cultures. It is trite to say it in the sense that it has been said so many times before, but it is worth saying again: it is a very challenging thing for Aboriginal persons to compete successfully with non-Aboriginal people--as I believe they must do--and, at the same time, retain their Aboriginality. It is a very daunting task. If I recounted the number of Aboriginal people who, in my opinion, have successfully done that it would be a very short list indeed. It is not an easy thing to do. Having said that, I believe that, as other speakers have said and as has been borne out by numerous inquiries, the latest of which was the Aboriginal deaths in custody inquiry, there is no more vitally important element for public policy than education in terms of public support and resources to assist the Aboriginal people of Australia. That is my opinion, without question.

In conclusion, may I say on behalf of the Government that I am grateful for the expressions of support from the Opposition for this legislation in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I commend to the Senate the speedy passage of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION BILL 1991EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In speaking to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, which are designed to split the Export Finance Insurance Corporation from Austrade, I wish to make it clear that the Opposition will not be opposing them. The Bills aim to establish EFIC as a separate corporation from Austrade and to supplement its existing reserves by an additional $200m in callable capital. In so doing, existing provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act relating to export finance and insurance are repealed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well to remember at this stage that the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation has been around in one form or another for over 30 years. It has probably been buried away and not subject to much scrutiny or attention--until in 1986 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, decided to amalgamate it with Austrade and to make the combined operation something that was to be at the forefront of building Australian exports. The McKinsey report showed this whole endeavour to be a complete and abject failure.

To say that the Minister's oversight of Austrade has been slack is perhaps not to put it too highly. It is interesting to note that the last annual report we received was for 1989-90. Though there is provision for the Minister to make directives from time to time, he certainly has not done so. We still do not have the annual report for this financial year. I have managed to ascertain that it exists in draft form. It is important to note that many agencies and departments make draft annual reports available, as is proper, to Estimates committees for the purpose of Estimates hearings. Austrade chose not to do so. I understand that it will not make even the draft available until it has been seen by the board which is meeting at the end of this month after the return from overseas of the new managing director.

It is also worth noting that a curious part of this whole exercise to split Austrade, which the McKinsey report, as I said, showed to be an abject failure, from EFIC--which, interestingly enough, was exempt from the McKinsey inquiry, despite the fact that it had a common board--was carried out in a way where the new personnel have been appointed pursuant, or allegedly pursuant, to the McKinsey report while the two organisations remained joined and in the care and control of DITAC, whereas that part of the old joint operation, namely Austrade, is to go to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. But, curiously, EFIC is to remain with DITAC.

My colleague Mr Downer in the other place correctly said that in his view EFIC should also be transferred to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, as that is where many aid programs with which EFIC needs to interact in fact lie. The decision to let EFIC remain within DITAC seems to me to be a very strange and, indeed, wrong decision because the history of its administration is not good. I will look at some of those aspects a little later.

The Bills themselves implement a decision taken by the Government in the March industry statement. The new EFIC is to be endowed with responsibility for officially supported export finance and insurance matters previously undertaken by Austrade under the same name. Although there may be no immediate direct financial impact from this Bill, there is provision to make a call upon the Consolidated Revenue Fund of up to $200m if it is determined that EFIC's assets are insufficient to meet anticipated liabilities, losses and claims. Under circumstances where the Corporation determines that its money and other assets are excessive for the purposes of meeting anticipated liabilities, losses and claims, the Corporation is to return excess capital to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill provides transitional arrangements necessary to preserve continuity as export finance and insurance matters are transferred from Austrade to the newly constituted EFIC and its new structure. Assets, liabilities and staff associated with the relevant functions are also transferred from Austrade to EFIC by this Bill.

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation in one form or another has been around for some 30 to 35 years. It aims to insure exports against risk of non-payment by overseas buyers and provides a range of guarantee and bonding services, and of course loans. At present, it covers about 10 per cent of Australia's export trade. Offshore investments can also be insured against non-commercial loss due to exchange transfer blockages, expropriation or war damage and can cover an investment that may be in the vicinity of $490m.

It is important to point out that there are two types of business that EFIC carries out: one is on the national interest account and the other on what is called the commercial account. Before I explain the distinction between those two methods of accounting, it is reasonable to point out that perhaps the distinction can indeed be described as a fiction, as indeed the high risk nature of the business that EFIC carries out is delineated by the fact that the private sector is unwilling to operate in these areas. Indeed, as Mr Downer pointed out in the other place--a thought with which I certainly concur--if it were possible to privatise EFIC, that would be a positive thing, but the degree of interest in the private sector in high risk business certainly appears to be limited.

It is interesting to note that clause 62 of the main Bill we are now debating provides that the Commonwealth will guarantee all payments that may be due to be paid by EFIC to a third party, and clause 63 provides that it is exempt from taxation. To describe it as a truly commercial operation, a government business enterprise, as the Government is so fond of describing these corporatised functions, which is then pushed off budget, is not to give a good definition.

Let us look in a brief way at the two types of business that EFIC does and will carry out: firstly, at the insurance where EFIC will carry the loss--that is what it calls its commercial account, be it insurance or loans--and, secondly, at the national interest account where, very simply, the Consolidated Revenue Fund or the taxpayer carries that risk. In those situations, the practice would seem to be that EFIC decides that it will decline to carry the whole risk or part thereof and makes a recommendation to the Minister that the remainder or all of the risk be carried on the national interest. It sets a premium which seems to be, by practice, a commercial or quasi-commercial premium plus 25 per cent. The best example of that sort of insurance on the national interest is the wheat sales to Iraq.

As well as that, there is the function of guaranteeing performance bonds, which are largely relevant to loans made by EFIC. EFIC's concessional finance is available and is based on rules consistent with the OECD rules. There is a lending program of about $1.6 billion currently in existence and funds are obtained on foreign capital markets and on-lent at subsidised interest rates. Indeed, in the performance notes that accompany the current Budget, some $14.7m has been provided for interest subsidies. Of course, this is taxpayers' money.

I suppose that it is relevant at this stage to mention that during the Supplementary Estimates earlier this year, when Senator Button and I were having a discourse about an alleged commercial loan of some $8m to one Mr Cantor at 8 per cent over eight years, Senator Button told me vehemently that we were not talking about taxpayers' money. I insisted that we were, and Senator Button wrote to me on 3 September and admitted that he stood corrected, that the interest subsidy was certainly taxpayers' money.

As I said, it is with concern that we see EFIC established as a statutory corporation--a GBE. That is because we are concerned that scrutiny may be lessened. Despite the fact that public money is involved in the funding of EFIC, the Bill casts doubts on ways in which the Parliament and particularly the Senate Estimates committees might be able to scrutinise those expenditures. There is some discourse at the moment as to the basis on which agencies that are being corporatised are subject to that scrutiny.
