I would like to outline one case with which I have been dealing particularly at the moment, because it highlights the need for scrutiny by the Parliament, and that is the case which has become known as The Other Woman, involving the boat on which a loan was made to Mr Edward A. Cantor for $8m over eight years at a subsidised interest rate of 8 per cent.

It is part of Government policy to support the shipbuilding industry so far as it relates to large ships--not small ships. Therefore, a number of loans have been made and a large amount of bounty has been paid. In this case, my initial concern when I raised the matter in the Supplementary Estimates in the first half of this year was how much care EFIC had exercised in choosing the person to whom it chose to lend money.

It had been drawn to my attention that a New Jersey newspaper had reported in 1988 that Mr Cantor, to whom the loan was being made, had been charged with racketeering and conspiracy, and bail had been set at $25,000. The report went on to say that Mr Cantor had been detained in New York in July 1988 and charged with defrauding a federal bankruptcy trustee of more than $1 million just months after negotiations began for the construction of The Other Woman. In fact, the contract was signed in December 1987. The contract was with Runmere Pty Ltd and was signed on 28 December 1987. The contract price was $US7.65m. If that is converted--if my memory serves me correctly, the Australian dollar was being valued at between 76c and 80c in the dollar at that stage--that is about $A9m.

On 4 February, Runmere wrote to a credit manager of a particular supplier and asked for credit to be established. He stated that the value of the shipbuilding contract was $13m. One can only assume that that is the contract price plus the anticipated bounty payments. The boat is now alleged to be worth between $25m and $30m and Runmere has gone into liquidation. There are outstanding creditors, according to the last statement I saw, who are owed in the vicinity of $4.4m. The liquidator has a claim against Mr Cantor for some $5m to $6m of estimated alterations to the boat which were never paid for. This would go a long way towards paying some of those outstanding creditors.

As I said, my concern initially was that we should ensure that EFIC never again did business with a person having such a background as Mr Cantor. Subsequent to my raising the matter, I then received a very curious letter, dated 25 September, which was faxed to me from a firm of solicitors in Brisbane. I quote from their letter:
Mr Edward Cantor's sin in your eyes apparently is that he was convicted in New Jersey of some financial irregularity. . .

As I understand it, this is in addition to the other charges because my belief is that those other charges were dropped. I do not know under what circumstances; I am simply told that they were dropped.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You don't want to know either, do you?

—-I would be particularly interested to know. This firm of solicitors said that it was writing on behalf of the management and employees of Australian Yacht Builders, which is the company owned by Mr Cantor and which completed the building of the boat after Runmere went into liquidation and, indeed, received the second and third bounty payments of $1.9m and $0.3m respectively.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Cantor bought the shipyard for less than the mortgage value of the property when it was put to auction--namely, $1.35m--and the directors of Runmere were forced to pay the difference out of the sale of their own homes. As I said, this letter was written apparently at the behest of the management and employees of Australian Yacht Builders. The letter goes on to say of Mr Cantor:
He says in his defence--
that is, when he was actually convicted--
quite simply that he was convicted of making a loan to an insolvent business associate which was in the circumstances interpreted as a bribe.

Here we are making a loan of $8m over eight years at 8 per cent to Mr Cantor, about whom I have received a letter from a firm of solicitors, dated 25 September, telling me that Mr Cantor has in fact been convicted of a bribe.

I still find that I want reassurance from EFIC that we will not be doing business with somebody such as Mr Cantor and that the work that is done in investigation and scrutiny will improve. I have never got that undertaking. The reason why the case became even more important was that, although the contract for building the boat was signed in 1987 and the arrest took place--according to the letter I received from Senator Button--on 26 July 1988, the actual credit agreement under which the $8m was paid was not signed until 13 October 1988.

In the interim, EFIC went and got a legal opinion after it became aware of the arrest, to see whether or not it would proceed with the loan. It sought that legal opinion from a New York firm of solicitors. Pursuant to that opinion, it proceeded with the loan. I have repeatedly asked that the Senate be allowed to have a copy of that advice so that we may see the efficacy of the negotiations and, indeed, the checking of potential clients that EFIC engaged upon. The Minister has consistently refused to make that legal opinion available, and he claims commercial in confidence.

Let us look through the question of this particular loan. Because in the contract there was provision for a performance bond--and, of course, Austrade was the guarantor of that bond--there was, in fact, a payment made to Mr Cantor of $2.23m. That statement was given in evidence by Dr Fisher, who is the general manager of EFIC, in these current Estimates hearings. Although we have made a loan to Mr Cantor of $8m, which has to be repaid, we have also given him, virtually in cash, $2.23m and we have also given him bounty payments of $2.2m.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not right.

—-I ask the Minister whether or not that final payment of $0.3m, which he told me in his letter was due to be paid upon completion of the boat, was in fact paid. The bounty payment of $1.9m certainly was.

SPEECH.PARA: The total amount of government and taxpayers' money that went into this boat was $17.1m. Indeed, Mr Cantor has admitted that himself. But the interesting point is that we are meant to be doing these things, I am told, in the interests of exports for Australians and producing business for Australians. I think it is well to note that the company that had the contract is, of course, now in liquidation. There are outstanding creditors and there is an outstanding claim against Mr Cantor which the liquidators have no money to pursue. We now have a boat which is valued at somewhere between $28m and $30m. I am informed that Mr Cantor was going around New York saying, `I have this wonderful boat courtesy of the Australian taxpayers. It is a very good deal'.

My concern, as I said right at the outset, is that by looking at the way in which this particular case has proceeded we need to be sure that this newly created body, EFIC, pursuant to this legislation will be subject to the scrutiny of the Parliament. This case of The Other Woman, this particular boat, is not alone. I am told that there is something in the vicinity of $110m worth of loans which are perhaps at risk. Of course, I am also aware of the fiasco with Mr Eliadakis who also received a loan initially of $4.3m to build a boat in which he took off to the Greek Islands. Then he received another advance against a further loan, which was approved, of $10 1/2m, and he received $1.2m for a boat that was never built. Those are still matters which need to be investigated as well.

We do not know the extent of these loans or whether they have in fact been placed. But I am aware that there are at least two other boats which EFIC has taken possession of and is attempting to sell. I do not know the extent of the loss which will be incurred in that transaction.

As I said, the Minister likes to make a distinction about a government business enterprise somehow being a totally commercial exercise. Of course, the Minister was not in the chamber when I dealt with that original distinction. But, whichever way it goes, on page 264 of the program performance statements for the current Budget Papers one will find that the total outlays concerning EFIC by way of appropriation are $258m. Some $264m, less $20m, is in respect of national interest business and a further almost $15m is for interest subsidies. By any account, EFIC must remain a truly accountable body to the Parliament, both through the Estimates committees and in other ways.

Another point was raised by my colleague Mr Downer in the other place. It is one which I think is an important point and worth pursuing; that is, it would be interesting to establish a joint EFIC banking industry working group to examine whether the commercial banks can play a bigger role in providing some of the services that EFIC is currently providing or assist with the provision of those services.

As I said right at the outset, the likelihood of being able to privatise EFIC seems somewhat remote as so much of the business that it does is unattractive to the private sector as much of it is high risk business. The overseas experience is that overseas countries maintain an equivalent to EFIC as an instrument of providing assistance to industry, particularly in the export area. The opportunity to privatise seems remote, but the suggestion as made by Mr Downer in the other place is certainly one that ought to be pursued.

The Opposition will not be opposing the Bills. We have some concerns about the manner in which GBEs operate. We are most concerned that these organisations remain subject to the proper scrutiny of the Parliament and that, somewhere along the line, we are given some reassurance about the processes which EFIC goes through to choose those people to whom largess is extended, certainly with a component of taxpayers' funds as well as government funds. That is a point which I think needs to be addressed. I trust the Minister will do just that when he speaks on this mater.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Today the Senate is considering the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill 1991 and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: These two Bills seek to enact an announcement made by the Government in the March 1991 industry statement. In that statement the Government announced that EFIC, to use the short name, would cease to be a division of Austrade and would be re-established as an independent statutory corporation. This reverses the 1985 decision incorporating EFIC into Austrade.

EFIC provides finance and insurance services to Australian exporters. The assistance can take many forms--for instance, subsidised interest rates, guarantees to financial institutions in respect of finance granted to exporters and insurance against non-payment by overseas buyers of Australian exports or national interest insurance. However, GATT and other international agreements limit the amount of assistance which can be granted.

It will be useful to review briefly the history of assistance provided to Australian exporters by way of these arrangements. In 1956 the Export Payments Insurance Corporation was established to provide insurance for exporters against the risk of non-payment by overseas buyers. Since then, the range of EPIC's facilities has been extended, reflecting developments in financial and insurance markets and the changing pattern of Australian industry and international competition.

From 1971 buyers' credit was made available as an alternative means of financing exports of capital goods. In 1975 the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation was established, replacing the existing EPIC, with increased powers. These included strengthening commercial relations with overseas countries; developing facilities for Australian exporters; facilitating the provision of long term credit sales of machinery and capital goods; and establishing lines of credit to developing countries and State trading corporations.

In 1978 EFIC was allowed to provide indemnities to private financial corporations which issued tender, performance and related guarantees. In November 1983 EFIC was allowed to provide foreign currency financing and give Australian exporters access to lower interest rate currencies for medium and long term credit which met the terms being provided by competitors. The legislation also removed the restrictions which had limited EFIC's services to those not normally provided by the private sector. In other words, EFIC was able to compete with private insurers, and I will return to that point later.

In 1984 a pre-shipment finance guarantee facility was introduced to assist Australian manufacturers to obtain finance for the production of goods for export. In 1986 EFIC was subsumed into the newly created unified export service provider, Austrade. The current separation of EFIC from Austrade is part of the general reorganisation of Austrade following the McKinsey report which was provided to the Government in December 1990. That report recommended that Austrade should adopt a market driven approach and concentrate on providing better access to overseas customers utilising government clout and in-depth market know-how. This was based on the recognition that Austrade has to deal with both economic and cultural diversity and a very broad and complex range of products. In particular, the report recommended that Austrade gear up its capacity to access and influence foreign governments which are often key buyers or key influences in most countries and assist countries in overcoming, cost effectively, language and cultural barriers in unfamiliar markets.

In focusing on these objectives, the McKinsey report recommended that a more critical approach be taken to the selection of markets where Austrade could provide these services most usefully. Thus there should be greater concentration on key markets such as Japan, the Republic of Korea, Taiwan and the emerging economies in Eastern Europe where, at that stage, Austrade's coverage was particularly thin.

It is pleasing to note that in today's Australian Financial Review there is an article which quotes the Managing Director of Austrade, Mr Ralph Evans, as saying that Australia will provide a take-off point for American companies in unlocking markets in Asia and, interestingly enough, Eastern Europe, and that in fact the initiative taken by Coca-Cola to buy out a local franchise holder to use it as a vehicle for these activities did include Eastern Europe. It would appear that the tyranny of distance does not apply in modern trade as stringently as it used to.

I believe the continuing need for Austrade is well documented in the McKinsey report, and it is also illustrated by the fragmented nature of Australian exports and the high proportion of companies where the volume of exports in any given overseas market is well below the critical mass which would justify opening a representative company office. To illustrate that, the report suggests that exports in excess of $10m per year are necessary. However, only 242 exporters have aggregate exports in excess of $10m each and the number that export more than $10m to individual countries is much smaller than that. Hence some form of collective trade representation is essential at this stage of Australia's transition into overseas export markets.

Welcome though the McKinsey report and the subsequent shake-up and reorganisation of Austrade are, the question needs to be asked whether these support services are all we can expect from this Government. The Australian Democrats believe it is the task of our Government not to achieve a level playing field or to keep it level for our manufacturers and exporters but to tilt it in favour of our manufacturers and exporters. In this regard, it is disappointing that neither the reorganisation of Austrade nor the separation of EFIC from Austrade offers any decisive moves in that direction.

I will name just two measures which the Government should consider. One would be an export bounty of 5 per cent payable on the value of new exports in any one year. In 1989-90 this would have cost $140m for increased exports of $2.8 billion. It would be a small price to pay if this measure had doubled the value of our new exports at the cost of another $140m. The second measure used by many other countries to gear up their export industries has been tax concessions for profits derived from exports. Such a measure would clearly have to be phased out over time. However, there is a lot to be said for decisive action to assist our manufacturing industry when the country has one million unemployed--a circumstance that does not seem to bother this Government overmuch.

I return to the EFIC Bills. To the extent that they increase the range and efficiency of the services provided to exporters, the measures are of course welcome and the Bills are supported by the Australian Democrats. However, they seem to do little more than change labels on doors. If one were cynical, one could even suggest that the measure is an outcome of the bureaucratic wrangle between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which finally succeeded, and I think rightly so, in acquiring Austrade while EFIC has remained with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.
In conclusion, I ask the Minister to expand on one statement contained in the second reading speech, to the effect that:
EFIC will continue to work with the financial sector and not in competition with it, to provide Australian exporters with access to competitive credit insurance and export finance facilities.

The Minister may wish to explain what this means in practice. Does he mean that EFIC will not attempt to provide credit insurance which is more competitive than that provided by the private sector, or is he simply going to take the costs up to the level which represents the commercial cost of such services provided by the available commercial facilities? The Minister has said that these services will be provided not in competition with the private sector. I confirm that the Australian Democrats will not oppose these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Bill 1991 and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1991, even though I must say that I have heard a lot of it before. I suppose there is a political virtue in repetition, even if there is no intellectual one.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure of the implications of Senator Spindler's last question. The fact of the matter is that EFIC is very largely a supplier of finance to exporters where the private sector will not be involved. That is true of credit agencies throughout the world which are sponsored and supported by governments. So EFIC is in no different position from other agencies and, indeed, its activities are complementary to what may or may not happen in the private sector.

I take on board some of Senator Spindler's other observations. I must say that I do not embrace Australian Democrat Party policies about tipping the playing field in our favour. I must say that in the debate which takes place about these issues I am very much in favour of having a level playing field. I am not sure that we have that in the international community at present, not because of competitiveness or otherwise but because of practices which are adopted by a variety of countries and which really affect and distort trade movements throughout the world. We can begin by asking our farmers about that because they understand it.

This legislation is essentially concerned with the establishment of EFIC as a separate statutory corporation, the question of capital adequacy and the Government providing EFIC with access to the government guarantee. I must say that EFIC has operated for 35 years without a call on the government guarantee. It is anticipated that it will do so in the future. They are the essential points of the legislation.

As the legislation is not opposed--in fact, I understand that it is even supported by the Opposition and the Democrats--I need not go into great detail about the structural arrangements which have been entered into. Let me say, however, that I want to correct some misapprehensions. Firstly, EFIC supports somewhere between 10 per cent and 15 per cent of total Australian exports. A lot of concern has been expressed in the course of this debate about The Other Woman and that particular transaction, which I want to deal with in a minute for the umpteenth time.

The fact is that EFIC supports something like 15 per cent of Australian exports. While Mr Cantor might be alleged by some to be a bad risk because of some information which was plucked from a New Jersey newspaper, the fact is that, in terms of EFIC's total operations, the most costly operations that EFIC have had to indulge in over the years have been support for rural exports from this country to countries which are credit risks, either for political or other reasons. That is where EFIC's greatest exposure has been and that is an area which, strangely enough, the Opposition has said nothing about in the context of this debate. The point of an organisation like EFIC is that it does support export activities in a variety of fields that are not normally supported by private sector institutions and are not prepared to take that level of risk.

When Senator Bishop talks about the structural arrangements that have been entered into, she ought to get some things right. With her level of experience in discussing this issue, she ought to get a few fundamental things right. For example, she suggested that in 1986 I put Austrade and EFIC together and now, in 1991, I am responsible for taking them apart. Senator Bishop would not by any chance be avoiding the issue of getting the facts right, would she?

I make the point that, since its inception, EFIC was a separate statutory organisation until 1986, when it was put together with Austrade, not by me, as Senator Bishop said, but by the Minister responsible. This canard has been circulated by Senator Bishop and her colleague Mr Alex Downer--smart Alex Downer--in a number of press releases and elsewhere. They have said that I have had responsibility for EFIC and Austrade for six years. That is not true; I have had it for four years. There is an important difference in that. Senator Bishop should try to remember that fact in some of her public statements in the future because it is important if she keeps on repeating what is totally untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What--have you only been responsible for two-thirds?

—-Senator Bishop can say that if she wants to; it is her right. It is a free country and she can say that. No doubt she will. I want to correct her or one or two quite fundamental points about some of these issues and the practice which has been adopted by some Opposition politicians who are sort of garbage can recipients of all the political garbage and scuttlebutt that comes their way.
—-If you think about that, you might think that is a bit unparliamentary.

—-Not at all. That is certainly true of some allegations which have been floated about. Senator Bishop adopts a slightly different line from her colleagues in the House of Representatives regarding the separation of EFIC from Austrade, a decision which has been made by the Government. That decision was made essentially on the basis of two factors. The first is experience. EFIC work took up a great deal of Austrade's time. Austrade has a particular function to perform, which is the promotion of exports. EFIC has a particular function to perform which is different, and it is the financing of exports.

SPEECH.PARA: As we diversify exports from this country, EFIC's role becomes more and more associated with the support of manufacturing and service industry exports. As that happens, the important thing for EFIC is to have a close association with manufacturing exporters, which essentially comes through the industry portfolio. What we have done is restore the position to what it was on the basis of the objective, pragmatic experience of the operation of Austrade and EFIC together. We have made those arrangements which we think will work better in the future.

Senator Bishop said that she wanted to be assured that scrutiny will not be lessened because EFIC has become a government business enterprise. There is no change in the status of EFIC in those terms. EFIC has always been a government business enterprise. The level of scrutiny or otherwise will not change as a result of the sort of change which is now taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am very pleased to hear that.

—-I am glad that Senator Bishop is receptive to learning about these things. It will not change. I am surprised that, having given so much attention to this legislation and the issues associated with it, she did not notice that the statutory relationship remains the same. Senator Bishop, in talking about EFIC and its role in the future, picked up another point which was made by Mr Downer in the House of Representatives, that is, that the banking industry and the insurance industry should be involved in a working group to see what could be done consistent with EFIC's functions and further operations. Senator Bishop said it was unlikely that anything like that could be done because it was high risk business.
—-I didn't. I said it would not be privatised. Don't get it wrong.
—-I quote Senator Bishop. She said that it was unlikely that that could be done because of high risk business which EFIC--
—-I said it was unlikely to be privatised.
—-She went on to say that after she said the bit I have just mentioned. I wrote it down. She said that, because of high risk business, it was unlikely that it could be privatised.
—-You weren't here for the first part of my speech.

—-Yes I was and I wrote it down. Senator Bishop went on to say that, while it would be desirable to privatise it, overseas countries operated equivalent organisations. She doubted whether that could happen. That suggestion just confuses ideology with function. Everything that moves is to be privatised in this new Liberal Party, which has so much conviction and strength about these issues. It is still getting over the Fraser years when nothing happened and is now constantly trying to demonstrate its macho qualities by saying, `We will privatise all these things and everything will be sorted out'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not a very sensible approach to policy making; it is quite ridiculous. The suggestion a few months ago was that Austrade should be privatised. Members of the Liberal Party who went to Austrade to talk about that came back with the conclusion, on the basis of a little experience, that that should not happen. It is similar, of course, with EFIC because EFIC supplements and complements the private sector. It does not compete with the private sector; it complements it.

The suggestion has been made that there should be discussions with the banking and insurance industries to see where the activities of the two overlap. All those discussions took place this year with the banking industry and the insurance industry. We had a review of EFIC--its role and its functions--the banking and insurance industries were asked to make representations and their representations were discussed in the course of the review. What did they say? They said, `We are happy with the operations of EFIC as it now is'. Both industries said that. The only thing they really asked for in their written submission, but not in discussion, was the possibility of further government funding being made available to support private sector activity in making loans in support of exports.

You pay the piper, you call the tune. They would like us to pay the piper--them perhaps--rather than devote money to EFIC. That was not even raised by the banking or the insurance industries in the discussions which took place; it was only raised in the course of a written submission. For Mr Downer to make this latter day suggestion that there should be some discussions with the banking and insurance industries--

TALK.START.PARA: —-It wasn't `discussions'; it was a working party.

—-Senator Bishop wants to call it a working party. I do not know how they are going to work; they have to talk if they are going to work. There is too much talk, perhaps, but that is what they have to do. They have to talk.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Downer's making this latter day suggestion illustrates how out of touch the Opposition is on some of these issues except where it gets nice little leaks from people who have been sacked by Austrade, or people who have not been promoted by Austrade in the course of the McKinsey review, and gets fed a few little bits of scuttlebutt, most of which are wildly inaccurate. It is these issues which set Senator Bishop aflame with a passion for ironing out all these little concerns which she has. I concede they are important, nonetheless, they can become an obsession in the context of an organisation such as EFIC and an organisation such as Austrade.

I do not want to go back to the debate about The Other Woman--the ship. We have talked about this ad infinitum. Senator Bishop has publicly accused me of misleading Parliament on the basis of a letter which I wrote to her in which I admitted that there had been an interest subsidy of $268,000 in respect of this ship.

I wrote to Senator Bishop--I did not have to--and said, `I stand corrected on this issue'. If she had the grace and dignity occasionally to say, `I stand corrected' on some of these issues, then we would have what she seeks--a level playing field in the course of the debate. But Senator Bishop has made that accusation. She could not wait to put my letter into the public arena and repeat it again and again. Poor old Mr Cantor. She persecuted Mr Cantor around the country in pursuit of her private obsession about this issue, and there is no level playing field there.

What she has done time and time again, for a person who purports to know something about the processes of government, is to misrepresent the issue in relation to this ship. She talks about $17m of taxpayers' money. She has included in that an $8m loan which is repayable, but still she publicly says, `$17m of taxpayers' money has been lost'. She misrepresents this issue again and again. It might get her name on the front page of Truth or another newspaper like that, or on some sleazy television program, but it will not do her any good in the longer term to go out misrepresenting these facts.

Look at the other money which went into this ship. Bounty money went into this ship. Does Senator Bishop approve of bounty payments or not? She should answer the question publicly. Does she approve or not? She will not go out and say anything about that issue. Since 1949 various governments in this country have paid bounties to the shipbuilding industry and have subsidised it. It was in her Party's rotten period of government, throughout the Fraser period and so on, that the shipbuilding industry went downhill, day after day, week after week and there were no exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Watch the BP--the blood pressure.

—-Senator Patterson need not worry about that. She should look after herself and go back to swimming. Since this Government came to office we have been supporting exports of up to $250m a year from the shipbuilding industry in this country. That never happened during the period of government of those opposite when they paid the bounty at a much higher rate than we pay it.

SPEECH.PARA: The bounty is paid as a matter of right, in respect of which there is no discretion in either the Minister or anybody else, provided a shipyard is registered. The conditions under which a shipyard is registered are contained in the ships' bounty legislation. There is no discretion in either a Minister or anybody else about that issue, and there should not be. Senator Bishop's line is that a Minister should have his fingers in the honey pot all the time making decisions about whether Mr Cantor was sufficiently moral to make a loan to, and about whether the colour of the eyes of the proprietors of some shipyard or other was sufficiently blue in order for them to get the bounty.

Governments cannot be about that, just as governments cannot be about meddling in the day-to-day business of an organisation like Austrade--who it employs and so on. Senator Bishop and her colleagues should look at the Austrade Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I look at the provision for you to make a direction.
—-A direction in relation to matters of policy.
—-Which you have never done.
—-Yes I have.
—-Where?
—-In relation to South Africa. I think I made one at the time of the Gulf war. I certainly made at least one in relation to South Africa.
—-We will see that in the annual report.

—-That is not the point, Senator. If you think the power of direction in a Minister in section 10 of the Austrade Act means that a Minister can say, `You won't employ this consultant. You ought to employ that consultant. You ought to get down into the bin with Senator Bishop and look at every employee of Austrade and concern yourselves with all this petty bric-a-brac which belongs to the mind of a B-grade accountant.', that is so much bunkum because that is not a sound principle of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Austrade has a management. EFIC has a management. They both have boards which are responsible for these things. To cloud all these issues and put together in relation to The Other Woman as she is called--the ship--the bounty legislation, which has nothing whatsoever to do with EFIC legislation--

TALK.START.PARA: —-I didn't say it did.
—-Yes, you do, every time.
—-Senator Button, I have allowed this to go on partly for its entertainment value but I remind you that you should be addressing the chair.

—-Madam Chair, I am responding to Senator Bishop's speech which she made here. You may not have been here at the time--or maybe you dozed off, as most people do. The fact of the matter is that she made these allegations here again, she makes them in public and she has got it wrong. She ought to get it right so that she can pursue whether Mr Cantor repays his loan over the next few years in future Estimates committee hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is supported by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It is important legislation. It establishes EFIC as a statutory authority with a new board. EFIC will continue to discharge the same sorts of functions as those it has discharged in the past, together with some extra facilitating arrangements which the Government has made for EFIC in relation to the callable capital and one or two other matters which will enable it to improve its services to exports. That is a very important function.

This country is increasingly dependent on diversified trade relationships with the countries of the Asia-Pacific region. Export credit is a most important issue in those countries if Australia is going to do business. Ship credit--credit for the exports of ships--is a most important issue. No country in the OECD that builds ships does not provide export credit for those ships. Indeed, there is an OECD rate for exports of ships. It is the difference between that rate and interest rates in the United States and Australia which caused the payment of $268,000 in respect of the ship which Senator Bishop is obsessed about--maybe because of its name, maybe because of other things. I commend the legislation to the Senate and I look forward to its speedy passage.

—-I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia. Can the Minister advise what steps have been taken to broaden the research activities of the Darwin based North Australian Development Unit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At best, I think northern Australia has received spasmodic attention from previous Federal governments. It is my belief that this is one of the reasons why the social, economic and political debate in northern Australia is, in comparative terms, behind the rest of Australia. The Prime Minister has been determined to ensure that this would be redressed and that this Government would pay more than lip service to such an important area of our country. I was deliberately appointed as Minister assisting him for northern Australia as a result of that decision. Indeed, it was the first time that a Federal Minister had been appointed with responsibility for northern Australia since the dismissal of the Whitlam Government in 1975. Since that time the Government has been working on an economic development and social justice strategy for northern Australia to guide this and future Federal governments in assessing the potential of this region to our country.

ANSWER.PARA: The strategies are examining the economic structure and performance of the region, its income and wealth, its contribution to the national economy and the level of government services that are delivered in the region. The economic strategy is being conducted by the Centre for Applied Economic Research and Analysis at James Cook University in Townsville. It is exploring the avenues available for further economic development of the north and the means by which government can assist in facilitating this growth. The Government has recognised--indeed, I publicly stated it--that a study of the economic potential of the region would tell us only half of the story without an associated social justice strategy. As many honourable senators will be aware, the development of the strategy was announced in the last Budget.

Late last year, along with others, I expressed considerable interest in broadening the North Australian Development Unit's activities which, until now, have been specific to the Department of Social Security, to encompass other portfolio areas of interest to northern Australia. A particular concern was to provide through NADU some cross-portfolio coordination of these issues. After extensive consultation with the Prime Minister and several ministerial colleagues, particularly Senator Graham Richardson, the Minister for Social Security, it was decided to broaden the functions of this unit to enable it to conduct and sponsor research on potential economic and other developments in northern Australia as well as research on social security and program delivery in line with the economic development and social justice strategies of the Government.

This unit will become part of a new capacity on northern development matters within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet from the end of January 1992 and will report to me. The unit will be headed from 1 March 1992 for three years by Mr Bill Gray, who is currently Chief Executive Officer of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Mr Gray will become an Associate Secretary in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

I am particularly pleased at a personal level about this appointment. Mr Gray is not only a competent and proven administrator of some note--I am pleased to see Senator Tambling nodding in assent to that--but has also spent considerable periods of his life in northern Australia. On a personal level, I have known him for more than 20 years. I am delighted that he has been able to accept this appointment. By the way I point out, for Senator Tambling's benefit, if for no-one else's, that Mr Gray intends to reside in Darwin to fulfil this role.

In conclusion, the objective is to provide the analytical research base required for decisions on northern development, that is, to provide more direct support for my role in advancing within the Government the interests of northern Australia. As a consequence, we intend to name this new unit the Office of Northern Development. It is the first unit of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to be established in northern Australia.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Will the Minister explain the claims that the EIS for the third runway at Sydney Airport has failed to make a comprehensive analysis of the cost-benefit comparison of building a third runway and Badgerys Creek?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The claims are not correct. The environmental impact statement does in fact contain a comprehensive evaluation of the alternatives.
—-Is this how your back bench communicates with the Whips in the chamber?

—-This is an important matter and some Opposition senators actually want to hear the answer. The EIS does contain a comprehensive analysis of the alternatives that are available to the Government's strategy of constructing the third runway at Sydney Airport and having a staged development for the airport at Badgerys Creek.

ANSWER.PARA: What the environmental impact statement categorically demonstrates is that this strategy is the most cost-effective provision of airport capacity in terms of construction costs per passenger. It is the better strategy in terms of lower airport construction costs in net present value terms than the Badgerys Creek alternative. It produces lesser numbers of people in Sydney seriously affected by noise than a substantial domestic airport being established at Badgerys Creek. The estimate is that, with the third runway, the current number seriously affected by noise in Sydney would be substantially reduced to 26,900, whereas the number seriously affected by noise with Badgerys Creek and no third runway would be 34,000.

Other important economic considerations favouring this strategy include: an immediate large scale development at Badgerys Creek would require a minimum of $800m spent in road construction as compared with about $180m for the roads required for this development in Sydney; travel time from the central business district to Badgerys Creek represents a serious penalty of between 40 and 65 minutes over travel time from the central business district to Sydney Airport; and the immediate development--and this is vitally important--of a major domestic facility at Badgerys Creek would require the major airlines to split their operations--there are a number of examples around the world that can be turned to for the results of that--before commercial market demand said they should, and this would involve serious cost penalties to the operations of the major airlines.

The environmental impact statement does demonstrate that Badgerys Creek will not be commercially viable until around 2005 to 2010. Consequently, the immediate construction of a regular passenger transport airport at Badgerys Creek would have to be totally funded by the taxpayer, as opposed to the construction of the third runway at Sydney Airport which will be funded by the FAC in a normal commercial manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Some of yours don't.

—-In response to that interjection, if the Opposition's proposals to build a narrow spaced third runway at Sydney Airport had been developed, it would have been an economic and aviation disaster. That was the Opposition's policy. Not only did the Government move away from that option but, as a result of the environmental impact statement being conducted, it was decided to widen the space between the runways by an additional margin as distinct from the Government's original decision. This will provide quite beneficial operational benefits to the airport.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, the EIS also reviewed the cost-benefit analysis done by Coopers and Lybrand and found that, compared with that company's estimate of $17m, there was a net benefit of over $1 billion of the third runway as compared with Badgerys Creek.

—-My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the campaign which, understandably, aims to enable Mr James Savage, whose death sentence has been commuted by a United States court to lengthy imprisonment, to serve his sentence in an Australian gaol. Is there any provision for this to be done? If not, can the Government take any action to make it possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand why Senator Zakharov has asked this question. She refers to some understandable reasons which might lead people to think that a person such as Mr James Savage ought to be transferred to serve his prison term in Australia, perhaps on the grounds that he would thereby enjoy the support of the Aboriginal community in Melbourne and that of his natural mother.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, there are other considerations which need to be taken into account. One has to recall that this man was found guilty by a jury in Florida of murder in the first degree, robbery with a deadly weapon and sexual battery with great force, with a deadly weapon, against a 57-year-old woman. I think that we can all take some heart in the fact that the Florida Supreme Court has commuted the death sentence. It is certainly in accord with Australia's humanitarian policy that the death penalty ought not to be inflicted, even for such crimes as those.

The question of whether a transfer ought to take place is quite another matter. Indeed, under Australian law at the moment there is no provision whatsoever by way of treaty with the United States, or indeed any other country for that matter, to permit the transfer of prisoners from a jurisdiction in which they have been convicted back to Australia. Even if Australia did have such a treaty on international models, it would require the consent of the sentencing country to allow that transfer to take place. It is by no means clear that the State of Florida, for example, would consent to the transfer of a prisoner who has been properly convicted of the crimes that I have mentioned.

Before Australia would even consider entering into such a treaty relationship, Victoria would be required to pass enabling legislation to make it possible to hold such a person in custody in an Australian prison. Otherwise, if Mr Savage, for example, was simply returned to Australia and taken from the airport to a place of custody in Victoria, he could immediately apply for habeas corpus and be released. There is no law enabling him to be held in Australia for an offence for which he has been convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment abroad. There would also need to be laws relating to remissions and so on.

The bottom line in all of this is, as far as I am aware, that there has been no request made by Mr Savage; there have been various people purporting to speak on his behalf. As I understand it, there has been no formal request made by Mr Savage. Of course, if such a request were to be made, the Government would take it into account in formulating its policy. The policy of the Australian Government at the moment is that there are no such treaties. I believe that I have indicated a very considerable number of legal hurdles which would stand in the way of their being negotiated successfully.

—-Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen reports of proposals for industrial relations reform in which a minimum hourly wage rate would be set `within a bull's roar of the mean average wage that is paid at present'? Is this a technical term that only industrial relations experts understand? For the sake of the ill-informed in this chamber, can the Minister explain where this bull's roar could be placed on the scale between the award rates of pay and average weekly earnings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have seen reports, which appeared in the Bulletin of 1 October, of an interview with John Howard, the shadow Minister for industrial relations. It is an interesting interview. It is the first time in my reading experience in the past couple of years that I have seen John Howard probed behind his glib slogans and asked to answer in detail what his significant slogans are supposed to mean. He is found extremely wanting on both the facts and on the details. The shadow Minister is pretty good on slogans and one-liners, but they do not mean anything about real things in the real world affecting real people.

ANSWER.PARA: Among the more startling revelations in this interview was that he said that the Opposition would support a minimum wage, expressed as an hourly rate, to prevent exploitation of workers under the Howard version of workplace bargaining. He said that the minimum wage--and the quote is right, as I understand it--would be within a bull's roar of the mean average wage that is paid at present. That sounds good and caring, but it raises a number of questions.

For example, the mean average wage that I assume he is referring to is the current average weekly earnings, which stand at around $480 a week. The lowest award rate--and this is an award rate determined by the Industrial Relations Commission based on justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case in this industry--is around $300 a week. In metals, it is $305 a week; in child care, it is $302; and in clothing, it is $303. So if the average weekly earnings are $480 and the lowest award rate is around $300, does this mean that bringing it within a bull's roar is an increase of roughly $180 a week for those workers? Is that what Mr Howard means? If he does mean that, once the wages of those lower paid workers have been brought up to the average, the average will change and get higher, so will we then bring wages up again--and again and again?

It may well be that Mr Howard has invented a new system of wage fixation in this country. It may well be that Mr Howard has invented a new form of wage leapfrogging. It prompts one to ask: is Mr Howard an ACTU stooge? Does the ACTU know about this? Does the Confederation of Australian Industry support what Mr Howard says? Or does Mr Howard mean something much more sinister than what those obvious, literal translations of his words indicate? Does it mean, for example, that $300 a week is where the minimum wage will be set, and that bringing the minimum wage within a bull's roar of the mean average means that wages in this country will be depressed to the minimum level in order to lower real income levels across the board? Is that what the minimum wage means? I look forward to some clarification on this matter by Mr Howard because certainly wages policy, as articulated by him as an expression of policy on a very important part of the economic policy, is unintelligible at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. Is the Minister aware of proposals by some States that the National Rail Freight Corporation should be expanded to include interstate passenger services as well as freight? Does the Commonwealth agree that moving interstate passengers efficiently is just as important as moving freight? What are the impediments to such a rationalisation and efficiency measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following response to Senator Kernot's question. The National Rail Freight Corporation has been established by the Commonwealth and the mainland States, except South Australia, to operate all interstate rail freight operations under a single management structure. South Australia supports the Corporation and proposes to sign the agreement after a number of issues under its railway transfer agreement with the Commonwealth are resolved through bilateral negotiations.

ANSWER.PARA: The NRC will operate under the provisions of the Companies Code as a strictly commercial corporation at arm's length from government, and will be subject to the laws of the Commonwealth and relevant States on the same basis as any private company. It is expected to commence operations in the new year, beginning with marketing and terminal operations. Other functions will be transferred progressively from other rail systems.
The NRC will be responsible for its capital investment program and investment in specific corridors, such as the Melbourne-Adelaide line. This will be undertaken, again, on a fully commercial basis.

The NRC's charter is to eliminate losses on interstate freight operations within three years and to become profitable within five years. No decision on standardising Melbourne-Adelaide has yet been taken by the NRC. In fact, the Corporation is holding its inaugural board meeting today. Should the NRC decide to proceed with this option, it would only do so if it were consistent with the NRC's charter to eliminate its current losses. On this basis, the benefits of any decision to standardise this rail link would flow to all Australians who currently bear the cost of subsidising interstate rail freight operations.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the unanimous decision of the democratically elected Parliament of Croatia last night to activate the declaration of independence made on 25 June. Was this decision taken in face of the continued threats to democracy and peace, culminating in the bombing of the Presidential Offices which are adjacent to the parliamentary building in Zagreb, these bombings having been directed by the Yugoslav high command who are members of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia? What was meant by the Prime Minister's statement last night to cheering Croatian demonstrators here in Canberra that the Australian Government will recognise the independence of Croatia `as soon as we can'? What is preventing that recognition now? When will that recognition take place so as to give a clear message to the hardline Stalinists in the Yugoslav high command that Australia rejects the Maoist notion that power grows out of the barrel of a gun?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We in Australia and the Government accept that the desire for independence by the people of Croatia, and Slovenia for that matter as well, has been popularly and democratically expressed. As the Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions, not just last night, Australia will be among the first to recognise Croatia and Slovenia when the conditions are right; as soon as we can, in other words. What is constraining us in that respect is essentially two considerations: one is the need to satisfy ourselves that the formal international criteria for recognition are in fact satisfied, and there is a very real question, certainly so far as Croatia is concerned, on the issue of effective control of the territory in question by the government in question. It is very difficult to argue that there is such effective control in the particular military environment that Senator Harradine has just drawn attention to.

ANSWER.PARA: More than that, there is a concern not to go down the path of premature recognition to the extent that this, or in circumstances where this, would in fact prejudice the achievement of a comprehensive settlement of the whole sorry situation in Yugoslavia. That is very much the view that is being taken at the moment by the countries of Europe, with which we are, of course, in close consultation on this issue and with many of the foreign Ministers with whom I have had recent opportunities to talk in both Europe and New York. It is the view that is being taken in North America by the United States and by Canada. It is generally a very widespread perception that as horrifying as the conflict has become, as urgently as we all want to see it resolved, there is no basis for making the assumption that a resolution would be any faster or any more satisfactory were we to jump into recognition.

We will have regard to the various considerations that I have mentioned, just as was the case with the Baltic states, as soon as we are satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, as soon as it is possible to do so. As soon as the modicum of conditions that I have identified are satisfied, we will be among the first to recognise the entities in question as sovereign, independent countries. It is not time to do so now.

As to the larger question that Senator Harradine has raised about the conditions that are at work producing the conflict that we are witnessing, whether it is an ideological conflict or whether, as rather more people would want to characterise it, it is one involving ancient, nationalist and ethnic enmities, that is an issue I do not think it is necessary to go into on this occasion.

Similarly, as I said yesterday, while overwhelmingly the concern of the international community at the moment points to the activities of the JNA and, in effect, the Serbian side of the argument, it is not easy to say that has always been the case with every single one of the breaches of the cease-fire or the acts of gross misbehaviour that have occurred during this unhappy conflict. It is not an easy situation in which to cast one-sided blame. Our hope is simply that good sense, moderation and reason will prevail, that all sides will appreciate that this is a conflict which can only be resolved by negotiation, not `out of the barrel of the gun' as Senator Harradine says, and that a negotiated peace that recognises these emerging realities on the ground will certainly be achievable.

—-My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.
—-This is out of the top drawer.

—-I put it away. I thought Question Time was over. I draw the Minister's attention to the media reports in Queensland that allege Japanese organised crime members are infiltrating the Gold Coast. Could the Minister advise the Senate whether the Australian Federal Police is monitoring the actions of Yakuza in this country? Could the Minister assure the Senate that Yakuza have not financed or do not hold interests in tourist resorts in this country? Finally, has the Australian Federal Police received current information regarding Yakuza movements from the Japanese federal police?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think Senator Jones is probably principally referring to a Four Corners report recently which covered investment in Australian golf courses and resorts by allegedly disreputable Japanese people and corporations. It appears that the report correctly stated that a number of the Japanese businessmen who have been charged in Japan for company and share market offences have been involved in such investments, but these were made prior to any charges being laid. Nevertheless, the question of money laundering of the proceeds of crime into Australian real estate and tourist developments is a matter which the Government takes very seriously indeed. For that reason, the Australian Federal Police's national intelligence division is compiling a report on the situation. I had discussions as late as yesterday with the Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, particularly in relation to the money laundering aspects.

ANSWER.PARA: But there are some difficulties which ought to be understood. The first is that the national police agency in Japan is only one agency. There are 47 prefectorial police forces operating autonomously from the national police agency. There is no central intelligence base and the national police agency in Japan has very little of the intelligence held by the prefectorial police or other agencies.

Japan also has very strict privacy laws which control the exchange of information; even the information exchanged through Interpol is severely limited. No information will be released by Japan unless there is a specific offence under investigation and that offence exists in Japanese legislation as well. As I am advised that money laundering is not an offence under Japanese legislation, we have some difficulty in that regard.

Since February this year the Federal Police has used its liaison officer in Honolulu to liaise with the Japanese National Police Agency. This is relevant because the United States law enforcement agencies have long-established networks of cooperation with Japanese law enforcement agencies based in Hawaii in relation to the overseas activities of the Yakuza. I believe that that sort of comprehensive knowledge possessed by the United States law enforcement authorities as to the penetration of Japanese criminal enterprises overseas is a very useful network into which the Australian Federal Police do tap.

Representatives of the Federal Police have attended a number of conferences in Japan on drugs and organised crime, the last one being the Third Conference on Organised Crime in 1990. In November this year the Assistant Commissioner, Investigations, Mr Ian Broomby, will be attending a Tokyo conference on organised crime. I have asked him to ensure that our very real concern about these matters is conveyed to the Japanese authorities and to pursue every possibility of ensuring that current, relevant, timely advice is available to the Australian Federal Police so that we can deal with the phenomenon of alleged money laundering into Australian tourist developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Bell asked me a question about the potato cyst nematode and I promised to get back to him with further details. My answer is not all that long, but I do not wish to delay the Senate with the internal analysis of this disease, so I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: PCN is regarded as the most serious pest threatening the Australian potato industry.
It was first found in Australia in 1986 at Munster, south of Perth. Extensive surveys in Western Australia over the past few years indicate the nematode only occurs in the Munster area.

In late January this year the nematode was also found in a potato crop at Wandin, Victoria about 45km east of Melbourne. Extensive surveys since then indicate that PCN is confined to a total of four market gardens, all in the Wandin area.
Both outbreaks are subject to eradication campaigns which are coordinated by a Standing Committee on Agriculture (SCA) Consultative Committee.

Research indicates that the Western Australian and Victorian outbreaks are unlikely to be linked. However, the means by which each outbreak became established is unknown but it is likely that the nematode had been present for a number of years, at both locations, before it was detected.

Quarantine has been applied to the infested properties and the area surrounding them, which has restricted the movement of potatoes and nursery stock plants within Victoria, interstate and overseas. An assessment of the economic impact of these restrictions on the industry is not known at this time.

I rise today to comment on the annual report for 1991 of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, a relatively new body to the economic and social life of this country and to the industry. Unfortunately, the Government has not provided nearly enough resources to enable this new body, capably led by Mr Richard Beetham, to execute its responsibilities in the timely manner required of a service delivery agency of the Commonwealth. However, this lack of resources should not in any way diminish the importance of this new body because it will continue to play a significant economic and social role in Australia, particularly in an environment of potential growth for the insurance and life insurance industry.

I draw to the Senate's attention two primary responsibilities of the Commission. Firstly, it has to supervise insurance companies and brokers and superannuation funds in accordance with the requirements of the relevant legislation and, secondly, it has to consider issues of relevance to the insurance and superannuation industries as well as to consumers and beneficiaries of services provided by those industries.

This Labor Government has announced its plans of bringing the annual contributions of the everyday workers' salaries or wages to something like 9 per cent or above by the end of the decade so that superannuation will be by way of future savings for Australia. Unfortunately, the Government has failed to acknowledge a number of problems inherent in this approach. Businesses see this as another type of payroll tax, another impediment to employment and another significant cost to jobs and industry. There are special problems that I do not think have been adequately addressed in developing this approach. There are special problems for casual employees, itinerants and even married women, particularly in their capacity to accumulate adequate funds for a meaningful retirement benefit without losing significant benefits under health care card and pharmaceutical arrangements.

Unfortunately, superannuation has now been seen by this Government as a very convenient vehicle for adding significantly to the revenues of government. All too readily, the changes in the last few years have been seen as golden eggs in terms of the potential for revenue collection. They form and are centred basically around the need, as far as the Government is concerned, to get additional revenue from this form of saving. I believe that is regrettable. It is regrettable that we have an entry fee of 15 per cent, which means that for every $100 invested effectively 15 per cent is potentially coming off that investment. So the available amount for investment is diminishing. I believe that we should have a greater degree of flexibility in the range of savings that can be made through insurance plans.

The other big problem I see is the very heavy charges made by the life insurance industry in the management of those funds and its impact on accumulated savings, particularly for people such as married women or casual employees. People who move from job to job sometimes find that they are contributing, for example, to a number of casual employee superannuation funds. The companies concerned are deducting portions of their incomes perhaps to put them towards life benefit funds. However, in a few years, the various costs will mean that the investments come back to having a nil value. So as a means of saving for retirement for certain people in our society, I do not believe that these schemes are a very efficient mechanism. The Government should be looking at other vehicles such as savings plans and saving through other avenues in the insurance area.

The amount invested in superannuation over the years illustrates the growing importance of it. In 1980, total investments in the industry totalled $18 billion. They are estimated to be $130 billion this year with the possibility of reaching $600 billion in another 10 years. Not only management but also prudential standards will be required to make sure that we do not have too many entrepreneurs entering this industry with a view to executing fraud and other offences. TALK.START.PARA: —-In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: annual report of the Australian National Audit Office, 1990-91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to the Auditor-General's report on the Australian National Audit Office, I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate a significant disagreement that has now emerged between the Audit Office and the Government which requires early settlement. The Auditor-General, as the servant of the Parliament and, through the Parliament, the people of Australia, has to ensure that public money is spent properly and that departments and organisations and other bodies of the Government behave in a responsible way and within the law in the collection and spending of taxpayers' money.

Unfortunately, the Government is apparently disagreeing with the Auditor-General about some significant elements of the way in which the Audit Act should be reformed and how the role of the Auditor-General should be protected from the activities of government. In some instances, those activities appear to be aimed at limiting the capacity of the Auditor-General to provide to this Parliament the full and proper reports that this Parliament requires. As the Auditor-General says in the foreword to his report:

The year saw only limited progress in the development of the new Auditor-General Act to replace the Audit Act 1901. The new Act may not be in operation until 1 July 1993--some four years after the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended its development. This is most unsatisfactory. Furthermore, the proposed Act does not include the most important of the reforms recommended. . .
He discusses those reforms later in the report. On the question of efficiency audits, the Attorney-General notes that:

. . . any objective appraisal of current achievements in creating the basis for long term benefits to the Parliament through the ANAO can show only limited results because action to achieve the fundamental reforms proposed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its 1989 Report on Reform of the Australian Audit Office is still needed.

The Auditor-General is stressing here that we will get only limited results because of the failure of the Government to proceed, as it should have proceeded long ago, with the reforms required in the Audit Act. Some problems remain with the type of mandate the Audit Office should have. The Auditor-General says in his report:

Although the ANAO's efforts in 1990-91 have gone some way to address the call from all recent external reviews for major increases in ANAO efficiency auditing activity, the return of the Government Business Enterprise mandate to the ANAO has been accomplished by the qualification that efficiency audits may only be carried out at the request of the relevant Minister.

In other words, appropriate inquiries into the Government's organisations can be done only if the Government feels it is appropriate for it to be done. The Auditor-General is acting on behalf of the people, not of the `management'. It is exactly the same situation with the auditor of a public company. The auditor of a public company reports and examines on behalf of the shareholders, not on behalf of the management. The Auditor-General says that efficiency audits may be carried out only at the request of the relevant Minister. He further says:

This constitutes, in effect, a mandate reduction and will require detailed monitoring on our part of the effectiveness of other performance and accountability mechanisms in place. Any problems arising may require me to consider this restriction more closely.

He also notes that the Government appears to have some kind of policy of limiting the scope of the Auditor, because in the matters of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation legislation the Senate had to amend legislation to ensure his mandate. This revealed the extent to which the Auditor-General and the Government appear to be on a collision course. The Auditor-General says:

As a result of this I can no longer support the exercise of ministerial discretion in granting choice of auditor. The shareholder, i.e. the Parliament, should be able to indicate its wishes in this matter (as it did for the AWRC and AWC). It is a matter of deep concern that the proposed Auditor-General's Act, which would provide a long term framework for Parliament's approval, is still awaited.
I believe the proposed Auditor-General Act should be changed to provide more effective assurance of the Auditor-General's mandate.

The Opposition would totally support that view and endorse the Auditor-General's concerns. The Auditor-General also states that the Australian National Audit Office needs to operate as a statutory authority. He says:

The importance of an effective public sector audit office in supporting accountability to the Parliament, to Ministers and to Boards is well recognised. However, if unaddressed, existing constraints on the ANAO's capacity to manage itself will heighten the risk that those served by the ANAO will receive less assurance and protection than they should have. Recent experiences in the private sector and some areas of State Government administration are indeed a warning of the dangers that exist. The Commonwealth administration appears to believe it is immune.

This Government has seen the disasters that have taken place in State Labor administrations around this country where multimillions of dollars of taxpayers' moneys have gone down the gurgler in badly audited, incompetently run and disgracefully managed--in terms of governmental management--organisations. This Government is still shackling the Auditor-General and, as the Auditor-General says, `The Commonwealth administration appears to believe it is immune' from the very same things that have damaged so many State governments. The Auditor-General's report needs to be seriously looked at. I agree with the Auditor-General's comment that the assurance required by the Parliament about the performance of a public sector organisation reflects public accountability and is a higher obligation than that placed on private sector auditors.
As the Senate knows, there are multimillions of dollars of funds involved in many of these governmental organisations and accountability is absolutely vital. The report continues:

. . . Parliamentary concerns and interests are of central importance in the planning of the audit work program and, therefore, the Auditor-General's decisions on his work program take into account the views of the Parliament.

There is no doubt in my mind that the view of the Parliament is clearly that the Auditor-General should have greater capacity to report in an unfettered way to this Parliament. I conclude by requesting the Government to hasten this process. The failure to proceed with this legislation so far is of major concern. As the Auditor-General says:
On 30 November 1990--
almost 12 months ago--

the Department advised that its aim was to have the drafting instructions for the legislative package to replace the Audit Act. . . completed in sufficient time to permit the legislation to be introduced into Parliament in the 1991 Budget sittings, with a proposed commencement date of 1 July 1992.
At this stage we have seen no indications that that legislation will come forward. As the Auditor-General says:

. . . the introduction of the legislation into the Parliament in the 1991 Budget sitting and the commencement date of 1 July 1992 appear unlikely to be achieved unless the Government and the Parliament increase their priority in the legislative tabling program.
As far as the Opposition is concerned, we would be very keen to see that legislation come forward. The Auditor-General continues:

If the legislative package is not included in the 1991 Budget sitting of Parliament, an eventuality that is becoming more and more certain, then the next likely commencement date for the legislation would be 1 July 1993--some four years after the JCPA reported. This is an extraordinary delay for legislation that sets the revised accountability principles for the public sector.

I say amen to all that. I urge the Government to accept the Auditor-General's strong recommendations and to recognise that his views have generated a great degree of concern within the Opposition about the Government's willingness and enthusiasm to allow itself to be subject to the sort of scrutiny that it requires. I urge the Government to take speedy action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I also want to comment briefly on the annual report of the Australian National Audit Office. I congratulate the Auditor-General and his staff on the production of this report, which I think is an excellent, very comprehensive and informative document, although we have had only a couple of hours in which to look at it. It will certainly bear very careful further consideration because the audit function goes very much to the core of efficiency and propriety in terms of the operations of a parliamentary democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Office runs a very lean operation. Its resources are limited. It carries out a major role for us all. In the past 12 months and beyond it has undertaken a very heavy program. In recent years it has had added the role of efficiency auditing on top of its more traditional roles of performance auditing and the auditing of financial statements. Its complexity of work has also increased greatly over recent years as the complexity of government has increased and as the operations of government have become more commercialised in various areas, therefore requiring a different form and technique of auditing and a different role for the Auditor-General than has perhaps been the case in the past. I congratulate the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, in particular, and his staff on what I believe has been an excellent job.

Following up some of Senator Michael Baume's comments, which were very apt, the Auditor-General has done that job under extremely difficult circumstances. I too refer to the delay in the proposed new legislation to replace the existing Audit Act--legislation which will comprise, as I understand it, three or four new Acts which were meant to be introduced this year so that they could be properly debated and actually operative from 1 July 1992. In any event, that would have been a very long delay since the original decisions were made to go down this new legislative path.

I would have to say that Senator Baume's concern and the Auditor-General's concern about the extraordinary push out of the starting date to 1 July 1993 were confirmed by the Government in the Senate Estimates Committee hearings just a few days ago. Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, confirmed to Senate Estimates Committee A that the legislation would not be operative until 1 July 1993 and that this Parliament will not be seeing the legislation in draft form probably until late in the autumn session of 1992.
