TALK.START.PARA: —-So the Hawke Government will totally escape the scrutiny as we will be in government by then.

—-Certainly, the Hawke Government will escape the added scrutiny that will be imposed as a result of these new provisions, but I can assure Senator Baume and the Senate as a whole that that does not mean that its performance will escape very intense scrutiny when it is thrown out and replaced by a coalition government at some stage in the next 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The delay does pose very major problems. It is intended that, as a fundamental part of the Audit Act reform process, the mandate of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office will be made much clearer than is now the case. The problem that the Auditor-General now faces is that the Government has given no firm direction to the Audit Office in terms of its mandate. It has left it being neither fish nor fowl and in a most confused and uncertain situation.

That has already had some major implications. We saw some earlier this year, the Senate will recall, over the question of whether the Audit Office would have a role in auditing the functions of the revised organisations associated with the wool industry. We had the situation where the drafting of the legislation relating to the wool industry--very important legislation concerning, potentially, $3 billion-plus of taxpayers' funds lined up by way of guarantees and so on--did not give the Audit Office the prime role in auditing those new wool industry organisations. It was only as a result of an extraordinary and very courageous act by the Auditor-General in bringing to the attention of the Parliament his concern at that situation that the Opposition--I am pleased to say with the support of the Australian Democrats--was able to change the legislation to give the Auditor-General an unequivocal mandate in relation to that wool industry auditing.

So long as the new legislation remains a figment of our imagination--which is all it is at the moment--the uncertainty and the confusion will continue, and the prospect of something seriously going wrong will continue because the Auditor-General does not have the mandate and the clarity in relation to his mandate that should exist.

In his report the Auditor-General draws attention to the problems as a result of the delay in the introduction of the new legislation. I urge the Government to have another look at this matter because it has obviously pushed the question of the audit function down far too low in its order of priorities. It is a matter that should have almost top priority for the Government. These delays, which now appear certain to occur in the introduction of that legislation, would be unnecessary if the Government were to reorder its priorities. I would strongly urge it to do so.

Another matter which is not touched on--from the consideration I have been able to give the report up to date--but which I believe the Parliament needs to address more closely is just where the Auditor-General and the Audit Office ought to fit into the whole structure of our parliamentary democracy. In chapter 2 of his report, the Auditor-General talks about the relations between the Audit Office and the Parliament. He makes some important points there but he does not go on to raise the really important issue of where the Audit Office should lie. At the moment it lies within executive government but the statutory responsibility of the Auditor-General is to report to the Parliament. In many respects it can be argued that the Auditor-General ought to be and is the servant of the Parliament; not just part of the executive government and subject to the whims left open to it at the behest of the executive government of the day.

We have not yet given sufficient attention to this very important question of whether the Audit Office and the Office of the Auditor-General ought to be located within the Parliament. That is something we need to address. The Public Accounts Committee is also of that mind. In America, as I understand it, the Audit Office is located within the structure of the Congress or the Parliament and is not a creature of executive government. Subject to further consideration, that is something which would be highly desirable in this nation as well.

I end where I began: the role of the Audit Office and the Auditor-General is quite crucial to the efficient functioning of a parliamentary democracy. It is one of the major safeguards that any parliamentary democracy can have around it. It needs to be protected and preserved at all costs. The process is helped considerably with the consideration of this year's annual report by the Parliament and also, hopefully, a consideration by the wider community about the role of the Audit Office and its functions. I congratulate the Auditor-General on what he has done to publicise these very important matters. I hope that we as a Senate and the Parliament as a whole will build on the report and give the function and role of the Audit Office the attention it deserves if we are to preserve our parliamentary institutions and our democratic institutions in the way I know we all wish to do.

His office is an effective way of keeping the public sector accountable, and this should not be hindered in any way.

I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that, in the corporate world during the 1980s, we saw Australian corporations through their various managements seek to do away with many of the internal controls, internal audit functions and staff associated with those important stewardship roles, with the result that we saw a corporate cowboy image develop in that environment. Despite pressures within the public sector to provide for such degrees of freedom in the public sector, through such agencies as the Public Accounts Committee and comments by various members in the House of Representatives and honourable senators in this chamber, we continue to press very strongly for adequate manning for internal audits to ensure that we have a continued high level of internal control mechanisms.

It is therefore a tribute to the Office of the Auditor-General, and previous Auditors-General, that we have not seen lapses in stewardship; we have not seen the loss of public funds in the public sector in the same way that money has been dissipated wantonly, recklessly and negligently in the private sector. I think this alone is sufficient testament to ensure that the Australian National Audit Office has the widest field of mandate so far as the public purse is concerned. I refer to the `public purse' as being where the Commonwealth Government effectively has oversight or guarantee, even though it might not make annual appropriations to particular government agencies.

I pay tribute to the Australian National Audit Office for the close role that it has with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which I am Vice-Chairman. I would also like to pay tribute to the calibre of staff who come to our Joint Committee through the Australian National Audit Office. I believe that they have continued to add to the high level and quality of the reports prepared by the JCPA. Parliamentary committees, through their examinations of Auditor-General's reports, play a crucial role in the public accountability process.

The report that has been presented today is but one of the many mechanisms whereby this accountability is acknowledged and communicated to the Parliament. This role, I believe, is enhanced by the fact that the Auditor-General looks to the Parliament. He looks to the committees and to individual senators and members for specific direction in the programming, planning and execution of audits. He always keeps the parliamentary interest closely at hand.

I again pay tribute to the support given not only by the Australian National Audit Office in providing seconded officers to the Committee, but also by the officers of the Australian National Audit Office who frequently attend the hearings of the Joint Committee in their capacity as observers and witnesses and who provided background papers and other information which is vital to our Committee.

In relation to some of that help, I refer specifically to the Department of Defence project, the annual reporting guidelines for statutory authorities, the social responsibility of statutory authorities and government business enterprises, the research and development project, the business migration program and the control of visitor entry. Again, I pay tribute not only to those staff who were employed specifically on those functions but also to the wider role of advice that has been given from time to time.

More importantly, the existence of the Auditor-General's Office and the large number of detailed reports issued by his office have allowed the Joint Committee to undertake a number of specific inquiries. There are 10 inquiries listed in the report and I refer the chamber to them.

This new Act, which we are hoping will come in the not-too-distant future, should affirm that the Auditor-General is the independent external auditor of the Executive and, as such, has statutory responsibilities to report to the Parliament. I remind the Senate that, as is stated in the report, audit independence can effectively be jeopardised through the imposition of resource constraints in one form or

another. The complete resource independence for the Australian Audit Office is neither possible nor desirable without having a mechanism which will provide an adequate minimum level of resources for the public sector audit functions. Where we have an inadequate level of resources, we will constrain the level of activity and the effectiveness of this important office of state.

It is rather unfortunate that in recent times we have tended to see an unfortunate degree of conflict arising between the Department of Finance and the Audit Office. It is inevitable, of course, that some of their functions from time to time, in this stewardship role and advice role, will tend to run along parallel lines. There is a need for both organisations to continue to display high levels of professionalism in the maintenance of standards which are of the highest order in ensuring the integrity of the parliamentary purse and the confidence that the Australian people have in the administration of the Commonwealth.

Therefore, I urge that the Australian national auditor be an officer of the Parliament, free of the Executive. In his response the Auditor-General acknowledges that, throughout the goals and corporate plans, his responsibilities are essentially to the Parliament and to the Executive, in that order. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! Before I call Senator Sowada, I remind honourable senators that this is her first speech. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, the pundits say that a week is a long time in politics and, whilst I certainly knew this intellectually, the reality of this maxim hit hard and fast seven weeks ago with the sudden resignation of Senator Paul McLean.

SPEECH.PARA: It was T.E. Lawrence, better known as Lawrence of Arabia, who, when speaking of the success of the Arab wars, said:
The dreamers of the day are dangerous men, for they may act out their dream with open eyes, to make it possible. This I did.

I have to confess of now understanding a little of what he meant because in my early teens I dreamt of one day participating in public life as a member of parliament. I now stand here before you, some 17 years later, as an Australian Democrats senator representing the State of New South Wales but, unlike Lawrence, this has been made possible not only by my own efforts but also by the one who came before me.

Mr President, it is a source of deep regret that I stand in this place and speak now as Paul McLean's replacement rather than as his parliamentary colleague. I have known Paul for nearly 10 years; since I first joined the Democrats, in fact. Indeed, it was he who encouraged and fostered my involvement in the Party when I was a new, bright-eyed and bushytailed young member full of ideals, enthusiasm and more schemes than a dog has fleas.

Paul is a foundation member of the Democrats and served at all levels of the party organisation prior to his election to the Senate in 1987. He fought many preselections before success came his way in 1986. Many members regarded this as a long overdue success made possible by the retirement of Senator Colin Mason.

During his four years in this place Paul's contribution to the Senate and to the Australian Democrats was enormous. As a former Army major his appreciation of the problems faced by veterans and their families ensured that the Australian Democrat contribution to legislation affecting their needs was underlined by a real understanding of the issues.

Likewise with defence policy, Paul was able to graft his experience and commitment to peace issues onto new defence models, unencumbered by the rigid thinking of old-style defence planners who saw value only in aircraft carriers, bulky hardware and large numbers of troops. Surely the Gulf War has shown us how out of date this antiquated approach has become. Wars can now be fought and nearly won without a regular soldier firing a single bullet.

It is in the economic area that Paul's contribution will be best remembered. As industrial relations spokesperson, Paul's many months of discussions with unions and business groups were about to bear fruit as he prepared for the major industrial relations debate that we are about to embark upon.

Perhaps his most memorable contribution was in his vigorous, relentless and dogged pursuit of bank malpractice, culminating in the now famous `Westpac letters' and pressure which was a major factor in the establishment of a parliamentary inquiry into banking. In so doing, Paul uncovered a veritable hornet's nest of shady dealings and gave hope to the hundreds, nay thousands, of average customers and small business people who had been wronged at the hands of banks and financial institutions.

The Australian Democrats will not let up in their pursuit of this issue now that Paul has gone. Indeed, we would fail in our commitment to small business if we let this important issue fall off our agenda. Paul himself will continue to work on his banking material over the coming months. We all wish Paul well for the future and hope that he will continue to contribute to the Australian Democrats and to public life in whatever capacity he feels able. His absence from the parliamentary party will be sorely missed and keenly felt.

So here I am, thrust into public life and acting out my dream. And yet my career as a Middle Eastern archaeologist is itself, for many people, a deep desire surrounded by fantasies of fantastic discoveries, exotic locations and a tinge of danger. Mr President, reality never matches the fantasy.

Many people have commented that my work as an archaeologist makes for an unusual background as a member of parliament. Perhaps it does. But while my archaeological background has received considerable attention in recent weeks, few would be aware that I spent a number of years in the insurance industry as a broker of fire and general insurance prior to changing careers and attending university.

I note that here in this place are gathered many people from around Australia with a variety of life experiences; indeed, I believe it is important that the Parliament of Australia should reflect the diversity which exists in our society. Nevertheless, it is a sad commentary on all our parties that Aboriginal people are not currently represented by one member in this place.

Despite the ethnic nature of my surname, I was born in Australia of parents who were very much the classic postwar European migrants from England and the Continent. I am a regular churchgoer and have lived all my life in Sydney's eastern suburbs, close to the beach and deeply influenced by the public school `surf culture' of Bondi and Coogee. In many respects the teenage experiences reflected in the 1970s movie Puberty Blues illustrate the typical struggles that I and many of my school mates faced in our formative years.

During this important time my interest in politics, issues and current affairs was fostered by my parents, themselves classic swinging voters living in the soon-to-be-abolished marginal seat of Phillip. My father was insistent that dinner be spent as a family gathered around the table, rather than around the television set. As an early example of my interest in politics, I recall at the tender age of 13 engaging my school colleagues in a vigorous playground debate about the merits of Gough Whitlam's removal from office. Little did I realise that years later I would stand in the House which was instrumental in precipitating his political demise.

I joined the Australian Democrats in 1982, after much consideration and thought about the merits of each political party and its policies. What attracted me to the Australian Democrats was the desire to engage in long term policy-making, not constrained by the politics of the next election which seemed to govern so much government decision-making. The Democrats offered new ideas, internal processes which enabled members to have a direct say in policy and party matters, and were concerned about the long term harmful effects of environmental degradation caused by the abuse of the world's natural resources. By way of example, the Democrats were one of the first political parties in Australia to start talking seriously about ozone depletion and greenhouse gases in the early 1980s. We were then branded as merchants of doom, but now these words are part of the political lexicon. Ten years on I remain convinced that the Democrats are the only party concerned about social justice, economic equity and the environment as a total policy package.

My work as an archaeologist and historian, intimately concerned with the interpretation of the past, has taught me a valuable lesson now that my work involves planning for the future--that is, that human kind has failed to learn lessons from its history. We have failed to learn from the lessons of Reaganomics and Thatcherism, where supply-side economic policies in those countries have resulted in increased national indebtedness, great social dislocation, even wider gaps between rich and poor and the removal of the state from the provision of essential social services, resulting in a situation where money talks more than social need. That is not my vision for Australia.

I want to see Australia become a more socially just, compassionate, yet economically competitive country where the long term value of preserving our environment and the need to foster creative thinking, innovation and productivity are recognised. Strong steps must be taken to restructure our industrial base by value-adding exports and encouraging innovative environmentally friendly business ventures. Increased productivity on the shop floor must be matched by creative thinking in boardrooms across Australia to develop new products, replace imports and create export markets.

The question of developing solar energy and other renewable energy sources must be urgently addressed by our businesses, researchers and by this Parliament. Long term job opportunities must be created and individual freedoms respected. If we want to become the clever country, education must not be regarded as a burgeoning budget item, but rather as an investment in our country's future, in our young people, and in the intellectual and scientific base of business.

Finally, Australia must stand up for human rights on the international stage. However, we must also become the committed country--a country committed to ensuring that the weak are protected against the strong, that appropriate safety nets prevent poverty traps and that real steps are taken to improve the health, education and employment conditions of Aboriginal people.

It also occurred to me at an early age that, in order to effect any real changes in our society, politics and parliament was the place to be. Real power resides here between elections--not with any number of pressure groups which try to effect changes outside this place. Whilst it is to the Government that people look for vision and direction, it is to the Parliament that voters turn to ensure adequate debate and scrutiny of policy, legislation and government activity. This will perhaps become more critical as Australians are faced with the need to make radical changes in the 1990s, changes in work relationships, expectations and economic focus.

The 1980s have seen a spectacular revival in the power of parliaments across Australia. No longer are they institutions captive to the will of the Executive and the old major parties, but increasingly they are real forums of debate, reform and public scrutiny. It is worth noting that State governments in four States--Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia and New South Wales--govern in the minority and, contrary to what honourable senators on both sides of the chamber would have us believe, this need not necessarily be a recipe for instability. If instability, as defined by the major parties, simply means an inability of the Executive to force through all sorts of iniquitous legislation with as little scrutiny and debate as possible, then more power to the parliaments, I say.

Majority governments in a Westminster system are in effect elected dictatorships which can force through legislation by gagging debate, crunching the numbers and often ignoring public opinion. I am proud that the Australian Democrats have been at the forefront of restoring some measure of primacy to the Parliament by ensuring that it is not a rubber stamp for the government of the day.

As we move increasingly into a deregulatory economic climate, where market forces are given the status of holy writ, the responsibility will be on us as law-makers to ensure equality of outcomes and that the so-called invisible hand of marketplace supremacy does not result in wider gaps between rich and poor, city and rural dwellers and skilled and unskilled workers. Government and the Parliament, as instruments of the people, will have a vital role in ensuring that economic benefits are more evenly distributed and that the powerless--be they workers, businesses, Aboriginal people or struggling families--are not exploited by those in more advantageous positions or more powerful economic relationships.

For example, I bring to this place very real concerns about the position of women as we move into the 1990s. It is true that over the last 15 years we have witnessed enormous changes in the role of women in society. Improvements and real gains have been made in the recognition of the contribution women make to the economic and social fabric of Australia. The participation rate of women in higher education, for example, has increased from 40.6 per cent in 1985 to 52.7 per cent in 1991. More women occupy management positions and more women are to be found in non-traditional jobs. However, for many professional women the glass ceiling syndrome in promotion and advancement opportunities remains a real issue, no matter how often or how many people say that the glass ceiling does not exist. I have suffered the humiliation of watching my male colleagues in previous jobs receive more pay than I did for exactly the same work.

It remains a fact that women still earn only 81 per cent of male average weekly earnings, that only 12 per cent of women hold full time managerial jobs and that women are significantly under-represented in academia. One only has to look around us to see that only 19 of 76 senators or roughly 25 per cent of senators in this place are women. I am extremely pleased to have been the means by which the Australian Democrats can now claim to be the first party with a majority female representation in the Federal Parliament.

Much remains to be done in changing community and employer attitudes and even the attitudes of women. The particular concern I raise here is the potential impact of a fully deregulated labour market on female workers. Labour market reform not only is a key economic issue, but also will be one of the key social justice issues of the 1990s. Labour market reform is not a matter of changing some inanimate regulation or business function but involves people--the millions of working Australians whose lives will be directly affected by the changes proposed by all parties in this place. The term `labour market flexibility' must not result in simply giving employers the flexibility to pay their workers less. The potential for big winners and big losers is enormous.

I believe that women could potentially suffer most in a deregulated labour market, especially those women whose command of English is poor. Women are poorly represented by trade unions, traditionally the mouthpiece for representing worker concerns and advocating their rights; indeed, only 34.6 per cent of women belong to a trade union. Women lack industrial muscle and currently must rely on the actions of strong unions, representing male workers largely, to negotiate wages and conditions which trickle down through union awards. In a deregulated labour market, women could stand to lose the most if left on their own without the protection of a trade union or the Industrial Relations Commission to oversight enterprise bargaining agreements.

In concluding, I would like to congratulate our new Leader, Senator John Coulter, and our new Deputy Leader, Senator Meg Lees. I look forward to working with them and my colleagues. I also thank my new husband, Mr Armon Hicks, and my parents, Val and Helen Sowada, for their assistance and support.

However, I pay tribute to those women, my friends, who have been a special encouragement and inspiration over the years--not only my mother but also Janine Haines; Senator Vicki Bourne; Dr Lisa Giddy, a former Egyptologist at the University of Sydney; Margaret Clark at the Institute of Administration; Debra Stirling from Coles-Myer; and Elisabeth Kirkby, member of the Legislative Council and State Leader of the Democrats in New South Wales. Elisabeth has the distinction of celebrating her tenth year in parliament this month. If I can humbly follow her model of honesty, integrity and professionalism during my time in this place, I will have served my country and my Party well.

As mentioned earlier, being an archaeologist places time and history in sharp perspective, especially one's own place in the scheme of things. Last year, whilst I was living amongst the tombs of ancient Egypt on the necropolis of Saqqara, it was my habit to stroll across the desert and watch the sunset at the end of a day's work. One balmy evening, I sat upon a mound of sand and looked across to the great pyramids of Giza, sitting large and heavy on the distant horizon as they have done for the last four and a half thousand years.

I then glanced down and saw scattered around my feet in the dusty sand fragments of bone bleached to a hard, dry whiteness by the harsh desert sun. On examination, I discovered that these fragments represented pieces of a human skull, probably dating several thousand years BC--a skull which had once enclosed a brain, thoughts, hopes, aspirations and emotions just like yours and mine. One's own sense of self-importance is rapidly deflated when confronted with the stark reality of human history in one's hand. We are all but part of the passing parade of humanity.

It is a tremendous opportunity to help craft, shape and influence a more socially just and equitable future for Australians living in the here and now, so help me God. I thank you, Mr President, and honourable senators for your attention and indulgence. I am under no illusions about my role in this place or the task ahead. But, like Lawrence of Arabia, I act out my dream with open eyes. Thank you.
Honourable senators--Hear, hear!

We are very glad that Senator Sowada overcame the time of her Puberty Blues and decided to bring the further experience of her various occupations and interests to the work of this chamber and its committees. As I say, I congratulate Senator Sowada on her maiden speech and move:

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I also congratulate Senator Sowada on her first speech in this chamber. The Bill that is now before us is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill has three particular objectives, all of which the Opposition supports. The specific provisions of the clauses of the Bill are set out in just three pages, and they are not at all controversial. They are all positive adjustments to student assistance that I am sure every member of this Senate sees as timely and appropriate and will be supporting. However, the wider context of the Government's education policies does arouse a great deal of controversy and opposition because of the damage that these policies are doing to education at all levels in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I refer to the Bill specifically. The Bill's three purposes are: firstly, to extend Austudy to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands; secondly, to deal with changes to the living allowances for the English as a second language scheme as this scheme is being integrated into the social security payments system; thirdly, to insert an appropriation clause into the Student Assistance Act to replace the existing appropriation mechanism through the regular appropriation Bills.

As I have said, the Opposition supports these three objectives, and there is no need for me to elaborate. To save time, I will just make a number of general remarks about the failures of the Government in its broad education policies and administration. They are, in fact, a disaster and it is about time the Ministers of this Government took some heed of the criticisms that have been expressed over many years now without any positive response, not only in this chamber but also in the other chamber.

In fact, this amending legislation is put before us by the Government at a time when its policies on education are even more controversial than they have ever been in the eyes of the Australian public and are increasingly deserving of the Senate's criticism and serious concern. Australia is being let down by this Government in every area of education policy and administration.

In education debates in the Senate for all these many years now, Opposition senators, including myself, have spelt out the Opposition's objections to what Mr Dawkins and Mr Baldwin have been doing to Australian education. I briefly summarise those objections again now: the centralising of decision-making; the restricting of important decisions to the Ministers and the bureaucracy here in Canberra when most of the expertise lies out in the cities of Australia where our education institutions are well informed by actual practitioners--not just those who are teaching and researching in our higher education institutions, TAFE colleges or in our schools, but the actual students enrolled who have a direct vested interest to ensure that they are getting valuable education provision, and the families who are supporting those students to a large extent. There are many mature students, of course, who are self-supporting.

We in the Opposition have been trying to encourage the Government to see that, given the rationalisations, the improvements that have been made, particularly through the 1970s, in the provision of education in Australia, and I will even include the words `standardisation' and `rationalisation', and with some degree of amalgamation of resources--given these broad achievements in the Karmel years--the time has now long come, and it has been here for at least the last five years, to give back to education institutions genuine power over the conduct of their own programs. In the past this has been called autonomy--what I call autonomy. The framework is already stable and well informed. Instead of keeping decision-making in Canberra with Ministers and bureaucrats, give the power of decision, give the initiatives to those who can be genuinely creative; that is, those who are the providers and users of our education institutions.

Boringly, we see the centralisation that is sapping creativity, I believe, in the education processes of Australia. We also see the imposition of restrictions through education institutions being required to negotiate their own profiles behind closed doors with public servants who are bound and limited by their Minister's guidance.

We have also seen too often the forced amalgamation of institutions for which there is not a voluntary approach and for which there is not any justified educational gain. There has been a complacent tolerance of a failing student support scheme that is full of inequities. There has been the maladministration of the education export sector, a matter which was last evening debated in this chamber and for which on behalf of the Opposition I set out the sorry record of this Government in letting down overseas students and letting down this important export industry, especially to the countries in our region in Asia.

The list of the inadequacies of this Government in the field of education goes on and on. But because this is directly a Bill about student assistance I will concentrate the remainder of my remarks on trying to urge the Government to act in the way that the Senate has already resolved with regard to one aspect of student assistance; that is, to make it possible for those in rural Australia who are suffering from the rural crisis to have the same opportunity to be enrolled in education institutions as all other Australians.
Opposition senators--Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —-I hear the encouragement of those honourable senators on this side of the chamber who are from the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Democrats. We on this side have passed a resolution calling upon this Government to act to take special hardship provisions to enable families in rural Australia to have their children continue in education, rather than pull them out of it because they cannot afford to continue to pay for university and other courses of education. This Government has let them down. It has not responded to the needs of rural Australia and has not responded to a resolution of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me remind the Government of Australia, through this debate, that its action in this area is not considered to be action by this chamber or by rural Australia. The hardship that has been felt by so many people in rural areas should be well known to every senator. Whilst I see only two Government senators present, I think many of even the Government senators are aware of the crisis in rural Australia. They are embarrassed; they run away and hide because of the failure of their own Government to act in this area.

I remind the Senate of an excellent speech made by my colleague Senator Olsen during the adjournment debate last night in which he addressed his remarks to a report about education in country areas. He spoke of the scandal of one per cent of rural Australian children gaining education outcomes, when a much greater percentage of Australians from every other part of Australia are gaining educational advantages.

Of any community group within Australia, I would say that Aboriginal Australians have the worst education outcome. I am glad to say that there have been some very substantial improvements in this area in the last 15 years and they are, in fact, now consolidating into a much improved situation, but Aborigines still have the worst statistics.

The second worst statistics belong to that 7 per cent of Australians who live in rural areas. If people live in the bush or in a country town they must be aware that they are likely to find that their children will have a lower education outcome and, for many, that means a lower opportunity to develop their skills and abilities. The Opposition has been complaining to the Government about this for years and we want to see some response. In particular, we want to see an amendment to the student assistance regulations and to the way in which this Government's student assistance schemes are being administered so that students from country areas will be able at least to continue the access to education they had before the rural crisis.

This distress inevitably has its effect on those from rural backgrounds who wish to continue their education. Their financial circumstances, and those of their families, can be so grave as to make it impossible for them to continue with their education. No Australian should be denied educational opportunities simply for financial reasons, and we should respond with sensitivity to the plight of the rural community at this time.

That is why the Opposition on 19 May--that is five or six months ago--moved a motion, which the Senate passed, calling on the Government to respond to the crisis affecting rural families and to take the initiative in providing hardship provisions to help those who are being denied Austudy because of the assets test. The Student Assistance Act, which we are amending by this legislation, is the basis for Austudy payments; that is, the living allowance payments and some other allowances--such as travel to and from home several times a year--which are made to more than one-third of all of our higher education students and in fact to senior secondary students.

Many rural families are being denied these payments because of an assets test. We did not introduce the assets test, but we believe that there is some principled reason for having an appropriately drawn and administered assets test for Austudy. We in the Opposition are opposed to an assets test for isolated children, but we have accepted the principle that there be some appropriately drawn assets test for Austudy. But when, in the present rural crisis, this assets test becomes a barrier to what we expected to be the normal access by students of those families to enrolment in education, we have to be sensitive and we have to do something about it.

If eligibility for Austudy were based upon an income test, then there is no way that rural families would not be receiving it because their incomes are zero, or negative, in very many cases. But they are left holding an asset that might be worth $500,000, or even more--the assets test actually starts at $750,000 or thereabouts. Yet a family with that degree of asset is not getting an income and is being denied the living allowance support that its student children would receive if the family were being assessed on income alone.

At the time I moved the motion in the Senate and on subsequent occasions I described the details of the hardship that was being caused and we called for a prompt and positive response from the Government. But what did we get? We did not get a prompt response. In fact, we did not get a positive response. The quarter measure that the Government limply offered last August in the Budget assisted only a small minority of those who were cut out. What about the majority? What about the other families and the students who are being denied an equal opportunity to education in Australia?

I do not wish to embarrass public servants who no doubt have wrung their hands and burned the midnight oil trying to work out the best way to formulate the appropriate response to this question. I know that public servants do not have responsibility for policy decisions; it is the responsibility of the Government, the Cabinet and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). From the lack of response, lack of any promptness and lack of any positive measures, we can see that it is a hard-hearted Cabinet, a hard-hearted Prime Minister and a hard-hearted Minister who may be cynically saying,`We haven't got any votes in the country; we won't spend our money helping these suffering Australian families'. How cynical! Perhaps, even more cynically, they are saying, `We are going to lose the next election no matter what happens. Let's not go through the struggle of trying to find the appropriate words to put in place'--through a Bill such as the one before us now, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill--`the hardship provisions for rural Australia which the Senate has called for'.

As I have said, the Government waited until the Budget to respond to this matter and, although the need for action had been urged by the Opposition for many months, it was a very weak and inadequate response. Decisions could have been made and announced much sooner when rural Australians were first feeling the pain. I think it is an illustration of the fact that the Government lacked political will.

The Budget decision is inadequate. Let me make it quite clear that the Opposition sees it as in no way fulfilling the resolution that the Senate adopted on 19 May. We immediately pointed this out in the Budget. Let me remind the Senate what my colleague Dr Kemp, the shadow Minister for education, said in his press release on 20 August:

Mr Dawkins' acceptance of the Opposition's initiative to introduce a hardship provision for Austudy recipients has failed to provide an adequate response to the problem. The provision does not go nearly far enough in offsetting the difficulties incurred by many students in metropolitan and rural areas in obtaining financial assistance.

The narrow application of the hardship provision will mean that only those who are destitute and are already leaving their farms, or whose parents receive a social security or veterans pension will be eligible for student assistance.
`This is completely inadequate . . .

Let me say it again: the Opposition sees the Government's failure as completely inadequate. I am only saying all this now in regard to student assistance because that is what is before the Senate chamber and we still want the Government to respond. The press release further states:

These are measures designed to enable the Government to appear to be doing something but in no way provide for the many students who desperately require Austudy and will not receive it under the Government's proposals,'. . .
It continues:

On the 19th of May 1991, the Coalition successfully moved a motion in the Senate that called on the Government to introduce equitable and fairer educational assistance for families who were forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds. This would involve assistance being made available on a case by case basis, to the many students and families that have been affected by the rural crises and economic recession.

Instead the Government has made hardship provisions available only to those who are completely destitute, are selling their farms and leaving the land. `This is too little too late,' Dr Kemp said today. `We cannot wait until students are completely destitute before they are able to receive financial assistance.'

I hope that the Government thinks again. Certainly that is what I and other members of the Opposition urge should happen. I hope that we will be gracious enough to acknowledge that when the Government makes some decision in the coming weeks.

I also hope that the Government will respond to all the inadequacies of the Austudy scheme. The Opposition has pointed them out and has made a commitment that, when in office, we will properly address them. Our policy at the last election included these words:

Austudy has been bedevilled by administrative deficiencies and suffers from continuing allegations of unfairness in the award of benefits. In particular, the new assets test on Austudy and the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme recipients has introduced hardship for some Australian families. So Austudy needs review and reform. SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the criticisms made by the coalition speaker on education when the debate on this Bill took place in the other place.
