DEBATE.TITLE: FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION BILL 1991FISHERIES MANAGEMENT BILL 1991FISHING LEVY BILL 1991STATUTORY FISHING RIGHTS CHARGE BILL 1991FOREIGN FISHING LICENCES LEVY BILL 1991FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) BILL 1991FISHERIES LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Fishing, whether it is commercial or recreational, is important to Australia. Very few people appear to understand the size and the operation of the fishing industry. It is large commercially, has a high investment, is a substantial employer and, most importantly, is diverse; it is all around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been to most but not all the fishing ports. I always concentrate upon the value of the industry and the people that are involved in it. They are real people, they are working people, who are producing something for the national good. I believe that more recognition than they normally get is due to them. There are millions of Australians living close to the sea who have a fundamental interest in doing one of the basic things in life--that is, going out and trying to catch themselves a meal. Those people also cannot be ignored at a time like this.

I welcome this opportunity for changes to be made to the administration of the fishing industry; they are long overdue. I will not deal with the details of the Fisheries Administration Bill and six related Bills. We have been over them ad nauseam within the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. However, there is much to be said about the industry at large and the purpose and implementation of the legislation that I wish to put on the record because it is important.

Historically, the management of the fishing industry and of fishing generally has been inadequate. It must be borne in mind that Australian waters generally are poor in the production of fish. They are not as well endowed with the appropriate currents, upwellings and so on that make for good fishing in other parts of the world. Australia's opportunity is much less.

There are other problems: we have a long coastline; many large and small ports; six States and a Territory to administer; isolation; and poor coordination and communication. Over a period of years Australian fishermen have not adequately protected the stock. They talk and offer protection but the result is there to see: there are more people fishing harder than the stock can provide. With fishermen and people who are after a natural resource, there is always a certain amount of `them versus us' in competing for the stock and in considering whether the administration can be beaten. Beating the system is very much part of the fishing game.

Looking back over recent periods, the fishing skills and training have advanced considerably. For instance, the Australian Maritime College has done a lot towards improving fishing techniques and the training of participants. The boats and technology are much better than they used to be. New supreme materials are used in nets and winches. There are new sonar systems. All of these things aid the fisherman and not the fish.

The levels and management of stock have declined alarmingly and are still declining. That decline must be reversed. In 1976 the real slaughter of the immature southern blue fin tuna became fashionable in Australia. It followed the closure of whaling in the west and the fishermen concerned turned to the southern blue fin tuna. The prawn industry then collapsed in the Gulf of Carpentaria and that collapse continued with scallops, gemfish, lobsters, prawns and sharks--maybe the orange roughy will be next--all heading in the same downward direction.

It was in this light that the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce produced the report entitled, Development of the Australian Fishing Industry. I thought it was appropriate to look back and see what we were talking about 10 years ago. The Committee, which I had the honour of chairing 10 years ago, made 10 recommendations. I will not read them all, but I will read a portion of three of them. The first one, in part, reads:

. . . develop and implement a national fisheries policy defining the objectives and strategy for the rational utilisation of Australia's fisheries resources and devise clear guidelines for the management and conservation of those resources.
It goes on:

The Minister for Primary Industry direct his Department to establish formal procedures for implementing the Government's long-term policy objectives and priorities for the development of Australia's fisheries resources and the Australian fishing industry.
The second recommendation states:
The Minister for Primary Industry, in developing the national fisheries policy and guidelines for the management and conservation of fisheries resources, give particular attention to:
(i) the immediate and long-term effects of various management measures on the biological and economic status of established fisheries;

(ii) the effects of the implementation in management regimes in one fishery on the biological and economic stability of neighbouring fisheries and on other fisheries resources, and the need for a multi-species approach to management. . .
The third recommendation states:
The Minister for Primary Industry direct his Department to accord priority to the revision, consolidation and replacement of the Fisheries Act 1952.

Here we are 10 years later, in 1991, and what have we learnt? It is a great shame that we have taken so long to do so little. We are suffering from exactly the same problems as we did 10 years ago, but the problems are much bigger as a result of not doing something about them. The new organisation has a big job ahead of it. We have seen a decade of decline. The stocks are much worse; the capitalisation is much greater; and the catastrophe in trying to clean it up will be massive.

We only have to look at the south-east trawl situation. Three or four or five years ago a stop could have and should have been put to the situation that was developing. The $40m buy back situation in the Gulf of Carpentaria should not have been necessary. I also question the part that the fishermen's own organisation, NFIC, has played, if any. I also look at the management committees and wonder whether they have been successful. The consideration of the resource is paramount. The question of sustainable yield is essential and must rise above all others.

We often hear excuses for the over fishing that takes place. All people have a reason as to why they should catch a few more fish or why they should ignore the technical advice that would indicate that there is a problem. This applies to the professional fisherman and it equally applies to the recreational fisherman. The recreational fisherman who goes out in the name of sport and catches fish that he will not be able to use--it will be wasted--is just as guilty as the professional who may catch a boatload of, say, orange roughy and puts half of them on the tip. Every fish caught should be utilised. Conservative estimates must be the basis of the planning, whatever is done.

There is no easy answer to the huge over capacity of effort that we are now confronted with. There are certainly hundreds and probably thousands too many commercial boats around the Australian coast. At the same time, of course, the number of pleasure craft is increasing. The people on a considerable proportion of those craft also catch fish. Then we have the impact of beach fishing, rock fishing and spear fishing on many of the inner coastal areas around Australia.

Whether fishing is recreational or professional, the catch is a common resource to all and the rules should apply to all and the costs must be shared equitably by all. Costs cover things such as licensing, surveillance, search and rescue. We must also consider the various support industries--the boats and the gear--and the tourism and all the other things that go with fishing. At this juncture there is no area that offers more room for further discussion than the question of dealing with professionals and the recreationals.

I often hear calls from fishermen, particularly those from outlying areas, to leave the industry alone. They do not want to be changed. They say that the administrators should just leave them alone so that they can continue on as they have and, in due course, they will be able to leave their fishing boats, their licences and so on to their sons to carry on after them. I always say to the fishermen that, like farmers, manufacturers or industry--people of all sorts--they are part of change whether they like it or not. They must be prepared for change and they must be able to deal with it as it comes.

In the meantime, still better scientific evidence is needed. We need more industry participation in discussions on the management and all things to do with fishing. There must be a much closer relationship between the industry and the new AFMA organisation than has existed in the past with the Fisheries Service. There has to be a much better and closer leadership from NFIC if it is going to remain part of the system. There particularly needs to be more operator participation in the discussions, in the meetings and in the communications generally. Until now, by any standards this has been totally inadequate.

There are problems and issues for consideration in many places. We have to look at the effect that aquaculture will have. In the meantime, we have to look at getting this offshore constitutional settlement finalised. We have to do something about the overlapping of the Commonwealth and State functions, to say nothing of the problems that the Government has created--we must do something about those--and the effects of the non-decisions that should have been made.

This legislation came through in various stages and the way it turned up is the worst I have ever seen. We started off with a handbook or policy statement called, `New Directions in Commonwealth Fisheries', which I was told at Estimates committee hearings took seven people a year and a half to produce. The legislation that followed took four people a year to produce. The first Bill arrived in the Parliament just before Christmas in 1990, with a promise that the balance of the legislation would be here in February 1991. In fact, it turned up just 25 days prior to the date it was planned to be implemented. When it was brought into the House of Representatives, honourable members were given 45 minutes to look at seven Bills and to pass them. It took 15 years of man time to produce this rubbish which, so far, has produced between 80 and 90 amendments, and that is after trying to jam it through with no discussion at all. Prior to getting the legislation, for three months I had been endeavouring to get information from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the officers, without any success.

The legislation as discussed was open-ended with employment problems and had no funding undertakings, no indications on the loss or retention of the rights that the fishermen may have and no information on the taxing measures, et cetera. Between March and June, in spite of considerable effort, we still had no undertakings. As I say, discussions with the officers concerned were fruitless. The industry at operator level was absolutely confused and the ground swell in that area grew and grew. The fishermen were told nothing. I entered into a situation of occasionally writing to any fishermen that I could find just to give them some information. I thank those who took the trouble to keep in touch and raise a lot of issues.

I was very disturbed that the relationships between the industry and the AFS, and the industry and NFIC were so poor. The NFIC officials had no idea of the reaction that was raised out in the field by its ordinary grassroots members. NFIC did not know what its members were saying or thinking. I do not believe that NFIC was seeking any information from its members, although the members in the field were seeking information. They were also seeking ways in which the legislation--or what they believed the legislation would produce--could be improved. All the time that I was getting hundreds of communications from ordinary fishermen, I was getting letters from officers of NFIC telling me that the legislation was okay, and would I please see to it that it was not held up and that it was passed as fast as possible.

We then had the late entry of the Industry Commission's draft report on cost recovery which confused the finalising of the Committee's contemplation. We also had the draft report from the ecologically sustainable development working group. As a result, the situation is still very far from being satisfactory. I thank the Minister for giving us an undertaking that, in view of all the confusion, he will refer the operation back to the Senate Committee in 12 months' time. I believe that there will be quite a bit to deal with then.

When dealing with fisheries legislation, we must take into account the fact that fishermen are individuals--very much so. That is one of the reasons why they are fishermen. Like many other people who are individually inclined, they do have a built-in anti-change factor. They would prefer to go along as they are rather than to change. In this particular case, as I have said, their organisational problem is quite considerable and their representation is always difficult. I find, when I am looking for one, that a good fisherman is usually at sea and seldom wants to go to meetings.

There are a lot of reasons why we should not be supporting the establishment of an AFMA structure. One of the main reasons revolves around the fact that I see it as producing a career structure for people who wish to work in the fishing environment. A problem within the Australian Fisheries Service, as a division of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, which is regularly reported to me is that fishermen who are trying to talk to somebody can seldom talk to the same person twice on any subject. It seems to them that there is a considerable turnaround of staff. Whether staff are moving in and out of the Service or whether they are just moving from desk to desk does not make any difference to somebody who is trying to get an answer. It is very annoying to find that the same person cannot be contacted twice.

I believe that AFMA will do a lot towards giving fishermen the opportunity to develop a closer relationship with the organisation that they see as being theirs. It will do a lot to break down the resistance to change and it should improve communications and simplify all the procedures. There are many things that have to be done in a departmental set-up which I trust will not need to be done under AFMA.

Mind you, there are still many problems. We have not really settled on the distribution of resources between fishermen. We have not determined the equity between the State and Federal jurisdictions. We still have many problems with the management of substantial fisheries. One of the big ones is the arrangement between the recreational and professional fishermen.

I would like to acknowledge the flexibility of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and the Minister in allowing the many improvements that we have been able to make to the legislation. At this stage, I cannot say that I like the legislation. I think that the Bills before us are confused and complicated. I am disappointed with their development and with the general lack of compatibility between the environmentalists and the industry that is so clearly reflected.

I congratulate Mr McColl on his appointment as the AFMA chairman. I wish him every success and express my support for him and hope that the resource and the fishermen will prosper under his administration.

In conclusion, the legislation aims to safeguard the resource, to secure the appropriate research funding and implementation, to simplify the management structures and to better administer the industry. I see no reason why it should not do that. I would like to thank all those ordinary back-bending fishermen from around Australia for their input, comment and concern and the good officers of the AFS who helped us to see this through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I begin my remarks on this package of fisheries Bills by picking up a point which Senator Archer made a few moments ago. The important function which the Senate plays in relation to the proper consideration of legislation is little realised.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Archer mentioned that this package of Bills was rammed through the House of Representatives in 45 minutes. He went on to point out that under our committee system this package has been sent to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. We have deliberated over a number of weeks. We have taken on board the draft report of the Industry Commission and the draft recommendations of the committee under the ESD process. We have independently, as a result of the recommendations from those other committees, made suggestions for amendments to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and to his Department, as a result of which we now have 80 amendments to this package of legislation.

It is about time that some members of the press gallery and journalists recognised that the real business of parliamentary democracy is now carried on in this chamber and not in the other place. This is the place where legislation such as this is given proper scrutiny and where amendments and improvements are made to legislation. This package of legislation--like several other packages of legislation, particularly in the area of social security with which we have dealt recently--is a very good example of the appropriate way with which legislation should be dealt.

Having said that, and having remarked that we now have 80 amendments to this legislation, I must tell the Senate that the Democrats will be opposing this package of legislation because, notwithstanding those 80 amendments, we still have a totally inadequate package of legislation. This is a very important area. We are dealing with a natural resource which has been woefully and abysmally mishandled but on which this country depends for a significant part of its protein intake.

We are also dealing with a resource which is part of the natural environment and which most recently has been shown to have considerable benefits in terms of human health by reason of the quality of the protein and the quality of the fats which fish contain. In almost every instance this resource has been overexploited and in many cases it is on the point of extinction; that is, there will be either a total wipe out or a situation will be reached where unless fisheries are closed for extended periods of time they will simply not sustain any reasonable level of exploitation for a very long period into the future.

All the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology have expressed grave concerns about the adequacy of this legislation. We have just heard Senator Archer repeat some of those concerns. I am aware that a number of people on both sides of this chamber have serious reservations as to whether this package of legislation can adequately address the very serious problems that we now face.

The Australian Fisheries Service tabled a report in September 1990. I would like to refer to table 3.1 from that report showing the status of Commonwealth, or jointly managed, commercial fisheries. This table refers to both the adequacy of the knowledge in relation to that resource and the level of exploitation in just some of the fisheries. In the northern prawn fishery it is thought that the knowledge is adequate but that the fishery is fully exploited and some is overexploited; in the Torres Strait prawn fishery the knowledge is adequate but it is fully exploited and some is overexploited; for scallops in the south-east fishery there is adequate knowledge but they are dangerously overexploited; and in the southern shark fishery there is adequate knowledge but the fishery is overexploited.

In that respect, I would point out that the South Australian Department of Fisheries has developed an excellent computer model which shows the level of exploitation, the level of the activity and the age structure of the population being exploited. This allows one to extrapolate forward the consequences of various management practices. This model indicates that the fishery should really be closed for at least 15 years if that fishery is to recover to a level which will sustain a meaningful level of exploitation from then on.

In the southern bluefin tuna fishery knowledge is good but it is dangerously overexploited. It shows that even in the face of good knowledge about the stock, its sexual maturity, the age structure, the migratory practices of the fish, their food habits and various other things, we have a stock which is dangerously overexploited. With regard to the jack mackerel fishery we have inadequate knowledge and uncertainty in relation to exploitation but it is probably fully exploited.

So we go on to the orange roughy fishery which was discovered in the 1980s. Against that we have inadequate knowledge and yet the present level is probably not sustainable. Since September 1990 it has become absolutely clear that that level of exploitation cannot be sustained and yet we have totally inadequate knowledge as to the nature of that fishery.

In relation to the adequacy of fish as an element in the diet of Australians, and bearing in mind the considerable benefits to Australians of eating fish, it would seem very unwise to continue to increase our population. I just say that by way of parenthesis because, necessarily, that would mean future generations of Australians will have less fish to eat per head of population, even if we were to turn this process around.

The Committee has considered this legislation and expressed very serious concerns in its report which was tabled this morning. I will just read a couple of paragraphs from the conclusions and recommendations section of the report:
The Committee wishes to express its unanimous dissatisfaction with the process which has led to the production of this report and the subsequent passage of the Fisheries legislation.

These Bills represent a fundamental change to the administration of Commonwealth fisheries. Yet, with the exception of the Administration Bill, the legislation was not introduced into the Parliament until 25 days before AFMA was originally due to become operative.

That is a totally unsatisfactory way for this Government to behave with respect to one of the most fundamental resources which, quite clearly for a number of years, has been grossly mismanaged and grossly overexploited. The Committee goes on:
The fact that the Committee has found it necessary to recommend over 70 amendments--
that in itself indicates something; the number is now 80 because the Government has continued to heap amendment upon amendment as the Committee was considering these Bills--

is a clear indication that the legislation was not sufficiently developed at the time of its original introduction. There were many unresolved questions about matters such as the objectives and functions of AFMA and associated organisations, allocation of resources for research and the cost of the proposals to industry.
The Committee report goes on making some very disparaging and damning remarks in relation to the way in which Government has handled this whole matter.

The Democrats concern, shared by many of the witnesses coming before the Committee, is about the dismal lack of recognition that resource management and ecosystem conservation should come first and industry management should follow. The package of legislation which is before us is really an industry management type of approach. Without a resource there will eventually be no industry. On present predictions there will be no fishing industry in this country in the very near future, particularly in relation to specific species.

The Industry Commission draft report, entitled Cost Recovery for Managing Fisheries which was presented to us--the author of that report came before us as a witness--recognised quite clearly the need to separate the two functions: firstly, the functions of managing a resource and managing an ecosystem in a sustainable way; and, secondly, the importance of managing a commercial industry which is based on the exploitation of that ecosystem. The Minister asked the Committee to take specifically into account that IC report.

In the recent past I have been extremely critical of the Industry Commission for not adequately taking into account proper environmental considerations, as it is charged to do under its legislation and for which it has a commissioner whose expertise is in the area of the environment. In relation to this particular report, I think the Industry Commission has done an excellent job. We were asked by the Minister to take into account its report. We have done that and, as a consequence, the Democrats believe that the Industry Commission recommendation that this package of legislation should not be accepted is the correct recommendation. We are adopting that and, as I say, we will be voting against this package of Bills.
An indication of just how badly fisheries have been managed in the past was summarised recently by Graeme O'Neill, the science writer for the Melbourne Age. His article states:

The shark boats now venturing out into Bass Strait have been taking younger and younger fish for the past decade. The catch sizes are perfectly legal, but the trend is dismaying. The southern shark fishery is on the brink of collapse from over-exploitation.

The collapse of the fishery may only be averted if the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry and Energy, which administers offshore fisheries, drastically reduces the number of shark-fishing licences and limits catch tonnages for the remaining vessels.

The evidence from the computer modelling in South Australia indicates that the most desirable course would be to close the fishery completely, perhaps for 15 or more years. Of course, that has very significant consequences for those who have invested heavily in boats and equipment to exploit that fishery. That example clearly underlines the difference between ecologically managing a resource and managing the industry which is based on the exploitation of that resource. Graeme O'Neill further states:

A similar crash is looming for the orange roughie, a deep-sea species that has been intensively fished for only half a decade. Scientists have recently discovered that most orange roughies in our restaurants are at least twice the age of the people eating them.

This species is well over 30 years of age before it reaches sexual maturity. On the discovery of that fishery, fishermen went out without any controls at all and grossly over-exploited it before there was any knowledge of the life cycle of the fish, the rate of their growth, the age of their sexual maturity and so on. The article continues:
Some were fingerlings when John Batman sailed over their spawning grounds in Bass Strait to found the city of Melbourne 150 years ago.
That indicates that we now know how slowly these fish grow. The article further states:

What is happening in Australia is part of a global trend. Fisheries are being subjected to enormous pressure from larger, more powerful boats, equipped with refrigeration to store their catch, and sonar to find it.

Technology has made the contest between hunter and hunted unequal. The imbalance became an obscenity in the 1980s with the advent of drift-netting in the open ocean. Thousands of lethal curtains of fine mesh, up to 70 kilometres long, drape the surface waters of the open ocean, enmeshing millions of fish without regard to their age or rarity, and drowning thousands of dolphins and whales.

We are, globally, in a situation where many nations are garnering the last fish out of the ocean. That situation is clearly not sustainable and it flies totally in the face of any concern at all for later generations of humans, let alone the species of fish and the whole ecology of which those fish are a part.
I refer to what the Industry Commission said in relation to this package of legislation. It had witnesses before it, as did the ISTC. The Industry Commission stated:
Fishermen complained that Commonwealth management was ineffectual, with most fisheries over-fished and all of the developed fisheries grossly over-capitalised.

Under conditions in which companies are desperately trying to recoup the investment of that capital, it is a very dangerous situation to put the control of those fisheries substantially in the hands of the people who have a financial inducement to regain their capital or at least generate a cash flow so that they can pay the interest on that investment.
The Industry Commission quoted Crutchfield's summary of the position in 1982--nine years ago--saying that it is still an apt description of Commonwealth fisheries management. The summary states:

Given all the time and all the splendid research that has gone into expanding our knowledge of the sea, its living resources, and the technical problems of harvesting them, the results are remarkably disappointing. The number of programmes that have actually succeeded in checking depletion of ocean fish stocks can be counted on the fingers of one hand. And those that have protected the stocks while providing some real improvement in earnings, stability of employment, and ability to withstand the usual economic jolts to which fisheries are subject can be counted by someone with no hands at all.

In other words, we have a dismal record in relation to the management of our fisheries. The question which must be asked is: will this legislation, which looks to the creation of an Australian Fisheries Management Authority, do any better? The Australian Democrats believe that it will not do any better and that it will divert attention from the need to set up quite different sorts of structures.
In its report, the Industry Commission, pointed, as I have done already, to precisely where that weakness is. It states:

Resource management is a fundamental weakness in current Commonwealth fisheries management. There has been a general reluctance to implement scientific advice where significant reductions in catches are the consequence.

In other words, when the management of the ecosystem--management of the fish stocks--from the scientific advice indicates a reduction in catches, if there is a significant commercial element in the control over the decision, the management body, in this case the Australian Fisheries Service, has been very loath to make that hard decision and, in many cases, has failed completely to take it. The Industry Commission goes on:

Recent policy statements have stressed the desirability of a conservative, ecosystem-wide approach to resource management. However, it is clear that this is not done at the moment. The Commission has seen little evidence that coherent resource management is undertaken by the Australian Fisheries Service except perhaps in Torres Strait.
It therefore makes the recommendation that:

Responsibility for marine resource management should lie with a multi-disciplinary expert body able to determine priorities and integrate scientific, economic, social and policy considerations, reporting to appropriate Ministers.

That is not what we see in this package of Bills. I have criticised the Industry Commission in the past but, in this respect, I believe that it has come down with an excellent report. We put aside its advice at our peril and at the peril of the fisheries which we are hoping to better manage. The Industry Commission continues:
The resource management body must have a brief wide enough to span all of these objectives and to deal with foreign and State Governments.
The operation of Australian fishermen overseas is something that was ignored in the original package of Bills.

It is therefore not an appropriate function for the body conceived as primarily concerned with a particular objective or sector, such as commercial fishing or conservation. None of the Commonwealth's fisheries management agencies current or proposed meet these criteria.

That is what the Industry Commission has said. I turn to the evidence given to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology by Dr Young of the CSIRO. The CSIRO division of fisheries has had a particular and very effective research interest in looking at life cycles of varies species of fish and making recommendations in relation to the sustainability of certain levels of fishing. Dr Young said:
I therefore doubt that AFMA will have at its disposal either the amount of funds or the continuity of funds to commission the management related research needed to effectively manage the fisheries.

Dr Young points to another defect to which Senator Archer referred earlier. Leaving aside for the moment the question of the confusion over the objectives of AFMA and its membership, Dr Young is expressing grave concern as to whether the structure is such that the funds would be made available.

I recall in-committee discussions over this very point. It was stressed that if the funds were to come to some extent from industry, those fisheries which were being better managed and which were generating a cash flow would be capable of also being levied so that they could provide funds for their better management. However, those fisheries that were being overexploited, particularly those that might be closed down altogether, would generate zero funds. Yet they would be precisely the fisheries that would need the funding to learn how better to manage them, supposing that they could be brought back to some sustainable population size which was capable of some sustainable exploitation. Dr Young draws the conclusion:

So in the absence of any specific purpose funds for this research in the present Bills, I believe there is a serious deficiency in research funding for natural resource assessment, and the proposed Bills neither recognise the need for this type of research nor identify the agency to set priorities and commission the work. It is my view that an adequately funded resource management body such as that proposed by the Industry Commission would be an appropriate body to determine such research priorities and also to commission the work.

Clearly, Dr Young from CSIRO supports those recommendations of the Industry Commission. In relation to research, I would reflect briefly on a question which Senator Archer asked Dr Young during that hearing. He asked how well researched the waters were around Australia. Senator Archer will recall Dr Young's reply:
If we compare them with Europe, North America and the North Atlantic, we are probably 80 years behind them. They are very poorly researched.

Not only have we a situation that is extremely dangerous in terms of looking forward but we have not done very well in the past. We are building a house of cards on the inadequacy of our previous research.

The Industry, Science and Technology Committee heard calls for a far greater focus on fisheries resource management--from such diverse sources as the Industry Commission, CSIRO Division of Fisheries, public sector union delegates and the Australian Fisheries Service itself.

The Government responded with no fewer than 80 amendments, 21 of which are responses to those originally proposed by the Democrats. I stress that very early on we put forward a large number of amendments. Leaving all that aside, we still only put forward those amendments in an attempt to improve this totally inadequate legislation. We believe that the amendments have improved it, but that it is still inadequate. The amendments make significant changes that are consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development, but they do not go far enough.

While we are willing to cooperate with the Government to help it improve its own legislation, we must point out that the Government has ignored our request to take more time to get the matter right. Instead, the Government prefers to push these Bills through at the earliest opportunity. What has happened today with the collapse of one Bill and the earlier debate of this legislation is a further speeding up of this very important package of legislation. Amendments were being drafted and altered shortly before the Committee considered them. Often amendments were given to us that had not been properly considered. It was a messy, breathless process. What was needed was a total rethink, and it is still needed.

The Industry Commission has still to come forward with its final report. The ESD process, which the Government itself has created, has not yet come forward with a final report. The Democrats are not convinced that the proposal which the Committee has made and which has been accepted by the Minister to the effect that there will be a review in 12 months time is the best way to go.

The basic philosophy in these Bills has been around for a long time. Senator Archer outlined just how long it took to get these Bills in place. We suspect that if there is a review which is started even before 12 months--and it takes a similar length of time to modify the legislation as this package of legislation has taken--by that time it is very likely that many of the important fisheries in this country will be totally beyond the point where they will sustain in anything like the near future, say in the next 100 years, any reasonable level of exploitation. That would be a disaster for the people of this country, for the fish stocks and for the ecosystems of which they are a part.

It is a reflection on this Government that, having committed itself, at least in principle and in name, to ecologically sustainable development, when actually faced with legislation it is turning its back on such development. This package of legislation puts in place a program for the commercial management of the exploitation of a natural resource. Despite all the amendments--80 of them--that the Minister has accepted, it is still basically a commercial management process that we are addressing here. It ignores the fundamental importance of managing a natural resource in a sustainable way. That is what this Parliament should be attempting to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We should be debating here this afternoon not so much the content of this package of fisheries Bills but the reasons why we have before us and why we have been forced to deal with such an inadequate and incompetent package of legislation. As a member of the Industry, Science and Technology Committee, I have been part of the struggle to salvage something workable and acceptable from a package of legislation cobbled together, for whatever reason, by a special unit which had had no experience in preparing these regulatory Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: To that extent, I acknowledge the enormous work put in by the Committee. The result that we have before us is in a far better form than otherwise would have been the case, but it is still legislation with which I have some difficulty. I commend Committee members for the way in which they worked assiduously to look at the flaws in the legislation that had been presented to us and to try to work through a series of amendments to improve the legislation. I single out my colleague Senator Archer specifically for the amount of work he did and the way in which he was prepared and willing to negotiate with the Minister and the departmental officers to work through this maze. Senator Archer deserves commendation for the amount of extraordinary effort that he put in to achieve that objective.

I have no idea, nor do I wish to know, what departmental power struggles led to what we have before us. I simply say that I hope the Department has learned a valuable lesson about the far-reaching results, not to mention extra work for the Parliament, that such an incompetent and incomplete piece of legislation can cause. After months of work, weeks of evidence and a mountain of research, we find ourselves at a point of no return. As Senator Coulter said, the Bill, which was originally scheduled for Thursday, has come on at short notice today, which is typical of the whole procedure. Had it not been for the Opposition pressing the point earlier in the piece, since the Australian Democrats supported the Government in the initial stages, we might not have been debating, as we are today, a piece of legislation that has rightly been heavily amended.

There is no doubt that the industry needs legislation, and it needs it now. Even with the 70-odd or 80-odd amendments that we have as part of this package, I still harbour some grave doubts about the measures before us. I suppose that the only saving grace of the whole exercise is that we have extracted from the Minister a promise that the legislation will be reviewed again by the Committee in 12 months time. That state of affairs leaves a somewhat near enough is good enough situation. In fact, in evidence put before the Committee, it was suggested to us that we should put this legislation through without the amendments and then patch it up afterwards. That was the evidence presented to the Committee as to the course of action we should take.

Does anyone in this chamber need to be reminded that that is not what is expected of us? I think not. We are charged with the responsibility of ensuring that legislation, when it passes through this chamber, is the best legislation possible for the needs of those in the community whom it will affect. That is our job; that is our responsibility.

Considering that the lifetime of an Act of parliament is some 10 years and that in that time it affects the lives and livelihoods of countless thousands of people, is it any wonder that concern is being expressed by speakers in the debate at the situation that has occurred over recent months with this legislation? Whilst I have doubts about the net effects of the package before us, I however trust that it will be effective, that it will meet the objectives that have been laid down, that it will be made to work and that we will have the opportunity over the course of the next 12 months to monitor very carefully the implementation of this legislation.

While it is one of the worst examples of what I would describe as legislative ineptitude that I have encountered in some 12 years in politics, it is surely symptomatic of the increasing number of bandaid type Bills that the Senate finds before it. Unfortunately, this is no longer the rare, exceptional case. I am uncomfortable, even after the exhaustive resuscitation of this package by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, about letting loose this package on a ailing, $1 billion industry. We are talking about a very significant industry within this country. Frankly, we have been cornered because of the necessity to get some elements of the package operational urgently, and I accept that some elements need to be put in place at the earliest opportunity. If it were not for that promise of another appraisal after 12 months, I would not find myself able to support the package today. I do so reluctantly.

We need fisheries legislation--it is long overdue--and we all recognise that the fishing industry is fighting a losing battle, in some instances against the environment and in other instances against its own greed. We know that there are severe problems in many Commonwealth fisheries and that, with a few exceptions, they are overcapitalised and in some instances depleted. We know that the fishing industry has often been unprepared to accept scientific evidence that does not necessarily agree with its point of view in the short term.

I well understand that because I had experience in the Tonkin Government as Minister of Fisheries. I well understand the implications of trying to advise a fishery and people involved in that fishery that, if they continued to take the resource at current levels, they would have no resource within a set period of time; in other words, they wanted to ignore reality for the short term. I understand the difficulties of having to get that scientific message through to people in some sections of the fishing industry.

The South Australian Act introduced in 1981-82 put in place management of the various fisheries throughout that State. It has developed some role models over the course of the last 10 years, which I will refer to in a moment. There ought to be the example that is followed in many instances of putting in place the management plan of the fisheries that we are talking about.

Of course, the fishing industry needs good management and it needs it urgently. I do not find that this package, with its complex edifice of power, provides it. So the Australian Fisheries Management Authority replaces the Minister as the maker of day to day administration and policy decisions. We still have huge unknowns and confusion about where the roles of AFMA and departmental officers will overlap. In the confusion of this package, perhaps they will fail to act in time. It is hoped that at the 12-month review we can have some frank discussions on the short term outcomes of some of those structures, which I think are vague.

The prime purpose of these Bills is to achieve optimum utilisation of our resources while at the same time preventing over-exploitation. In that respect, I commend the proposal to endorse the banning of driftnet fishing, a practice which could bring about the total destruction of the world's marine resources if left unchecked. It is interesting and commendable to note overseas experience, where a number of countries, including the United States, are moving towards the banning of driftnet fishing. It is a move in the right direction. It is a positive aspect of the package of Bills that we have before us.

It should also be noted that the package is being rushed through before two other major studies on fishery management have been completed. Previous speakers have made reference to that, in particular Senator Coulter. That appears to me to be illogical. One report that we await is the Industry Commission's report on cost recovery for managing fisheries, an exceptionally important inquiry into cost sharing arrangements between the Government and fishermen. It should have been considered. It is an important review. Put simply, it appears to me that the legislation replaces bad and complex management with confusion and is delivered without all the relevant facts to hand.

The report of the Industry Commission, which has been referred to, surfacing during the course of this legislation through the committee stage, was another important factor. Many important issues which should have been addressed are not addressed. An example of that is that the Bills do not take the opportunity to regulate activities of our fishing crews around the world, yet the Law of the Sea Convention provides us with an obligation to do so.

I think Senator Coulter referred to the need to balance development of the fishing industry, exploitation and sustainability. Marine scientists are urging drastic reductions in catches from Australian fisheries. According to the South Australian Department's model, if the southern shark fishery was closed down today, it would take 15 years for a sustainable level to return in that fishery. That is almost frightening when the implications for that one fishery are considered. It is frightening when we consider the response to a question from Senator Archer in the committee stage that, in terms of available scientific data upon which to base management plans, we are decades behind countries overseas.

Whilst I have said much against the way in which this legislation was drawn and presented to us and about the inadequacies of departmental and industry management, I want to take this opportunity to refer to what I think are some well managed fisheries, which were also the subject of evidence put before the Committee. I referred just a moment ago to one such fishery.

For many years I have praised the efforts of the Spencer Gulf and West Coast Fishermen's Association in South Australia, which could well be regarded as a role model of how a fishery could and should be run. I hasten to add that I well understand that no two fisheries are the same. One example from Spencer Gulf in South Australia may perhaps not have direct relevance to one in the Gulf of Carpentaria because of the number of boats in the particular fishery and a whole range of competing factors and pressures that are applied, but I hasten to add that, in this fishery, people recognised a depleting resource, were prepared to accept the scientific evidence, were prepared to sit down and put in place a management plan and were prepared to accept the disciplines that a management plan applies to a fishery. Today that fishery and the fishermen in it are reaping the reward, with cost effective fishing in terms of the cost of going out for the catch and the return that they are getting.

While much debate on this legislation has referred to the environmental danger of overfishing and the depletion of stocks, the Spencer Gulf and West Coast Fishermen's Association has had in place management strategies which have ensured that it minimise the risk of stock depletion through overfishing by developing appropriate harvesting objectives. It opens and closes the fishery at short notice--at a day's notice. If the size of the stock the fishermen are catching is down, the fishery is closed for one, two, three or four weeks, whatever the case might be, until the stocks are of a size that ensures that there is continuing stock available. The fishermen do not go in and harvest and harvest until the point is reached where they are not getting a return for the cost of going out in that particular fishery. It has also set clear goals to optimise the value of the catch in order to maintain stable economic returns in the fishery. The fishermen have been prepared, as I said before, to abide by the discipline of that fishery.

I well remember that once in 1982 when the management plan was put in place a skipper of a particular prawn boat breached the management plan. As Minister at that time, I was asked by the fishery--the fishermen, the association--to apply a severe penalty. It was applied with the support of the association for the breach of that management plan. We took the boat out of the fishery for something like a month in what was the prime prawn catching season. It is interesting to note that since that time no prawn boat has breached the fishery management plan because all the fishermen recognise the bottom line dollar cost of the breach of that management plan. The disciplines can work where there is a coordinated effort and a willingness to understand scientific evidence, to participate in the establishment of the management plans and then make sure those management plans work. They can only work if discipline is applied.

In the 1990-91 annual report of the Spencer Gulf and West Coast Fishermen's Association it is interesting to note that the fishermen themselves have allocated $170,000 for prawns statistics and development of a database. They have also allocated $40,000 towards reproductive research. As well as committing their association to a two-year research program into juvenile prawns, they are developing an electronic black box automatic surveillance system.

While there are many fisheries urgently requiring more efficient management techniques, it is clear that there are some, such as the Spencer Gulf and West Coast Fishermen's Association, which are operating effectively and responsibly. I suggest to honourable senators that the reason is not only the leadership of the association which recognised that long term planning required management structures such as this, but also that the fishermen in the fishery started to reap the dollar rewards of the management plans. As we see, they are now ploughing dollars back into the fishery for research for the development of databases for this ongoing process so that we get to understand the fishery well. It is fisheries such as this that the Government should be consulting to avoid some of the pitfalls that can come through the establishment of management structures.

One of the most important components in the management of a fishery is the industry and mutual cooperation between fishermen, biologists, managers and governments. It is of paramount importance that there is a clear understanding and participation in the development of those management plans. This has been exemplified by the fishery that I have referred to which, for the last eight years, has provided vessels and funds for research with the department. It has played an active role in research management and cooperated with the appropriate government bodies at a State and Commonwealth level.

I use this example deliberately to highlight what I consider to be the ineptitude displayed by this Government in providing incorrectly drafted legislation designed to make major changes to an industry that recognises there is room for improvement and that sections of the industry are facing extinction. But, at the same time, the industry has areas which have operated and are operating efficiently and profitably. With such a solid base for improving administration and efficiency within the industry, this Government has demonstrated that in those two areas alone it has been incompetent in the way it has handled this matter and brought it before this Parliament.

The responsibility surely is that of the Minister and the Government of the day to ensure that the legislation which is presented to this Parliament, guillotined after an hour's debate in the House of Representatives, pushed through as a matter of urgency, introduced within days of the so-called start-up date, to get it right. They should recognise that they have a basic and fundamental responsibility to get it right before the legislation is introduced. A government that fails to at least take those initial steps is a government that is failing the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to make a few short remarks on this package of Bills. I too want to register my protest at the way the Bills were handled today. We were told at only about 2 o'clock today that the package of Bills was coming on. We were also told that the Bills would not be distributed until 5 o'clock tonight. That does not give honourable senators who are interested in this particular industry the time to put in a well-researched contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: We find these Bills before the House today with 79 amendments. These Bills have been scrutinised by the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, then reconsidered by the Committee following a request by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). Also, we were asked to consider the Industry Commission's draft report into the cost recovery of management of fisheries. Today, after months of effort--particularly by Senator Archer, who has put in a marathon effort on the Bills, Senator Coulter, Senator Olsen and also honourable senators from the Government side--the Bill was thrust on us with two hours allowed for preparation.

The Fisheries Management Bill introduces plans of management of the Commonwealth fisheries, the new rights called statutory fishing rights and fishing permits. The Bill also establishes an offence for taking certain species and bans driftnet fishing in the Australian fishing zone. I certainly concur with that. I think it is a very positive step and one that most young people would certainly be supportive of. The new concept introduces statutory fishing rights and will allow access rights to manage fisheries either on the terms of the certificate or, if not, indefinitely. The concept of fishing permits will apply to developing fisheries, even without a plan of management from AFMA.

The Fishing Levy Bill provides for levies to be collected to cover the cost of administering fisheries and collecting research and development levies as well as other contributions for specific fishing matters. The other Bills in the package cover payments of levies by foreign fishing boats in the Australian fishing zone and the allocation of statutory fishing rights in the new fisheries by means of auction, tender or ballot where the plan of management provides this. As well, the Bills cover the transfer of administration to the new authority from the Australian Fisheries Service and the establishment of fishing industry research and development corporations under the Primary Industry and Energy Research and Development Act. This has been a long time coming.

To this point, the fishermen have had to pay their fees to a government department, but now those fees will be paid to a statutory authority. The fishermen will pay their way and they will have a say in the running of that authority. That is to be welcomed. My Party represents primary industry and it has always believed that those people who grow, hunt or fish have the right to decide the future of their industries. The setting up of the authority by these Bills certainly gives fishermen that right, and I welcome these Bills for that reason.

The fishing industry is an important industry for Australia. It is worth over $1 billion in exports--although a lot of imports are coming in too. Billions of dollars would come, I imagine, from the crayfish and the prawns which are exported. The industry is worth more than that when one considers the 4.5 million recreational fisherman who take pleasure in fishing. The industry also creates around 8,000 jobs and it makes a massive contribution to the economy through tourism.

These Bills give the industry a management system that is both cost efficient and flexible and one which provides for appropriate scientific and environmental input. This is where Senator Coulter and I have a disagreement. We have spent many hours together on the Committee and I know that he is concerned that the scientific input is not sufficient. Therefore, he will not be joining the Government and the Opposition in supporting these Bills.

Both the Opposition and the Government recognise that it is important that the 600 to 800 levy payers in the Commonwealth fishery have the right to run their own industry. Whilst we have some doubts about the legislation and some regrets that it has not been handled in a different way, that is why both the Opposition and the Government believe it is important to get the Bills through.

The industry has been seeking a cost efficient structure; one that is financially accountable to the industry. The Government's system got a little out of control when it ended up with 110 fishing officers--public servants--being supported by 800 levy payers. As the industry rationalised and increased, the system could not continue as it was because there were more and more public servants being supported by fewer and fewer fishermen.

Under AFMA, the industry will now be more cost efficient, with important decisions like the setting of the total allowable catch being made by the board with a large input by scientists. I think that will stave off the fears of the amateur fishermen who have expressed some concern. The eco-management will be balanced, and it is hoped this will all be able to be a part of AFMA's management of the industry. This should be assured by the authority's objective of developing and implementing fishing-specific management plans. It will also set sustainable catch quotas, grant ongoing and temporary access to fishing and fish resources, monitor activities of fishermen, and monitor the performance of each fishery where necessary by restructuring programs.

The present state of the fishing industry is depressed, as Senator Olsen correctly pointed out to the Senate. The northern prawn fishing fleet will be halved by 1993, with a buy-back program to be paid for by levies placed on the remaining fishermen. The southern shark fishery has been reduced from 3,000 tonnes to 800 tonnes, which has been achieved by methods such as net reduction on each boat. The gemfish quota has been abolished upon scientific recommendation; there are quotas on orange roughy and tuna; and bans will also be placed on at least two other species. That is the environment--of reduced returns and major adjustments--which faces the fishing industry at the moment. All over Australia fishermen are competing against a lot of odds. The ecosystems and the breeding grounds are being broken down and used for tourist development, which is having an effect on fisheries. There has been further destruction of the fishing habitat, and that is also having an effect.

I support the Bills because I believe the fishing industry requires an authority to run that industry, and this set of legislation allows that to occur. It is very difficult to draft legislation for the fishing industry; it is an incomplete and imprecise industry. It is not as though one plants, grows and reaps; it is a hunting industry where one goes out and takes a chance and battles the elements. For that reason, it is difficult to legislate for. There will be a revision of the Bills in 12 months time, which is also supported by the industry. I have been told, `Let us get in there; there will be mistakes and we will correct those mistakes, but we have to start somewhere. We have to start with some legislation and we will improve on it as we go through'.

It is against that background that both the Government and the Opposition are supporting these Bills. In 12 months time we will again review the legislation and if people--whether they be professional fishermen, environmentalists or recreational fishermen--wish to have some input their concerns will be heard. But let us take the first step of introducing these Bills today and launching the fishing industry into a new era. I offer AFMA my good wishes and wish the fishermen all the success that this new statutory authority will afford them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —-I support the Fisheries Administration Bill 1991 and six related Bills. I say at the outset that the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology had very useful discussions during the process of examining the Bills and certain very useful amendments were provided. I have never been a great admirer of the Industry Commission, but I pay tribute to Dr Gentle who represented the Commission in giving information to our Committee. I commence my remarks by quoting from the Commission's report entitled Cost Recovery for Managing Fisheries, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Crutchfield's summary of the position in 1982 is still an apt description of Commonwealth fisheries management.

Given all the time and splendid research that has gone into expanding our knowledge of the sea, its living resources, and the technical problems of harvesting them, the results are remarkably disappointing. The number of programmes that have actually succeeded in checking depletion of ocean fish stocks can be counted on the fingers of one hand. And those that have protected the stocks while providing some real improvement in earnings, stability of employment, and ability to withstand the usual economic jolts to which fisheries are subject can be counted by someone with no hands at all.
It is against that background that the legislation was introduced, and it is now before this chamber in its amended form.

This legislation is not just about looking at the way in which fisheries operate now, but also about the way we protect them for future generations. We have no right as a community to deplete those fisheries in such a way that there would be nothing left for other generations. Obviously AFMA, which will be brought into existence as a result of these Bills, will have a great responsibility. It will have to look at the efficiency of the way it catches fish, maintain conditions where there will be sustainable catches and move away from having people rush in with over-capitalisation and a dog-eat-dog attitude. I guess that this attitude was epitomised by one fisherman who was quoted in the press in Queensland some years ago as saying, `If there is one fish out there, I want to be the person to catch it'.

I understand from evidence given by the fishermen that their understanding is now much greater. They are more enlightened and have a different attitude towards the notion of the sustainable catch and looking after the fisheries. They have complained for some time about the fact that they were contributing considerable amounts of money to fisheries management, and that they were not getting the sorts of returns they expected in terms of the quality and quantity of that management provision. With AFMA instituted through this legislation, they will now have that input as individuals to their own organisations and people will be elected to that body. Their organisations will also have input.

With those rights to do that will go the obligation to maintain the fisheries, as I mentioned before, and to look at the whole marine ecology. That will not only ensure that there is not the old attitude of considering only whether we conserve or sustain a particular type of fish, but also show how that type of fish or other marine animal fits into the total ecology. Sometimes, depleting one particular species will automatically naturally deplete or eliminate other species.

I do not think that the legislation is perfect. I will certainly be watching very keenly in the next 12 months to see how those fishermen perform and what they do. As a member of the Committee, it is my view that it should be looking at what is happening much earlier than at the end of 12 months. If the fishermen make mistakes and do not give the sort of quality management that they expect of others, they can expect some really harsh criticism from us and some very forceful changes from the Government. At least it will give them the opportunity to make good on what they say is needed in the fisheries.

I commend the legislation. I wanted to make those points so that people in the industry did not think that now they have the legislation they want, in the main, nobody will be watching to make sure that they carry out those responsibilities they fought so much to get.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to thank those honourable senators who participated in the second reading debate. They were substantially the same senators who participated in the extensive committee process, in which I played a small part at some time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fisheries Administration Bill 1990 and six related Bills that we are dealing with today in the second reading debate are, by their very nature, complex and far reaching. On the one hand, the legislation has to deal with the very important issue of the conservation of a community owned resource and recognise the needs of the commercial fishing industry and those who rely on it for their livelihood, and balance that with the interests of those who engage in fishing for recreation, which is a very large number of Australians amongst whom I am not to be counted.

The legislation has been drafted to give effect to a fisheries policy statement first released by the Government at the end of 1989. As will be only too familiar to the participants in the debate, the key elements concern detailed objectives which place particular emphasis on the principles of ecologically sustainable development; the establishment of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority; the creation of the Fishing Industry Policy Council; enhanced emphasis on plans of management as a fisheries management tool; the creation of specific fishing concessions and formal recognition of statutory fishing rights; the enhanced role and recognition of management advisory committees; and new and improved administration and funding arrangements for fisheries' R&, which is very important.

We have had the opportunity through the Senate committee process and the winter recess to further strengthen the legislation. I believe that this detailed consultation process has addressed all the major concerns of the legislation and, as a consequence, the legislation has been improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It has addressed them, but not met them.

—-We are all entitled to our view. We will see which is the majority view in just a moment. This has resulted in a considerable number of amendments being considered and agreed to. The amendments affect three of the seven Bills, namely, the Fisheries Administration Bill 1990, the Fisheries Management Bill 1991 and the Fisheries Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The explicit recognition of ecologically sustainable development is particularly significant in a policy sense. I welcome those changes. The changes made cover three main areas--more explicit enunciation of ecologically sustainable development principles in the objectives of the legislation; the provision of temporary order facilities; and the extension of plans of management to cover, where appropriate, recreational fishing.

The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology spent a lot of time dealing with this legislation. Many honourable senators obviously put in a number of hours on their own research in addition to that and in consultation with the industry. Many came to it with a background of interest and expertise. It was one example of the Senate committee process making a substantial contribution. On behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), I thank the Committee for its consideration.

I should mention before I conclude, in the interests of being comprehensive about the amendments, that there were also a number of drafting and other amendments and related consequential changes, thus meaning a large body of amendments, but the three principles I outlined go to the essence of the changes which the amendments bring about.

As has already been mentioned--and this is an important point to make in conclusion--the Minister has given an undertaking that the operation of this legislation will be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in 12 months time. I take it that is because the members of the Committee feel they have not given fisheries enough attention recently and they would like to give it a bit more time. I understand that view.
