SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--
The Bill will amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 to:

(a) require that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal be given prior written notice of acquisitions of interests which could contravene that Act, including a contravention that would arise if the interests of associates were aggregated;

(b) increase the ABT's powers to gather information on the ownership and control arrangements for media outlets to assist the Tribunal in determining whether the ownership and control rules of the Act have been, or are likely to be, contravened; and

(c) strengthen the powers of the Federal Court to protect licensees and other companies and to prevent, or prevent the continuation of, contraventions of the ownership and control rules, either on an interim basis to enable proposed acquisitions of interests to be appropriately investigated or on a more permanent basis.

The changes will not affect the limits currently provided for under the Act. The Government has no wish to interfere in arrangements which comply with the letter and the spirit of the Act. The changes simply strengthen the capacity of the ABT to gather information and ensure that acquisitions which do not comply with the spirit and letter of the Act can be prevented if there are reasonable grounds to suspect that the limits will be contravened.

Persons acquiring media interests in good faith have no reason to fear these amendments, but it is an entirely different case for anyone seeking to acquire real control over media outlets in contravention of the Act. The Government will not stand by and allow the Act to be ignored or circumvented.

The amendments will make it more difficult for people to evade the legitimate requirements of the Act. I believe they should, therefore, receive universal support from within this Parliament and from all Australians concerned with the independence of our media from improper influences.
Passing to the details of the Bill, I refer to clauses 5 and 6, which introduce the prior notice requirement that will apply to the majority of acquisitions.

Naturally prior notice will not be required of persons who are unaware of an acquisition, which is quite possible given the tracing requirements of the Act. Those people will be required to give notice when they become aware of the acquisition.

The notification requirements will only apply to interests which could give rise to a contravention of the ownership and control rules of the Act, which include the foreign ownership and cross media rules. It will not apply to the vast range of acquisitions which will not have that effect. But, for the first time, the obligation to notify the ABT will relate to the acquisition of interests, rather than to the more limited concept of a transaction. Persons who will acquire interests by way of gift or through the operation of law will now have to notify the ABT, rather than wait for their interests to be discovered by other means.

Associate relationships will also be the basis of a requirement to notify the ABT if the aggregated interests of the associates could amount to a contravention of the Act. Those relationships may be evidence of persons acting in concert, but they will certainly not, taken on their own, be conclusive.

The aim of the notification requirements, and of the related information gathering powers, is not to remove the fundamental duty on the ABT to establish that a contravention of the Act has occurred. People will not be required to prove themselves innocent under the Broadcasting Act, any more than they are under other Acts. The aim of the requirements is simply to enable the ABT to gather information in a timely fashion which will enable it to make decisions on an informed basis and, if appropriate, to discharge its onus of proof before the Federal Court.

Because the definition of associates in the Bill is relevant only to a notification requirement, it has been cast widely. However, the Government has no wish to intrude more than is necessary into the legitimate activities of individuals, even that limited class of persons who have interests which fall within the notification requirements. Consequently, the ABT will have the power, by notice published in the Gazette, to exclude certain classes of people. The ABT will be able to exercise this power either in relation to particular inquiries or generally and the Government expects it to use this power to the maximum appropriate extent.

However, the ABT will not be able to negate the policy of the amendments by use of this power. They can only exercise it in relation to interests not likely to contribute to contraventions of the ownership and control rules and any determination they make will be a disallowable instrument; to be tabled and capable of disallowance by either House of the Parliament.

Associate relationships, and evidence gathered as a result of the notification requirements or of the strengthened information gathering powers, will be evidence of the matters to which they relate and will be considered by the ABT in exercising any of its powers under the ownership and control part of the Act, in accordance with proposed sections 90HB and 92EB.

The strengthened information gathering powers under section 89X (clause 4) will combine with the already extensive powers of the ABT to inquire into acquisitions, and proposed acquisitions, of interests to give the ABT the muscle to discover the reality of arrangements often obscured within a maze of legal minutiae. An important change in the section 89X powers lies in the reduction of the minimum time in which a person must respond to an ABT request for information from 21 days to 7 days, or less if the ABT considers that reasonable. This is essential to enable the ABT to react before acquisitions are completed, at least by applying for interim orders from the Federal Court. However, it does not allow the ABT to abuse its power. Under administrative law principles, the ABT must act reasonably, and I expect that it would be rare for a requirement to supply information in the shorter periods envisaged to be considered reasonable unless there is an urgent need for a decision or court application.
Clause 3 will introduce new confidentiality requirements in relation to information about prospective acquisitions to protect the interests of individuals during ABT investigations.

Clause 9 strengthens the powers of the Federal Court to make orders. The scope of those orders will now extend to any contravention, or possible contravention, of the ownership and control rules and to actions or things likely to affect the ability of licensees to comply with their licence conditions or to provide the licensed service or choose programming. The orders may be made on application of the ABT and may be either interim or permanent.

Interim orders may be sought either in their own right as applications for orders of an interim nature under subsection 92P (1) or (2) of the Act as proposed to be amended, or under subsection 92P (6) of the Act as an adjunct to an application for permanent relief under subsection 92P (1) or (2). Naturally, it will be up to the Court to determine whether an interim order is warranted. It will weigh all the circumstances and, I am sure, will act if there are reasonable grounds for doing so, whether in support of an application for permanent orders or in support of an ABT inquiry.

The proposed power of the Federal Court to protect licensees and other companies will be similar to current powers of the ABT under section 92M, but will be able to be made at any time, even before the transaction.
There will be no requirement for the Federal Court to wait until a contravention or proposed contravention becomes a breach of the Act.

The exercise of this extended range of powers by the Federal Court would be expensive and necessarily public. Persons wishing to acquire interests will probably prefer to avoid this. In such cases, it would be prudent for those persons to approach the Tribunal as soon as possible to discuss potential problems. The Tribunal is able to examine proposals and, if satisfied that there are no real causes for concern, can inform those persons of that fact, thus allowing them to proceed with the acquisition in full confidence. The Tribunal's provisional clearance, which I hope will become a normal feature of transactions involving media interests, does not require legislation. It is simply an incident of its functions.

However, to facilitate this function, and to ensure that conditions can be agreed between parties and the ABT, the Bill includes provision for the ABT to accept undertakings under proposed section 92NA. If the ABT accepts that those undertakings are adequate, there will be no need for the ABT to seek Federal Court orders that might prevent the acquisition. But the Federal Court will also be given powers under section 92P to make orders to enforce, or prevent a breach of, those undertakings.

I commend the Bill as an appropriate means of ensuring that the ABT can act to investigate media acquisitions that might threaten the public interest without the unwarranted and draconian step of casting the onus on the purchaser to prove innocent intent. We must never forget that it is for the ABT to establish that there may be contraventions of the Act.

I expect that the main effect of this Bill will be apparent in the limited number of times the powers of the ABT and Court are used. I feel sure that purchasers and ABT alike will be anxious to sort out any potential problems without the need to resort to those powers, and I think that will be a great improvement on the current arrangements.

But the powers will be there if needed. And I believe they will ensure that the Broadcasting Act can be applied appropriately and in a timely fashion until the Government's more wide reaching review of broadcasting regulation is in place.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Financial Impact

The Bill is expected to have no significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. The greater efficiency with which the ABT will be able to identify matters requiring exhaustive investigation as a result of the prior notification requirement should offset the cost of monitoring those notifications and the potential to avoid blatant contraventions and the expensive process of trying to rectify contraventions through ABT inquiry could result in savings.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CARRIAGE OF GOODS BY SEA BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill now be read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1991 replaces the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1990 which was withdrawn after concerns were raised by the legal profession, insurers, shippers and carriers. One wonders whether the Government is in control of its own legislative program, considering the problems it is having with its legislation and rushing it through, as appears obvious from the previous Bills we have dealt with. This necessitates that they be looked at again at an early stage. I wonder whether that is the situation with this Bill which was brought to the fore last year but was withdrawn after concerns were raised.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to update the rules regarding the responsibilities and liabilities of those who carry goods by sea and those who consign them. It seeks to incorporate amendments to the current international convention, the Hague Rules, to bring the procedures up to current day practical standards in Australian law.

A second part of the Bill seeks to introduce into Australian legislation, but not yet proclaim, a more recent international convention than the one provided for in the Hague Rules. This convention sets out the rules known as the Hamburg Rules. It was the most recent convention and meeting on the carriage of goods by sea. It places a greater liability on the carrier. The carrier's liability is also extended to include the time that cargo is on the wharf. These rules, unlike the Hague Rules, would apply to intrastate trade.

In considering this Bill and all of its ramifications, the Liberal and National parties have consulted very widely with a large number of people who are involved in the carriage of goods by sea. We have spoken with such broad based groups as the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Chamber of Shipping, the Mining Industry Council, the ANL, the Australian National Maritime Association, the Peak Shippers Association, the Shipping Users Group, the Wheat Board, the Wool Corporation, Conaust, various solicitors who have interests in these matters, the Grains Council, the Insurance Council of Australia, the Law Council, the National Farmers Federation, stevedores and shipping companies. In looking at this Bill, and the Hague Visby Rules and the Hamburg Rules that are all the subject of this Bill, the Liberal and National parties have consulted widely. I pay tribute to the shadow Minister for Land Transport, Mr Sharp, for his work and his broad consultation and also for the work done by his office on this Bill.

The current Australian arrangements regarding the liability for cargo carried by sea are based upon the Hague Rules, an international convention agreed to in 1924, which are embodied in the Sea-Carriage of Goods Act of 1924. The termination of the Hague Rules is now outdated. For example, valuations are in terms of the gold standard and have been amended to reflect developments in international finance by the adoption, for example, of the modern International Monetary Fund currency unit--the special drawing right. The Hague Rules were also drawn up before the development of containerisation and cannot accommodate the modern practice of aggregating many smaller packages in one container which, under the old rules, rates as only one package.

The amendments to the Hague Rules which this Bill embraces would bring Australian law into conformity with modern international practice, as reflected in the Visby and SDR Protocols to the Hague Rules. The Hamburg Rules provided for in the Hamburg Convention of 1978, as well as defining the limits of liability, also substantially increase the liability of carriers for loss of or damage to cargo. They extend liability to cover the time that cargo is on the wharf, in addition to the time that it is in a vessel, that is, for the time that the carrier has taken charge of the cargo.

The Hamburg Rules have not yet come into force. Twenty ratifications are required for this and to date only 19 ratifications have been lodged, although I understand that the twentieth--that of Zambia--is rumoured to be imminent. The Visby and SDR Protocols to the Hague Rules are not contentious in themselves. They bring the Hague Rules into line with modern developments and practices that were not in place and not relevant when the rules were first introduced in 1924. However, shippers, owners and consigners of cargo are concerned that the process of change in the liability regime will stop with these updates, leaving them with imbalances in liability between the consigner and the carrier that in their view exist under the current regime.

Shippers see their interests as better served by a new set of maritime laws that were being developed even as the SDR amendments to the Hague Rules were being made. They see their interests better served by the Hamburg Rules. As well as defining more precisely the limits of liability, these rules focus on the liability of the carrier, with a far more exacting regime in that regard. The benefits argued by shippers are that since they know the exact limits of liability and since its coverage is wider than under the Hague Rules, they are able to determine their insurance requirements according to the residual risk rather than take out cover against undefined limitation of the carrier's responsibility. A problem arises in that none of the states that have ratified the Hamburg Rules are what we might call like countries or countries with which Australia trades a lot or which have the same sort of trading culture that Australia has. That is, I might say, with the exception of the Federal Republic of Germany which in fact hosted the conference at which the Hamburg Rules were obviously adopted.

So far, support has been confined mainly to lesser developed countries, although some countries, for example Canada, have shown interest in the development of Australia's position on the adoption of the Hamburg Rules. Bureaucratic obstacles, uncertainty about the commercial impact of the rules, and political commercial conflict between established maritime countries and developing maritime countries have all been canvassed as reasons for lack of support.

The Bill provides for acceptance of the Hamburg Rules once the appropriate time has been reached for adherence to them by Australia. This would, of necessity, be after their entry into force, that is, one year after the twentieth country has ratified the Hamburg Rules. They would then be implemented by Australia by proclamation, if this legislation is passed, at a time to be determined by the government of the day and without need for further recourse to Parliament.

The Bill does not specify what criteria would trigger the proclamation. As there was some concern about this, the Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure for investigation of this and other issues. At that hearing, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Brown) expressed strong objection to including prescriptive criteria in the Bill on the grounds that trying to define an appropriate spectrum of trading countries could not take into account changing trade circumstances and would cause unnecessarily complicated provisions to be drafted and an attempt made to have them included in the Bill.

The Minister has said that it was important that it be done at a time that was suited to Australia's interests. We in the Liberal Party, the National Party and also the Australian Democrats agree that we would have liked to enshrine that in some sort of legislation, but the drafting of it became very difficult because it was trying to pre-empt or trying to guess now what might be the appropriate set of guidelines to consider in three years time. The Committee went along with the Minister's argument but on the understanding that he will give a specific undertaking that the section of the Bill dealing with the Hamburg Rules will not be proclaimed until it is in Australia's commercial interests so to do. That will be when our major trading partners have also agreed and when it is appropriate for Australia.

The Minister also agreed that he would give an undertaking to have comprehensive consultations with the industry and shippers prior to proclamation taking place. That was the result of the discussions on the Bill by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I must say that there was broad acceptance among the Government, the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats of what needs to be done. At the time of speaking we have not yet resolved a form of words which will put into effect what we have agreed upon.

I have three amendments to move in the committee stage. As I see it, they are the proper way to put into effect what has been agreed upon at the Senate Standing Committee's hearings into the matter. As I say, until now there has been no resolution. I will speak to and move the amendments at the appropriate time. The Standing Committee and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills were concerned at the open-endedness of the arrangements proposed by the Government for the Hamburg Rules. The Government wanted us to agree with the Bill at this stage but not proclaim it until it suited Australia. To a certain extent everyone is in agreement with that. However, it could mean that legislation passed now could drift on for five, 10, 15 or 35 years without ever being proclaimed. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was particularly concerned that there should be some limit to the time during which that piece of legislation could sit on the statute books without being proclaimed.

By way of amendment, we have proposed that if nothing is done within three years, if there has not been some resolution--I hope that the Minister and the Australian Democrats might just listen to this--that section of the Bill about the introduction of the Hamburg Rules will be repealed. The amendment goes on to say that will be done unless the Parliament or the Government does one of two things: either resolves that we as a parliament introduce and make effective the Hamburg Rules or, alternatively, both Houses

of parliament resolve to give it another three years. In that way the legislation has to come back to the Parliament and the Parliament will have the carriage of the Bill; it will ensure that parliament does not lose control of it and parliament can then decide, firstly, to start it straight away or, secondly, to give the Government another three years to deal with the matter. That is eminently sensible.

The Minister is concerned that if nothing happens the Bill will be repealed. There is also some concern amongst the Democrats that that might be the case. The Minister might try to say that it should be the case that if nothing is done within three years the legislation will automatically commence within three years. It would seem to be inappropriate that a Bill with the consequences of the Hamburg Rules could be introduced within three years simply by the effluxion of time. That seems to be the wrong way to introduce legislation and to make legislation effective. It is my submission that it is far better to have the legislation repealed unless something is done, rather than--as the Government proposes--to have it start unless something is done.

I might also add that the Minister may say that we will provide that the legislation starts in three years unless something is done, but if the Government does not like it at the time, it can move to have it repealed. If that happens and the situation in parliament is the same then as it is today, the Senate may well decide that the Bill should be repealed. The Bill would then go to the lower House where the government of the day which has the numbers would not decide that. The Senate will be saying that the legislation should be repealed and the lower House will be saying that it should not be repealed. Therefore, nothing can happen because it requires both Houses of parliament to agree.

In the eventuality that the Government's proposed amendment succeeds, the Bill will have commenced. The legislation would be introduced even though this independent chamber of the Parliament has decided that it should not be. What we are trying to achieve is best achieved by saying, `Look, it is repealed; but if both Houses of parliament then decide that it should be commenced, it can go ahead or if both Houses of parliament decide that it should get another three years, it will go ahead'. Having the automatic repeal provision ensures that the Government brings the legislation to the attention of the Parliament. It makes sure that the Parliament then has the opportunity to consider the situation as it applies at that particular day. The Bill then stays within the control of the Parliament.

The concern of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was that this legislation should not just be passed today and possibly proclaimed at any time between now and anywhere up to 35 years time. By having an automatic repeal provision that the legislation can be introduced straight away or it can be given another three years would seem to me to be the best way of ensuring what all parties--including the Government, the Opposition, the Democrats, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the Standing Committee--want. It is my submission that that is the best way to achieve it. No doubt, we will talk further about that when the Bill comes to the committee stage.

The Government has stated that there will be no costs, revenues or savings to the Government arising from the Bill. This does ignore any longer term tax revenue implications resulting from the transfer of insurance writing offshore that might result from any liability transfers to carriers. I might add that only 4 per cent of Australian cargo trade is carried in Australian ships. The Insurance Council of Australia Ltd has estimated that the value of this lost insurance business could be as high as $60m per year. In general, both shippers and carriers are in favour of the adoption of the first part of the Bill; that is, the Hague Rules and the Visby Protocol. The legal dispute that surrounded the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1990, as to whether it would achieve the desired result, has been settled to the satisfaction of the industry, shippers and the legal fraternity.

Several shippers and their representatives have expressed concern that the issue of liability for damage to and loss of cargo should not end with the Hague Rules and the Visby Protocol. However, the Government argues that the concern of shippers for a clearer definition of the distribution of liability is met by the Hamburg Rules as their stated wish is for a more equitable distribution. Shippers generally endorse this view, although some qualify their support with the proviso that it should be at such a time when there is international acceptance of the Hamburg Convention, particularly amongst Australia's trading partners. Neither the Bill nor the explanatory memorandum indicates just what would constitute international acceptance of the Hamburg Rules. In our consultations no-one has been able to suggest a benchmark. That is the problem I mentioned before which precludes us from trying to include something in the legislation to address that in detail.

The explanatory memorandum does indicate that taking into account the international acceptance of the Rules and domestic interest would trigger the proclamation. The Bill makes no provision for the means by which the government of the day would be expected to gauge and determine acceptance by industry and the community, although this was indicated as a condition for the proclamation in the departmental briefing.

Under these circumstances the reasons for tying a substantive matter in the first part of the Bill, dealing with the Hague Rules and the Visby Protocol, to the second part of the Bill, dealing with the Hamburg Rules, are not clear. It would have been the hope of the Liberal and National parties that this was divided into two separate Bills. That was spoken about by the relevant shadow Minister's office with the Minister's office. Apparently there could be no agreement reached and the Opposition is not prepared to move to split the legislation into two Bills.

I want to place on the record that the Opposition's preferred position would have been to have the Hague Rules and the Visby Protocol in one piece of legislation and the Hamburg Rules in another piece of legislation. We have had reservations about the wisdom of the linkage which does not allow discretion to accept one or the other while reserving judgment on or rejecting the other.

As I have mentioned, the Minister has given undertakings to set out clearly in his speech the need for general acceptance of the Hamburg Rules by our trading partners before the proclamation is made, to include a commitment that it will be introduced only when it is in Australia's interests to do so and, further, that the legislation will not be proclaimed until Australian industry and users have been consulted. Whilst the Minister has given those undertakings, the Senate will also note when my amendments are moved that we have also included those undertakings as part of my amendments. It is not that we do not accept the Minister's undertakings. On the contrary, they can go into the Bill without any difficulty. One of the amendments we are proposing reads:
A proclamation must not be made under this section--
that is relating to the Hamburg Rules--
until the Minister has consulted with representatives of shippers, cargo owners, carriers and shipowners, being representatives nominated by those groups.

A particular result is not required from those consultations, but it does impose upon the Government at least the obligation to go and talk to them. Even if the industry says no, the Government is not bound by that, but we wanted to make sure that the Government did at least consult.

As I have mentioned, the absence of a sunset date was also a matter of concern for the Liberal and National parties and for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. That matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee. We have reached agreement on it, although we are having some difficulty in getting the proper words to put into the legislation to reflect the agreements that were reached. I will deal with that matter further in the Committee of the Whole.

In the few minutes left to me, I will make reference to another matter, which does not relate directly to the Bill before us on the Hague Rules, the Visby Protocol or the Hamburg Rules but is relevant to the legislation in so far as it affects the waterfront. Of course, one carries goods by sea and they are put through the waterfront. I have had for some time a concern about the waterfront reform process in the part of Australia I come from--that is, the north Queensland area--and particularly in relation to the Cairns port.

Cairns has been typical of the Government's disastrous record on waterfront reform. When the media focus was on the port of Cairns it all got a bit hot for the Minister, and a provisional agreement was stitched up by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, with the approval of the Minister, which incorporated a deal to cut the port labour force from 23 to 10. That should have been done 12 months previously when the John Burke shipping company collapsed and left the port with twice the amount of labour on the port that was required.

That deal did almost nothing to redress most of the rorts and inefficiencies which have plagued that particular port, and many ports, for years. The deal, rather belatedly, cut the work force from 23 to 10. Users of the port are still saying that 10 is twice the number of people required. This provisional agreement, which seems to have been stitched up in somewhat of a hurry, does not show any progress on the issue of double-headers before supplementary labour is required.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What has this got to do with the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill?
—-To get goods carried by sea, one has got to move them through a port. I explained that five minutes ago. It is a pity that the Minister was not listening.
—-It is totally irrelevant.
—-I know the Minister is very sensitive about the waterfront reform industry, because it is falling down around his ears and he has not resigned, as he promised he would.

—-Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: with the greatest respect, this Bill deals with insurance arrangements covering the cargo of ships. It has got nothing whatever to do with waterfront issues in the port of Cairns. On the question of relevancy, I would ask you to bring Senator Macdonald to order.

—-I would ask Senator Macdonald and all honourable senators in this debate to relate their remarks to the Bill. As I interpreted the introduction of this last point by Senator Macdonald, he was seeking to relate it to the matters he had earlier discussed. I would ask him to bear in mind in the last few minutes of his speech that he should relate the remarks he is making about the waterfront to the Bill.

—-Certainly. The question of insurance, carriage of goods and liability for goods, whether they be on or off the wharf, is directly relevant to this Bill. In fact, as the Minister well knows, that is what it is all about.
—-Only if they are on the ships.

—-But if goods get onto the Cairns wharf, one finds that they go missing or they get damaged, and that involves insurance. All sorts of rorts are going on while trying to load goods. All those things--containerisation and how goods are packed--are very relevant to these rules and are exactly what the Hague Rules, the Hamburg Rules and the Visby Protocol are all about.

—-I do not think that your comment just now, Senator Collins, adds any more to the matter you raised earlier, to which I indicated that all honourable senators must relate their remarks to the Bill. Upon hearing Senator Macdonald, he is doing that. I note that he has only a minute or so left in the time allocated for his speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill 1991 will be supported by the Australian Democrats. I want to make it clear that we see this Bill as seeking to replace workable but out-of-date rules from 1924 with new but already out-of-date rules from 1979 to protect shipowners from the legal consequences of their actions. The Democrats accept this Bill, which is really a compromise, only because the way it is now written includes an intention by the Government, at some point in the future, to ratify the Hamburg Rules. As the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The main feature of the Hamburg Rules is to transfer the burden of liability from shipper to shipowner while the shipowner has care of the cargo. While this convention has been developed by the United Nations it is not yet in force internationally.

Nevertheless, we would prefer that Australia lead the countries which have already ratified the Hamburg Rules and tip the balance of legal protection away from the shipping carrier nations in favour of shipper nations such as Australia. However, the Government, in its wisdom, awaits a decision by our major trading partners to ratify the Hamburg treaty first.

Before Australia ratifies the Hamburg agreement, clause 8 of the Bill gives the Hague-Visby Rules statutory force to reduce the shipowners' liability of approximately $12,000 per package at present by one-tenth to $1,200 or $3.50 per kilogram, whichever is the greater.

The Bill's main advantage appears to be in its definition of a package or a unit of cargo which is important to Australian shippers because of the difficulty of quantifying raw materials. The Bill's legal liability limits were first established in 1979 and do not adequately reflect today's monetary values. However, the SDR Protocol does base the monetary values on a more stable international currency.

The new liability limits are also unsatisfactory when compared to the liability limit in the existing Act--one hundred pounds per package to be taken at gold value in 1924 prices; $11,760 as determined in 1986 by the New South Wales Court of Appeal in the Brown Bovery (Australia) Pty Ltd v. Baltic Shipping Co. Ltd case. Few shippers have the inclination, opportunity or financial wherewithal to sue a carrier in Australia where this provision applies.

Cargoes of manufactured goods are most likely to suffer as a result of the reduced liability. Fortunately for the Government, shippers of manufactured goods do not, as yet, constitute an effective lobby group. I am sure that the Australian shippers will wisely take out extra insurance to cover manufactured goods at sea, as the Bill does nothing to encourage shipowners to take care of Australian cargoes.

Clause 11 of the Bill does not include the same provision for Australian jurisdiction over contracts relating to the carriage of goods by sea to and from Australia as currently applies in section 9 of the existing Act. Clause 11 applies only to bills of lading, whereas section 9 of the current Act applies to bills of lading and voyage charter parties. In effect, voyage charterers--for example, Australian bulk commodity importers or exporters--will not be protected by the right to use Australian courts. A voyage charter party may provide for arbitration in London, New York or Beijing and the Australian voyage charter will be forced into commencing or defending foreign proceedings before an inconvenient forum to protect its rights. It is perhaps appropriate to mention that Japan, New Zealand and the United States have not adopted the Hague-Visby Protocols. The present Act, based on the original Hague Rules, currently operates among 85 countries.

The Australian Democrats would prefer to keep the existing Act intact until the Hamburg Rules apply. The Hamburg Rules, to our mind, actually redress the balance in favour of shipper nations with its comprehensive scope of coverage. Deck cargoes and live animals--much as they should not be shipped--are covered by Hamburg Rules but not by the Hague-Visby Protocols. Modern electronic forms of transport documentation are also covered by Hamburg Rules, but not by the Hague-Visby Protocols. Claims can be made for delays in the delivery of cargo under the Hamburg Rules, but not under the amended the Hague Rules. The Hamburg treaty extends the liability of shipowners and does not reduce them, as do the Hague-Visby Protocols--a relationship which better suits Australia as a shipper nation. It is important to make clear--as perhaps what I have said already does--our support for the Hamburg Rules. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, this Bill does not satisfy our support for those rules. However, we accept it because it indicates an intention by the Government at some future date to implement.

This Bill has been before a committee, as Senator Macdonald has said. There have been deliberations and there appears to be considerable agreement about what should occur by way of amendment. What I can make clear at this point--and what I will elaborate when it comes to the committee stage, in response to the amendments that will come forward--is that the Democrats will support strong amendments which will lead to the implementation of the Hamburg Rules. That has been our goal all along. It is what we will be looking for in amendments that come forward. The deliberations in the Committee, I believe, made that clear. Certainly our discussions in our party room support that approach.

In recent hours there has been some confusion about how subsequent amendments should be worded. We will continue our discussions on that. When we come to the committee stage, Democrat support will be gained for amendments which ensure, to the greatest possible extent, the implementation of the Hamburg Rules on the basis that we believe they provide the most appropriate framework for the situation here in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Opposition will be supporting the Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill and the amendment moved in the name of the Opposition by Senator Macdonald, who spoke so well on this Bill a short while ago. The Carriage of Goods by Sea Bill before us affects changes to Australia's marine cargo liability legislation. At present, our marine cargo liability regime is covered by the Sea Carriage of Goods Act 1924, which is built around the 1924 Hague Rules. The Hague Rules is the common name given to the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules Relating to the Bills of Lading of 1924. They limit the extent to which shipowners are liable for loss or damage of cargo in their keeping, and impose an upper limit on claims that can arise from loss.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hague Rules were the first attempt by the international community to find some means of dealing with the situation of shipowners who, if they had a free reign, liked to exclude themselves from any responsibility for the cargoes they had on board with respect to loss or damage. Many countries with which Australia has a seaborne trading relationship also support the Hague Rules--for example, Japan, which took about 27.6 per cent of the total Australian seaborne trade; and the United States which took 13.2 per cent. There are many nations which are not party to the Hague Convention, or the modifications to it that have taken place over the years.

The Hague Rules have been modified by international protocols: the Visby Protocol in 1968 and the Special Drawing Right Protocol of 1979 which updated the Hague Rules by increasing the liability limit, replacing the gold standard and redefining the cargo terms to take account of modern use of containers. The protocol to amend the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules of Law Relating to Bills of Lading, signed in Brussels on 25 August 1924, was amended on 23 February 1968 by the incorporation of the Visby Rules to become the Visby Protocol. The Visby Protocol contains technical amendments, rather than any adjustment to the basic matter of liability for the cargo.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to media reports which claim that Saddam Hussein is failing to comply with the terms of the Gulf War cease-fire and that Iraq still has a significant nuclear capacity:
(1) What is the likely outcome of pressure of further military confrontation with Iraq.

(2) What effect, if any, will Iraq's failure to comply with the terms of the cease-fire have on Australia's conditions for the lifting of economic sanctions against Iraq and will this further delay this lifting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The overriding concern of the international community remains to secure Iraqi compliance with Security Council Resolution 687 which, among other things, demands Iraqi cooperation in the removal or rendering harmless of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. President Bush first referred to the threat of military action to enforce compliance in July 1991, though he said on 28 July that it would be preferable not to use force if other methods could be employed. There is, however, continuing international concern over Iraq's lack of cooperation with visiting UN inspection teams, most recently demonstrated in the detention of a team in Baghdad. Security Council Resolution 707 of 15 August condemned Iraq for serious violations of a number of its obligations under Resolution 687, which Iraq has unconditionally accepted. In September, the Security Council and President Bush again called on Iraq to comply with the UN Resolutions. United States Government representatives said that the United States had not ruled out any options to ensure compliance. The international community hopes that, in order to avoid the risk of further military confrontation, Iraq will start complying fully with the UN Resolutions.

(2) Resolution 687 provides for the periodic review of economic sanctions by the Security Council `in the light of the policies and practices of the Government of Iraq, including the implementation of all relevant resolutions of the Security Council'. Australia does not separately stipulate conditions for the lifting of sanctions. Foodstuffs and materials for essential civilian needs are specifically exempted from sanctions. With the approval of the UN Sanctions Committee, Australian entities and companies have made sales to Iraq of wheat and other materials which meet the UN criteria. Security Council Resolution 706, adopted on 15 August 1991, allows Iraq to export up to US$1.6bn worth of oil over a six-month period in order to purchase food and humanitarian items. Resolution 712, adopted on 19 September, approves the Secretary General's detailed plan for implementing Resolution 706.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The honourable senator asked identical questions of all Ministers. The Prime Minister has provided the following answer on behalf of all Ministers:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) -- (6) Information on the membership and secretariat arrangements for most ministerial councils is included in the Commonwealth Government Directory. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 3 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Question on Notice No 535 of 7 March 1991;

(1) Was the nomination of Port Kennedy for inclusion on the Register of the National Estate considered by the Australian Heritage Commission at its June 1991 meeting; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(2) When is Port Kennedy likely to be listed on the Register of the National Estate.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the proponents are negotiating to sell part of the project to overseas interests.

(4) Is the Minister concerned that this area, which is of outstanding scientific importance, is likely to become an expensive, foreign-owned, tourist resort unless the Commonwealth Government uses its powers to prevent it.
(5) What action does the Minister intend to take on this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Port Kennedy-Becher Point nomination was considered at the meeting of the Australian Heritage Commission on 13-14 June 1991. The Commission decided that the area is of national estate significance.
(2) The area will be placed on the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate in the next gazettal which is expected to be on 26 November 1991.
(3) I understand that there has been some mention in press reports of selling parts of the project to overseas interests.
(4) As far as I am aware, the development proposal to date has been purely a matter for the WA Government.

(5) Should a Commonwealth decision be required for the development, the Commonwealth has obligations under section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act to consider prudent and feasible alternatives to the proposal and if no alternatives exist, to ensure that all reasonable measures are taken to minimise adverse effects. The Commonwealth would seek advice from the Australian Heritage Commission regarding the impact of the proposal on the national estate values of the area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 September 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the former director of the National Safety Council (Mr John Friedrich) and the former Shadow Minister for Defence (Mr Peter White) obtain copies of a report to the Federal Government entitled Counter Terrorism Capabilities in Australia, as claimed by Mr White in the House of Representatives on 4 April 1989; if not, on what evidence does the Government dispute Mr White's claims.
(2) Did the author of the report, Mr Roger Holdich, prepare an edited version of the report for public release.
(3) Will the Government publicly release either the edited version or the original report; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I indicated to the Senate on 6 April 1989 in response to a Question without Notice from Senator Newman, it appears that Mr Friedrich obtained a copy of the edited version of the report Counter-Terrorism Capabilities in Australia. The edited version does not carry a national security classification.
I am not able to confirm whether Mr White had a copy of the report.

(2) No. As the then Special Minister of State, the Hon Mick Young MP, advised the House of Representatives in a statement on 17 October 1986, the edited version of the report was made available to Commonwealth and State officials involved in counter-terrorist arrangements in Australia.
A complete copy of the report was made available to the then Leader of the Opposition.
(3) No. In his statement Mr Young indicated that the report would not be made public, and the same reasons still apply.
